RATING: 9
A ton of game for the money. Components and theme leave a lot to be desired, but the mechanics shine through. Cries out for a deluxe edition.

I also like the way it scales. Very relaxing at 2p, tense and busy at 3p, not tried 4p but guessing it's even tougher.

Update: As much as I personally enjoy the game I'm quite surprised it's climbed into the top 10. My guess would be that the core 'dice = actions' and tile placement mechanics are so satisfying that it keeps players engaged long enough to get past the initially fiddly array of building types and knowledge tiles.

RATING: 8
A game about building up your plot of land in the middle ages, acquiring mines, animals, buildings, boats etc. and using dice to limit your action choices.

This game is a bit of a departure for Feld in that there's almost always something good to do and its a game of point grabbing rather than a game where the game is hammering you.  Each turn you roll 2 dice which limit your actions you can do.  Actions are: 1) acquire a tile, 2) place a tile, 3) ship goods, 4) grab workers.  Points are scored in a myriad of ways: 1) animal tiles score, and can score cumulatively ala Taj Mahal, 2) shipping goods scores points on a per good basis, 3) completing regions scores as well as scores bonus points (the earlier you complete a region the greater the bonus), 4) one type of building has the function of points, 5) some knowledge tiles score for certain conditions at the end of the game such as building, animal type etc., 6) completing all regions of a one type score bonus points, 7) minor scoring of money, left over goods, and workers at game end.

Although your actions are limited by the dice, you have several options as to what to do each turn and the function of the worker tiles is to modify die rolls- a nice touch is that there is "wrapping" (6 to 1 for example).  I will say that despite this, dice rolls can be occasionally frustrating particularly if you consistently roll doubles (which I have a talent for).  The game plays 2-4; I have only played 2er so far but it works great at that number.  There are several different starting player boards which lend themselves to slightly different goals.  So far this is a very addictive and accessible game that the wife loves.

Own the [boardgame=110926]New Player Boards[/boardgame], [boardgame=132477]4 new hex tiles[/boardgame], [boardgame=139160]German championship board[/boardgame], [boardgame=150083]4th expansion boards[/boardgame], [boardgame=166589]Pleasure Gardens[/boardgame], [boardgame=190225]the Cloisters[/boardgame], [boardgame=234163]the Team Game[/boardgame] and the [boardgame=214005]Trade Routes[/boardgame] mini-expansions.

RATING: 6.5
The game involves placing tiles, as in Glen More, to activate abilities and score points. The tiles selected are not chosen by a rondel, as in Glen More, but by rolling two dice and using tokens to manipulate the resources, as in La Venise Du Nord. Set-collection plays a  big role, gathering multiple tiles of the same colour scores you points and completing a coloured region gives you further bonuses, as in Thurn and Taxis. The rules explanation is fairly long due to the amount of tiles available with different features, but the game is an enjoyable puzzle, if a little dry.

Traded with expansions for Furstenfeld.

RATING: 8.5
Burgundy is a much more relaxing game, you roll dice, pick which 1 of the 4 actions you want to do & you're done. The aim is to gain the most points while trying to fill up your player board. The best part is when you do some combos upon combos. And like Bora Bora, everything that you need to know is on the player board itself.

A nice balance between getting tiles, build them, selling goods & completing the areas.

RATING: 9.6
Juegazo Eurogame! Otro gran Feld. Sin cartas, con dados, pero la suerte la "planificas". Es un juego de estrategia de construccion de zonas muy especial y logrado. De 2 a 4. Funciona perfecto, más rápido, con 2 o 3 jugadores. A 4 más pique indirecto, pero más largo y hay demasiado AP. Tienes que tener en cuenta muchas cosas y gusta mucho la toma constante de decisiones. Por contra, comentar que el factor suerte, tras varias partidas, se aprecia demasiado elevado para la media de los euros. Imprescindible las expansiones de tableros nuevos para el juego: la nueva regla de construcción en éstos, le añade un punto de mayor dificultad al juego. Se puede imprimir el tablero que Feld diseñó para el torneo de 2013.

RATING: 9.5
Superb design.  Masterful balance.  

About the only criticism that could be leveled at this game is the art direction.  Not so much the art itself, which I find to be acceptable (particularly given how small the hex tiles are), but the color scheme really just makes this look bland.  If one were to choose a color to describe [i]Castles of Burgundy[/i], perhaps surprisingly, that color would not be burgundy--it would be brown.  The whole color direction of the game just leaves one with the unescapable feeling of brown.  

However, the mechanics and balance of this really shine.  It's actually fairly intuitive and easy to teach (though there are many rules--what each building does, what each bonus tile does, when particular regions are scored and how they are scored, etc.)--the iconography on the player mats has helped me play this with even unseasoned gamers.  Despite dice, it has a great mechanic for mitigating the impact of poor rolls, and part of the design beauty of the game is the planning that can go into board positioning so that one leaves oneself with good options despite the actual numbers that come out on the dice.  

I can see why this is a popular contender for championship series.  I'm looking forward to trying a few of the mini-expansions which appear to all preserve the central core of the game (outside of maybe the shipping routes).  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game has nothing to do with Ron Burgundy. It is, however, easily one of Stefan Feld's more well known games. Castles of Burgundy is a game about building your territory on your player tableu one drafted hexagonal chit at a time. You roll dice to determine what chits you are allowed to draft and where you are allowed to place them. Territories within your tableu can represent specific sets with powers that you can leverage to better score points. The theme and art are pedestrian unless you are a fan of pastoral landscapes and farm animals but the game design and play more than make up for it. One small gripe is that the game needs a insert or a Plano box or something that helps you keep all the chits sorted or you will spend a lot of time sorting each time you set up the game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Burgundy is surely not my favorite but I enjoy it nonetheless.

RATING: 6.7
An enjoyable, if somewhat fiddly, euro.  The subsystems are cleanly designed, and the variable boards and starting locations certainly keep the game relatively fresh and force the players to get used to playing on more than one clock (front runner with lots of small areas vs come from behind completer of large blocks) and with more than one subsystem (pastures close or far away, say).

My only concern is not so much about design but implementation: given fiddly art and pastel colours, I can't reliably see what's happening on other people's boards, so the dogging side of the game is less than it might be. Is that a chicken or a cow?  How many are there, anyway?  And what the heck do all of his knowledge buildings do?  Etc etc for the whole of the game.

RATING: 8
An excellent euro game that forces you to step up your optimization skills each time you play. The components look nice, if a bit dated but they certainly feel good too. It contains many balance fixes for differing numbers of players. Typically, however, first mover advantage isn't solved by simply adding another worker (ability to change a die face by +/- 1). As tiles get drafted, the players going last must settle for what's left. Ultimately, there are enough unique tiles that any player can attempt to make up the points with a long-run strategy. One downfall of the game would be the fighting over going first (or second in a 4-player game) as it does have such a significant advantage.

RATING: N/A
The game is set in the Burgundy region of High Medieval France. Each player takes on the role of an aristocrat, originally controlling a small princedom. While playing they aim to build settlements and powerful castles, practice trade along the river, exploit silver mines, and use the knowledge of travelers.

The game is about players taking settlement tiles from the game board and placing them into their princedom which is represented by the player board. Every tile has a function that starts when the tile is placed in the princedom. The princedom itself consists of several regions, each of which demands its own type of settlement tile.

RATING: 9
2-4(2,3)

UPDATE: Yeah, it's a fun one. It's interesting, on account of every action feeling "small" and even redundant (many of the buildings do things you could do yourself ... though I guess with the benefit of filling your board) so it feels awfully slow-moving (likely why some thing it feels about 20 minutes too long), but there is that tangible progression. I'm enjoying this so far.

-------------------------------------------------------

You know, Stefan Feld gets a lot of crap for pasted-on themes and dry, soulless Euros, but I think he's a pretty clever designer. I'm a mechanics geek and each of his games pulls interesting mechanisms together in a fun way. I've never really been let down by his games: Notre Dame, Luna, Macao, and now Burgen. I was turned off when I played the PC version of In the Year of the Dragon, but now I'm tempted to see how it plays face-to-face.

dBvB is a clever game that limits your options with the dice, but has a very easy way to sort of manipulate things so that you can do what you want. There are a lot of things to remember (not building the same building in a "city" is a rule we missed, say) and it's hard to figure out the way to "win" but it's a great puzzle.

RATING: 10
Keep 2018.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
An amazingly clever game of dice rolling and tile placement, that uses dice in some unique and interesting ways.

Across 5 rounds of 5 turns, players roll two dice.  The values of the dice determine the actions the players can make on that turn; collecting resources or planning buildings, placing them into their own landscape, acquiring workers and all manner of other options.  And there are options galore in this game - even though your two dice determine two actions, performing some of those actions allows you to chain further actions from them.

With so many potential options, the game does tend toward a moderate level of AP and because most of the resources are available to all, having someone take one of the resources you were after often means you have to revise your strategy on each turn, and the dice values can often constrict your actions.

Playing around 30 mins per player, I felt the game just slightly overstayed its welcome, but I can see the game becoming much quicker once you knew the nature of the pieces and with less than 4 players.

The only criticisms I have of the game is that the theme is meaningless, several of the colours are difficult to differentiate and some of the graphics are too small to be seen easily.  But these are minor concerns for a truly great game.

Overall, I found CoB to be an impressive combination of mechanisms, multiple options, manifold paths to victory and combined with a unique use of dice.  I thoroughly enjoyed the game and look forward to trying it with 2 players.

RATING: 10
Castles of Burgundy is Stefen Feld at his best. He once again takes the randomizing characteristics of 6-sided dice and turns them into something strategic. Each turn those dice rolls give you hard decisions to make. Take a building from the board, place said building or get workers to help you next turn. And while there is the chance you'll get shut out of what you really want you are never left without an option. It plays very easy. But the game can get a little long especially in the final rounds when your placement is so critical. If you are hesitant about buying your first Feld game we do not think you can go wrong starting with this one.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Dice games fall into the love 'em or hate 'em category all to easily.  Most of the time the hate comes from the feeling that the dice are (or the player is) cursed.  CoB avoids this very well.  Each turn's die results can be applied in many different ways and one key to playing this well seems to be positioning yourself for future turns to take advantage of whatever the die falls.  And it turns out that it is quite possible to plan for this too.  Which makes the game quite enjoyable.  It has very limited player interaction (mostly limited to interfering with tile drafts) - but the interaction can have a profound impact on an opponent's scoring.  You can try to ignore your opponents actions and you will find that doing so makes winning harder.  So while the interaction is subtle, it is important.  This game is also a great one for a casual game event.  You can talk / socialize with the other players while playing this one and still enjoy the game.  One of the best dice placement / tile-laying / set collection... Feld soup games out there.  Definitely a good game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A bit of an oldie these days, but a goodie. A great strategy game that gets your noggin working. Definitely recommended if you want to add a little weight to your collection, but don't want to scare newcomers with too much complexity. Does come with quite a few punchout cards. My copy came with both an English & French rulebook. Gameplay flows well, once everyone at the table is familiar with the rules. Some may find it boring, as it doesn't draw theme to it's forefront. The goal is to roll dice and choose your actions wisely or rather make the best out of what the game gives you to score the most points. 7.5/10 just because Euros aren't my strongest mechanic.

RATING: 9
Feld is clever. There is no doubt about that here. He makes dice actually great, by making their results the inputs into your decision-making rather than determining the effectiveness of decision outputs.

There is little more satisfying in games than kicking off a combo of tiles that lets you get and lay down four tiles or so.

The game's largest flaw, as with many Feld games, is that it feels like it should end about 20% sooner. I think I'll try removing one round from each phase some time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
While this game is little more than a point-salad, it has  immense replayability, tons of meaningful decisions, a healthy amount of tension, and scales incredibly well for 2-4 players. Each turn feels like a different tactical puzzle where players must find the best way to earn VP. And if players are observant, they will soon realize that this game isn't a solitaire experience as blocking/stealing tiles is a substantial threat. Overall, I really enjoy this game.

Is it perfect? Mechanically, it's difficult to fault this game. There is randomness but the dice serve more to focus players than mitigate their decisions; players often have numerous things to do and can modify dice-rolls easily. But component wise, there is more to be desired; The chits/mats are thin and the tokens would benefit from being more distinguishable. Simply put, this game deserves a deluxe edition.

RATING: 10
After 2 plays, I confess to being underwhelmed; by 4-5, I was intrigued; by 8-9, totally hooked. I adore this game!
It's a kind of delumptious torture, where you know perfection (filling 36 hexes) is impossible but nevertheless entices you to want to try and try again to better your previous. 
I know some, whilst loving CoB, are put off by the quality/colour of the tiles and yearn for a deluxe edition upgrade. I for one are not one of them. I actually like the game as is; it kinda has its own daggy charm. For me, it's perfect!
A great game.

RATING: 8.5
Stefan Feld is slowly finding a little place among my favorite designers. The last three Feld designs I tried intrigued me (In the Year of the Dragon, Luna and Burgen) at the very least.
This game has two immediately visible drawbacks: it has a very thin theme, and a quite terrible artwork (the components are way too small, and the colors are too "beige"! I must admit, anyway, that the graphic design is very functional). These two factors kept it away from the table for a long time before its inaugural cruise.
The gameplay, however, is fast (the idea of keeping the number or dice - and therefore actions - low is the decisive factor here), there is space for combos and specialization, and everything clicks quickly and in a very logical way.

One of my favorite Feld designs.

RATING: 10

RATING: 6
First Play: seduced into a game before I saw the cubes of death in person and their nasty little pictures printed all over the player board. To be honest, given a choice I wouldn't have started. However, this is not so bad as far as most dice games go. Yes the tendancy for the dots to fail to match your prefered moves and locations, time and time again, is bloody annoying. OK that can be mitigated by using workers to nudge the numbers in the right direction. I took the yellow tile that make a worker worth 2 for this purpose but it still wasn't enough. I seemed to be cashing in a die for workers every other go. That pissed me off for a start.

My next issue is the randomness of the tile distribution. Again you can get caught cold when turn order puts you at the back of the pack. It seemed no coincidence that the eventual winner and second place both scooped three mines each before the rest of us got one. That gets the cash machine rolling and you are on the back foot trying to get those central tiles if you are left out.

Because preceeding players will most certainly pinch your prefered turn there seems little point tring to plan ahead. There does seem to be a fair bit of down time.

The mechanism is quite clever but the chaos turns me off wanting to play this again. I certainly wouldn't buy it.

RATING: 7.5
An elegant game of building up your village(?) by competing over tiles to add to your player board. Even though you roll some dice that dictate your options, there's always something you can do to further your progress. There's a slight learning curve regarding what buildings do and how things interact but overall the rules are pretty easy to grasp. The board/graphic design is a bit "bleh" with all the muted colors but that doesn't bother me too much. There's not much to fault about this game. This, like it's box-kin Puerto Rico, is a game I don't get super excited about but I can see playing sporadically for years to come as it does what it sets to do extremely well.

RATING: 8
Castles of Burgundy is good fun but I'm not entirely sold on it yet, since I am still learning the nuances. So, I could be wrong on this but, the game feels too static. Almost any tile can be bought at almost any time, and most tiles have only instantaneous effects, so I didn't get that sense of growing from a tiny fiefdom into a kingdom of power and wealth. I would greatly prefer if there were costs and prerequisites that limited buying power in the early game and that affected choices later on for more strategic play and a sense of an unfolding story. As it is, the various board layouts don't do enough to offer a decent arc.

RATING: 7.7
Another game by Stefan Feld that uses dice in a rather interesting way. While being a bit less abstract than the dud Macao the theme is rather unoriginal to say the least. Still, building a city is always fun and managing how to expand yours to profit the most from the special actions makes for interesting decisions. The game is all about timing and a bit of luck. It's not very deep and there is almost no player interaction, but it's still an enjoyable medium level eurogame.

RATING: 7
I enjoyed this as I usually enjoy Feld games.  There are a lot of little pieces working together and enough flexibility for players to do what they want to do, but I'm not sure that long term replay-ability will be great.

After the second play, I think replay-ability might actually be there.  However, I've realized that it really just is a big game of maximizing in the moment.  I thought my wife would enjoy this game and she liked it okay in the first play, liking it more in the second play for her.

I don't dislike CoB, but the more I play it the less I like it.  I've traded away my copy and then tried it again a year later and it was okay but not good enough.  I'm probably done with this game.

The first ever game to reappear in my collection by my purchase after I got rid of it... a used copy in excellent condition was available at a reasonable price. I'm looking forward to playing it again.

My rating for this game has gone from 8 to 6 to 8 and now I've put it at a 7. That feels like where it belongs. It's not a great game, but pretty good. I'll keep it and probably play it once or twice per year.

RATING: 8
Another Feld masterpiece.  I expect my rating to go up.  Unlike other Feld games, it does not have any punishment/penalities if you don't do something.  But, it has a ton going on and what seems to me on first play a multitide of ways to go about earning points.  Timing is important in this one, as well.  Another great Alea game.  

I'm not sure what it feels like.  Turn order reminds me of Macao/ItYotD.  Taking tiles is like Notre Dame (and El Grande) where you take tiles into storage and then deploy onto the board with an action.  Some tiles have a variety of in game and end game bonuses which reminds me of the cards in Macao.  And it all is driven by using dice for action selection and for placement on the board.  But, it's not lucky dice as long as you have workers to adjust your dice (like Kingsburg).  

But, the game feels unique and really struck a chord with me.  It played very well with two.  I learned straight from the rule book and I felt we got through it without mistake.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I will admit I am not much of a Feld fan; about the only two games he has made that even potentially interest me are Trajan, which I have yet to play, and Castle of Burgundy, which I would call a Feld game for people who don't necessarily like Feld games (and also for people who do).

What gives Castles an edge is the way that the dice you roll, plus the location of where particular tiles are dealt in the board, gives enough variability to make action selection a genuine choice, rather than a scripted affair where you never have to deviate from your chosen strategy. Variable maps provide additional levels of specialization and keep the game fresh. It does still have the point salad feel, but there are big payoffs for staying focused on one or two areas. I traded away my copy as part of an offer I couldn't refuse, but I wouldn't mind reacquiring it somewhere down the line.

RATING: 7
An enjoyable but repetitive game of set collection.  It has a novel mechanic for 6-sided dice.  You use your die rolls (2d6) to collect tiles and/or place tiles, then repeat (again and again).  Large sets generally get more points.  After a second play, I think there's too much luck of the dice (and tiles for each round) for a game of this length that "wants" to be a fairly meaty strategy game.  The many small decisions tend to increase down-time between turns and ultimately the winner seems to be the person who got better dice rolls to take advantage of opportunities in tiles/majority positions.  Sure, there are dice modifiers, but if you have to use them every turn to fix your bad dice to try to slow down the leader(s), you're gonna lose.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Castles of Burgundy is a game that has grown on me quite a bit as we have played it.  It offers a medium depth, 90-120 minute experience that scales well from 2-4 players.  It takes a game or two to get familiar with all the tiles, but is fairly streamlined once you understand what everything does.  

The heart of CoB is that you acquire tiles from a common offer, and play them onto your personal board for points.  There are 25 turns, in 5 rounds of 5 turns each, with the tile offer refreshing after each round of 5 turns.  Every turn, players roll 2 dice, and each die allows an action which is constrained by the value on the die.  Generally, players can use a die to take a tile from the common offer and put it in their storage, to play a tile from storage to their board, to sell goods, or to take 2 workers, which allow modification of die values.  All of the tiles offer some kind of ability that activates when they are played to the board - everything from VPs to extra moves, to changing turn order.  The net result is that the dice constrain one's choices some, but there are many combos that can be pulled off as well.  The game asks the players to correctly value the tiles on offer and prioritize them, taking into account what everyone else needs, while maintaining flexibility to work with whatever the dice give.  

This is a favorite of my wife's, and has been well received by the two sets of friends we play games with most often.  It is interesting, and reasonably intuitive after the first round or so.  It offers a nice amount of depth and decisions, while keeping each turn brief to minimize downtime.  CoB is an excellent game, and one that has the right accessibility and depth to warrant a place in just about every collection.

First Impression: 

A good solid game. I see why people compare this to Macao, but to me it feels totally different. The long term planning aspect is significantly less and less connected than Macao. Overall a solid game, but of Feld's three games that I own, this is the one that I am least excited to play again.

*note*

I think high expectations played into my initial rating and impressions. Now that those expectations are lowered it will be interesting to see how I enjoy/rate this game after a couple plays.

*note*

I have now played CoB 10 times and I have to say my enjoyment has gone up with more experience. Now that I feel have a better understanding of how the game works I enjoy it quite a bit more. RATING: 7
Very impressed after one play.  Inspired, intricate game design.  Lots of moving parts, which seem overwhelming at first, but are fairly intuitive after a few minutes.  The choices range from a cornucopia at the beginning of each turn to doing the best you can with what little is left by the end.

Lacks that typical "Woe is me" feeling of many Felds, but certainly has plenty of long-term vs. short-term decisions.  I like how dice are used to narrow the choices to a manageable number, but the limitations can be mitigated by the choices made earlier.  (I was fortunate in my first game to go into the last turn with the ability to almost ignore the dice if needed, but I still found myself on the last two phases meticulously counting my resources to be sure I could pull off what I wanted to do.)

I can't help wondering how this game was birthed in Feld's mind.  What thoughts led to such an intricate interweaving of ideas and mechanisms?  A second play may bring me down to Earth, but right now, I'm very impressed.

8 Plays: A couple strategies seem to dominate, but I still enjoy it.

11 Plays: The advanced boards eliminate the dominant strategy problem, but introduce a balance issue as some boards are clearly superior.

26 Plays: The issue about unbalanced boards is mostly a non-issue (board #8 not withstanding). Played our first 3er with the Speilbox boards. Michelle scored 226 after almost being locked out of an all important castle in round 4. 

31 Plays: Not a fan of the new restrictive rules that came with the Spielbox boards. You can get hosed pretty badly and end up spinning tires for whole rounds for lack of a castle or space you can legally play in. We use the new boards but with the original rules. 

37 Plays: Pretty much done with CoB. Still, it had a good run!

67.5 hours

[b]TOTAL = 442.5/50 = 8.85[/b]


:thumbsup: [b]POSITIVE POINTS:[/b]

++ Great medium-weight tile-drafting strategy point-salad game with many paths to victory.
++ I like the fact that you only have two actions (dice) per turn with a limited choice of 4 different actions to do with these dice. This keep the focus to optimizing your turn.
++ I love the fact that even if you have a limited number of actions each turn, you can plan and do a super satisfying longer turn by combo-chaining a lot of actions back to back.
++ Scales really well and elegantly (just add more tiles to the setup) between all player counts (But the game take longer to play).
++ Great replayability due to using different player's  "map", the random tiles drawn during phases' setup and that not all tiles will show up in a single game (especially at lower number of players and because there is a lot of tiles).
++ Good value, as all Alea title (component of relatively good quality, but great price point).
++ There are smalls expansions (especially new player maps and some new tiles too) available for this game (which is useful to refresh the game when we have overplayed it).


:thumbsdown: [b]NEGATIVE POINTS:[/b]

-- Like many other have already said, the color choice (or at least the contrast of these colors) could have been better.
-- This feels like a multi-player solitaire game with few player interactions beside the main board and it can turn off some players (though I don't mind this especially that I usually play this game with my wife, so this turn out to be a good thing!).
-- The mini expansions are a bit expensive for what we get, but if you really like the base game, some are still worth it (though I would have prefer a real expansion consisting of all these mini-expansions bundled together that we could have bought in one shot).

Player Count Preference = Best at 2, recommended at 3 and 4! :thumbsup::thumbsup:
[/b]

RATING: 7
Castles of Burgundy is a great example of a game with a super simple rule set, but tons of decisions to be made within those simple rules.  There are a ton of ways to score points here, and balancing all those ways to score points is really challenging and brain burny.

The only complication comes in the form of the functions of all the buildings, which is actually what put me off this game for so long.  I was afraid that remembering all those special abilities would be a chore.  However, they really end up not being all that bad, and since the ability is only activated once, there's no need to remember what a tile does once you place it in your castle.

While I would advise playing with the starter boards in the first game, I really enjoyed the choices presented by the variable set-up boards.  Each board seems to have a focus, and even the decision of where to put the starting castle is difficult!

Overall, I found the game to be a good time, but without any real "wow" or fun factor.  It is a fun puzzle though, and I look forward to giving it some more play.

RATING: 6
If this isn't the game that inspired the term point salad, it should have been. On almost every turn of the game, you will get points, as so many of the actions give you them. And you just play to get as many for yourself as you can (although the beginning of each round will be more about acquiring tiles, and the end of the round more about placing them, just a question of going with the ebb and flow of the tile refresh rate).

Very solitaire, although you will occasionally choose option A over option B because while they are identical to you, it costs another player a point or two (out of two hundred or so).

RATING: 9
This is a real gem by Stefan Feld - the man is a fount of innovative games!  I have never played a dice / tile-laying game like this before.  There is a dizzying variety of ways to score victory points here, whether it be by completing regions of your estate, animal farming, selling goods, or maximizing bonus points from Knowledge tiles.  Often, many of those scoring options are available in any given turn and one is forced to judge which is best.  This flexibility also keeps the game engaging even when few tiles are available or when a bad dice roll(s) is made.  Some might be wary of the element of randomness introduced by the dice, but it is fairly minimal and easily mitigated by planning ahead and using worker tiles.  A top shelf Euro!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b]includes 4th expansion -- the monastery boards[/b]

Die Burgen von Burgund is one of the better dice-based resource games I've played, although admittedly, I haven't played many. You have two dice that provide you with (generally) two actions each turn, with the dice pips limiting your available options. However, the kicker is that the game provides you with plenty of things to do. Gradually throughout the game, you build your town with hex-based buildings and features.

Castles of Burgundy is a relaxing affair. There's not a ton that players can do to really mess with your plans, so it's more a race of efficiency and good planning. For those looking for a solid Euro light on conflict, this one is a winner. It also happens to be a game my wife really enjoys, and it's very solid as a two player.

RATING: 9.5
One of my favorites.  Plays very well with two, three or four players, and your strategy changes with each.  Game mechanics signify which turn and phase you are in, which is a very nice design touch.  Lots of ways to score points, which may be a turn off to some, is a great asset as come from behind victories are very possible with careful planning - to me this makes the game exciting and I'm always on the edge of my seat.  Great balance of luck versus strategy.

Two complaints that stop this from being a 10.  The hexes are so small, and the color scheme is very bland, which leads to consistent confusion on which tiles are which (the piece size I understand though, as it keeps the cost of the game down).  Second, the box is ill suited for the game (again though, they recycle boxes to keep prices down).  I solved the latter by modifying the insert by placing dividers to cut each tray in half, and this solved the problem.

Hmm...with that said, I'm changing my ranking to a 9.5 since the second complaint is solved.  In fact, I can play this in a bar comfortably by playing the tiles from the box.

Really solid game with lucid rules that explain the great options left open to the player.  These options allow for plenty of interesting choices.  Plays GREAT with any number.  Only real complaint is the lack-luster art design and box (which you too can remedy easily!).

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This was my first Feld game (and really, my first "larger" euro beyond Catan) and I went through three stages of understanding with it that went something like this:

1) oh my god this is the biggest rulebook I have ever seen dear god why

2) Oh, this is actually... really simple once you understand it.

3) oh my god no it's not simple it's like someone set off a string of firecrackers in my brain

The phrase "point salad" has been tossed around (get it) and it's true. Little bunches of points here and there for doing nearly everything. And that's the puzzle to solve: what do you do, in this very moment, that will net you the most of those bunches now, but even more later? Your choices branch, and spread, and branch again, until you're sitting there muttering to yourself for ages, mentally working through the choices that fractal out before you. It's absolutely a game that you can fall into analysis paralysis with, but I never found it getting too bogged down because of this.

The dice mechanic is clever. It has gentle indirect conflict by buying tiles out from the other player's nose. The whole game is just so damn satisfying to play, but is balanced by having everything you want just a little out of your reach. If you could just... stretch a little... further... and then the game has finished and you haven't completed half of the things you set out to do (or maybe that's just me)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
What makes Castles of Burgundy so brilliant isn't just that it plays well online both at http://www.yucata.de and http://www.boiteajeux.net. No, what makes it brilliant is that, unlike many worker placement games like Stone Age and Kingsburg, the total sum of your die doesn't contribute to your success. Instead, if you roll, say, snake eyes, you can take a tile in the 1 spot and place it on your map that is for the 1 spot. The idea is to fill your multi-colored, multi-numbered map.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

RATING: 5
Subjectwise: again clear that Stefan Feld was allowed to fondle the design at length, breaking the poor thing's joyous spirit and utterly and irrevocably draining it of anything that might resemble something human in the process. The preview video posted at Cliquenabend shows a rather abstract prototype: really, it looks a lot better than the kitschy retheme of castles in Burgundy, and stresses very well the fact that Feld's games are never about a subject, and all about clean and sterile mathematics. Stefan Feld is the Mr. Spock (or Data, whomever you prefer) of game design. 

Game-technically DBvB is a friendly game of dice-driven puzzling. The game doesn't do anything complex or exponential, it's only about making smart choices based on random inputs and generous modifier schemes. This is the Good Way to do dice; it's perhaps not as clever as in Yspahan or Troyes, but as the game progresses you can always select from several [i]interesting[/i] options no matter what the dice come up on. The skill is in recognising the best option, and perhaps foiling the plans of the other players in the process. Because this title has no point snowball engine, there is a continuous feel of involvement right to the end. That is also fine with me. The downside is, unfortunately, that with 4 players it takes too long to play to completion. There is a not insignificant amount of calculations involved, and since planning your exact actions is not really possible until it is your turn, the game begins to drag. As a result I want to stick to the lower end of the indicated player range.

When I first played it, I was pleasantly surprised by Feld's offspring, and put it on my purchase list. Then came along a second puzzle game of his, Trajan, and speaking for myself Trajan really renders Burgen obsolete. The reason is simply that the dice in this title become boring after a while: there is no sense of accomplishment when you decide on how to use the dice. Trajan's Mancala wheel is rather different and offloads its use entirely onto the player, making him completely responsible for an efficient traversal of the game's action state space. Burgen is dumb in this respect, and when I play it I never feel engaged or challenged. That is of course not the same as playing the game well: there [i]is[/i] skill in selecting the proper action. But there isn't much to tie multiple turns in a row together, and that's what bugs me. Consequently I've downgraded the rate for this game: it also indicates my stance on which of the two titles is 'better' much more clearly than previously.

RATING: 8
Very solid euro style game.  The Castles of Burgundy is a gamers game with lots of things to consider and multiple paths to victory.  The large hexagonal player maps are broken down into lots of small hexes.  Players take actions, eventually placing hexagonal tiles on their personal play maps and score points through out the game.  There is also a final scoring at the end.  The hex chit mechanisms create a plethora of opportunities which can seem overwhelming to new players.  The game has good replayability and is fun and challenging to play.  I like The Castles of Burgundy with either 3 or 4 players at the table.  The Castles of Burgundy made my top 50 games for euro style games I enjoy playing of all time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Truly a remarkable game by Stefan Feld.  While his games often have interlocking mechanisms, this one gives the player more room for independent choices.

Each turn players roll two dice, and the numbers allow them to perform actions - take a tile, place a tile, ship goods, or take workers.  Workers help alter the luck of the die roll, while the variety of tiles offer options for points.

A little tile-laying, a twist on worker placement, and a new twist on dice in board games.  There are so many ways to score points that it makes your head spin - yet there is no clear path to victory.  Plus there are a variety of player boards, offering endless variety.  Don't want to play too long?  Simply cut down the number of phases.

Lots of options and easy to dive into once you get a hang of it.  This is just a great game and I look forward to playing it again soon.

RATING: 9.5

The art is OK - I don´t get why everyone claims it is so ugly - maybe some depictions could be more clear or difference between light green and yellow is not too big, but overall I am not disappointed by the artistic part of the game. 

What I like:
- this is a perfect two player game, good for "nongamers" as there is no direct conflict
- The tactics and strategy is a big part of the game, dice only narrow your options. And there is nice amount of luck involved.
- overall, the game atmosphere is nice, I just enjoy playing this, everything clicked for me here.
- lots of different boards (some weaker, some stronger) adds to the replayability a lot

What I dislike:
- game boards could be thicker 
- the color palette is not very good, I assume light green, dark green and yellow tiles could do some issues for somebody (especially when playing in the darker room)
- you should be careful what board you choose, some boards are just impossible to beat with the weak ones (but on the other side this can possibly solve the issue with different player strength)

RATING: 10
I should not like this game.  I don't like most modern Euros.  I don't like worker placement (although this isn't'), and I prefer to find engines in cars, not games (although there isn't much of an engine in this).  The learning curve on this one can cause some new players (my wife) to get frustrated with it, and insist that they'll never play it again.  So why do I like it?  Maybe because once I figured out the intricate way everything fit together, the game just grew on me.  It's solid, the theme works, the mechanisms work, and the challenge of the game is one that intrigues me enough that I'm OK with the fact that there is absolutely NO relationship between the theme and the mechanism.  

UPDATE: November, 2015: rating has bumped up from 8 to 9.  The fact that this game rocks with two players has a lot to do with that.

UPDATE: December, 2016: rating is now 10.

RATING: 7.5
This game is sleek, streamlined, and plays like a dream. It's a good length and scales well to any player count. The decisions you make regarding what to do with your dice are rarely cut-and-dry. The pieces are ugly. The theme, if there even is one, is powerfully boring. Which is to say: this is a hard game to get people interested in. It can even be a hard game to get myself interested in--and I already know I like it. I consider that a problem.

RATING: 9
The Castles of Burgundy is a solid competitive game for those who like to think, calculate and strategize. The artwork is dull but game play is tight and tense. 

The strategic aspect comes from controlling the random elements of the setup and optimizing the tile abilities to maximize victory points. Players have to work with the random die rolls and random tiles available each round. They have to choose the tiles wisely and place them in just the right order so that their abilities work together to multiple their benefits. 

The limited selection of tiles each round reduces AP and encourages tactical moves. There is room for long-term planning but to win, players have to be flexible and responsive to change. In this sense, "Castles" has a nice balance between luck and skill. Veteran players definitely have an edge but new players can still stand a chance.

The random setup coupled with extra player boards provided mean high replayability. If you only want a pretty-looking game, this is not for you. But if you care even a little about the game play experience, you will enjoy "Castles" and quickly forget the shortcoming in the art department.

RATING: 10
I love the weight of this game.  The decisions are rich but not stressful.  The brain burn is there, but it's not overwhelming, especially since there's no punishment mechanism. I love teaching it to new players and they usually grasp it quickly. With 50 actions a game, theres plenty of time for new players to "click" with whats going on start really playing instead of trying to figure it out the first time around.  And even with the 25 turns it usually moves fast. The use of dice is awesome. They limit your choices, but not your strategy, and can always be mitigated.  People harp on the art, but I don't mind the found in a 70's attic look.  Yes it could be better, but as it is it's got charm to me. Feld's not much for theme, but the mechanics are so strong that it's like watching a work of art come together when you play it.  A super duper solid mid weight euro.  Definitely amongst my favorite, if not my #1

RATING: 9.1
The first visual impression is not the best and all the boards and tokens are made of plain cardboard (well, that also helps to keep the game price low).
In the first steps, it also seems that one is going to be lost among all the different building abilities, however, just after one or two rounds...the ideias start to flood in one´s head, our hands rush to grab the tiles we want or need (sometimes even jumping the turn order!), we get excited by how many different ways we can make points and how we get thrilled to find an action that scores a couple more points than other action that was already good in itself...
There´s always a great enjoyment in a game where you have two actions but can always use them to do something useful - the question is that if you can optimize the most of those actions, fulfil objectifs earlier than other players, etc
Although some work is required to build the set up after each round (5 rounds overall), the game plays in just about 90 min with players with some knowledge and is a great experience that soon becomes addictive.
A great work, possible the greatest until now, by Stefan Feld!

RATING: 6
Critically acclaimed by BGG on the whole and my first Feld game. Going to this from Kingsburg felt like a next step toward Euro gaming.

Neutral: Cheaper quality components keep cost down, but not bad quality. Building the estate isn't like going up a tech tree.

Cons: small cardboard chits and symbols which make it hard to read in some lighting. Lack of plastic bags and useless box tray make component separation and game setup a problem.

Despite the variable setup, the game doesn't seem that deep strategically.

RATING: 8
I really like aesthetics in my games as well as the tactile feel of components and this game just doesn't have any of that. The color choices are abysmal and the component quality leaves a bit to be desired. I really don't understand why designers/publishers of euros can't put even a tiny bit more effort in the artwork/theme/components of their games.

However, Castles of Burgundy with it's green/yellow/brown mesh of blah somehow finds a way to charm the hearts of many. I am not immune because I can't help but really enjoy this game every time I bring it to the table.

The game is so simple and elegant and yet provides a nice puzzle to try and piece together while also working out what your opponents need and getting those tiles before they can.

The turns are lightning quick and the game always ends sooner than you want.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This is a great game.  I really enjoy the fact that the "luck" of dice rolling can be changed using your workers, so you always have the chance to change what luck has provided.  There are so many different ways to score points that it becomes a bit too "analytical" for some peoples tastes, and that's where the beauty of the game comes through for me.  You truly have to think about what the "best" option is for you each turn, because all options are good in their own way.  The limited "vision" provided the players each round makes it interesting also - each round, tiles are replaced with news tiles, therefore you don't now how your strategy may need to change based on what is available.  I believe this game can be played in under an hour, but the true play time will be determined by how much analyzing each player does on their turn - this could mean a 2 hour game, or longer.  But I do recommend Castles of Burgundy, it's very fun.

RATING: 10
I bought this game on a whim after finding it on Amazon for $19.99. I was looking for a game with decent depth that could play well with two players (for my wife and I), with the option to scale up to more players if needed. What a pleasant surprise this game was! It took us a game or two to fully understand the tile icons, but once you get the hang of it the game is very intuitive, and the player aids on the player boards and rule book help tremendously. 

What I love about this game: It uses dice in a very interesting way, with a good luck mitigation mechanism of using "workers" to plus or minus a die's result. Not feeling lucky? You can stock up on workers to ensure that you'll get the result you are looking for. I love the variable player boards, so each game you will have a different strategy. The game isn't too confrontational, but there are moments when your opponent will unintentionally (or intentionally) take what you need. The game length is just right for me (though if my wife wants to play, this will probably be the only game she plays that night...each game usually takes us around 90 minutes, but we are in no rush). People complain about the art, but I couldn't care less. This game is great!

Game set up was the only draw back to this game. The insert the game comes with is not ideal. I tried drawstring bags, but eventually purchased a Plano box which fits perfectly in the box and organizes everything wonderfully.

RATING: 6
So far I've only played this game twice (and only with the number 1 player boards) and will certainly play it again. However, so far I don't enjoy it as much as I had hoped to.

I am a big fan of dice games and enjoy the central mechanic. However, there are a few things that really let the game down for me. 

Firstly; it seems to suffer from that thing which is often criticised in heavy Euros - it's too balanced. It seems very difficult to pull away from the crowd in any meaningful way.

Secondly; the single-hex village space means that lucky rolling in the first turn can create a significant advantage for the first player able to complete this (10 bonus points for completing in the first turn and 5-7 for the bonus tile). Given that it's most likely that all players will easily fill up about 3 quarters of their boards over the course of the game, there's no good reason to choose to start a larger village at this stage instead - any player who gets the opportunity will be guaranteed to take it.

Thirdly; (and this is only a small niggle really) the "Knowledge" tiles seem lazily unthematic - why not call them universities or monasteries or something?

RATING: 8
Excellent Feld game.  Simple dice action mechanic.  Luck can be offset by worker tiles.  Tiles can be played in specific order to create chain combos, which is both satisfying and integral to strategy.  Some aspects of the game can feel tacked on, mainly the "goods" mechanic.  Luck does have a significant role in this game (dice), but a clever player can usually make the most of his/her rolls.  The game scales decently, although the 2 player game can be cheapened by lack of "mine" tiles, making turn order a killer.  All in all, a really enjoyable game, with many different paths to victory.

RATING: 10
2-4

Doel van het spel:

Na de 5de etappe (25 rondes) volgt er een eindwaardering. De speler met de meeste punten wint het spel. In geval van gelijkstand wint de speler die heerst over het vorstendom met de meeste lege velden. Is het nog steeds gelijk, dan wint de speler die het laatst aan bod kwam volgens het spelersvolgordespoor. 

Voorbereiding:

+ Sorteer alle tegels per kleur (rugzijde) en leg ze gedekt naast het speelbord. + Schud alle goederentegels. Maak 5 gedekte stapels van 5 tegels, leg op ieder veld (A-B-C-D-E) 1 stapel en leg de rest gedekt naast het speelbord. 
+ Leg de bonuskaarten op hun desbetreffende plaats op het speelbord. 
+ Iedere speler kiest een kleur en ontvangt: 2 dobbelstenen, 2 pionnen (1 spelersvolgordespoor en 1 puntenspoor), een spelersbord met 1 burcht, 3 willekeurige goederentegels (dezelfde tegels komen op elkaar te liggen) en één zilverling. 
+ Kies een startspeler en hij krijgt de witte dobbelsteen + 1 arbeider. De volgende speler, met de wijzers van de klok mee, ontvangt 2 arbeiders, de derde speler ontvangt 3 arbeiders, ..... Ook de spelersvolgorde op het spelersvolgordespoor wordt aangepast: startspeler bovenaan, daaronder de 2de speler, daaronder de 3de speler, .... 

Speelverloop:

Het spel bestaat uit 5 etappes (van A tot E) 

Voorbereiding van iedere etappe: 

+ Alle overgebleven tegels (geen goederentegels) worden van het speelbord verwijderd.
+ De meest linkse gedekte stapel goederentegels wordt open gelegd.
+ Vul het speelbord opnieuw aan met zeshoekige tegels (aantal is afhankelijk van het aantal spelers) met de overeenkomstige kleur. 

Elke etappe bestaat uit 5 rondes.

Een speelronde bestaat uit: 

A/ Witte dobbelsteen 

De startspeler gooit met de witte dobbelsteen en plaatst de bovenste goederentegel op het overeenkomstige veld met de dobbelsteenwaarde. 

B/ Acties 

Iedere speler gooit met zijn dobbelstenen en de startspeler voert zijn volledige beurt uit. Daarna speelt de volgende speler op het volgordespoor (van rechts naar links, in een toren van boven naar onder) zijn spelbeurt, enz.... Je kan per beurt maar 2 acties uitvoeren (1 actie/dobbelsteen). Eenzelfde actie mag meermaals gekozen worden. De volgende acties zijn beschikbaar: 

1/ Tegel van het speelbord nemen: 

De speler neemt een tegel naar keuze van het depot (speelbord) gelijk aan de dobbelsteenwaarde. Hij legt de tegel in zijn opslagplaats (onderaan links op zijn spelersbord, niet in zijn vorstendom). 

2/ Tegel in jouw vorstendom plaatsen: 

De speler plaatst een tegel vanuit zijn opslagplaats in zijn vorstendom. Hij plaatst de tegel op een vrij veld gelijk aan de dobbelsteenwaarde en altijd grenzend aan minstens één al reeds geplaatste tegel. De kleur van de tegel moet overeenkomen met het kleur van het veld. De eigenschap van de tegel wordt geactiveerd (Zie tegels). 

3/ Goederen verkopen: 

De speler verkoopt al zijn goederen van de soort gelijk aan de dobbelsteenwaarde. Alle tegels worden omgedraaid en de speler krijgt 1 zilverling + overwinningspunten (waarde/goederentegel = aantal spelers). 

4/ Arbeiders nemen: 

De speler ontvangt 2 arbeidersfiches ongeacht het getal op zijn dobbelsteen. Een speler kan eenmaal tijdens zijn beurt 2 zilverlingen betalen om een tegel naar keuze uit het zwarte depot te nemen. De tegel legt hij (zoals gebruikelijk) in zijn opslagplaats. Dit telt niet als een actie. 

Tegels met hun eigenschap:

Schip: 

1. Neem “alle” goederentegels van één goederenveld naar keuze en plaats ze in jouw magazijn. 
2. Verplaats jouw pion op het spelersvolgordespoor één veld naar rechts. 

Dieren:

Punten = Aantal dieren op de tegel + dezelfde soort dieren in de weide.
Burcht:

Voer onmiddellijk een extra actie uit naar keuze. Dobbelsteenwaarde mag de speler zelf bepalen.

Mijn:

De speler ontvangt 1 zilverling per mijn aan het einde van een etappe.

Gebouwen: 
Zie gebouwen.
Punten:

+ De speler krijgt punten als hij een kleurgebied afsluit (volledig bezet met tegels). Hij krijgt punten afhankelijk van de grootte van het gebied (van 1 tot 36 punten) en afhankelijk van welke etappe (van 10 tot 2 punten). 

+ De speler die als eerste het laatste veld van een kleur in zijn vorstendom bezet, krijgt de grote bonuskaart. Afhankelijk van het aantal spelers krijgt hij onmiddellijk punten. De speler die als tweede het laatste veld van een kleur in zijn vorstendom bezet, krijgt de kleine bonuskaart. Hij ontvangt ook onmiddellijk de punten afhankelijk van het aantal spelers. 

+ Iedere speler ontvangt op het einde van het spel nog punten voor: iedere niet verkochte goederentegel = 1punt; iedere zilverling = 1 punt; per 2 arbeiders = 1 punt en de eigenschap van gele tegels = x-aantal punten. 

Belangrijke regels:

+ Tegel van het speelbord nemen: Als de opslagplaats van de speler vol is dan moet hij één van de tegels die daar liggen, verwijderen. 

+ Spelersvolgordespoor: Verplaatst een speler zijn pion naar een bezet veld, dan plaatst hij zijn pion op de andere pion(en). 

+ Iedere speler kan maar 3 verschillende goederen in zijn magazijn bewaren. Dezelfde goederen worden op elkaar gelegd. Kan een speler niet alle goederentegels (activatie bij een schip) in zijn magazijn opslaan, dan neemt hij enkel de goederentegels die hij wel kan opslaan. 

+ Een speler kan per arbeidersfiche de dobbelsteenwaarde met 1 verhogen of verlagen. Je kan van 6 naar 1 gaan en omgekeerd. Er mogen meerdere fiches voor één dobbelsteen gebruikt worden.

RATING: 8
This is a provisional rating based on one play. I actually expect I might raise the rating if I played it more (I don't own it). I'm not a Feld groupie. I bought and played Roma and hated it, and have been a bit gun-shy about Feld ever since. At first glance, this has all the problems you would associate with his games: to say the theme is wafer thin is an insult to wafers, and it's really just multi-player solitaire. To add to these weaknesses, the production quality is a bit poor, with flimsy player boards and far too thin tiles with obscure symbols on them, requiring you to constantly consult the rule book. But the clever gameplay sinks its hooks into you and things move at a quick pace. I found myself engrossed in the decision-making. It's amazing to play a dice game where it doesn't feel just random. The dice rolls feel like opportunities, not constraints. Eager to try again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
From the first play to the gradual unfolding of depths of strategy and possibilities, this game has been nothing but great. 

Read the rulebook once, print out this excellent single-page summary, and you'll never have to pause to look anything up again. 

http://boardgamegeek.com/filepage/67400/the-castles-of-burgundy-essential-rules-and-tile

EDIT: When I wrote the above, I had played maybe a half-dozen designer board games. After going much deeper into the hobby and playing many, many games, my good opinion of CoB hasn't held up at all. The best I can say of it is that it is the most acceptable manifestation of the idea Feld now trots out every six months, albeit with a clever new pasted on mechanism.

In short, "Choose some cards, tiles or bits. Then wait to see if other matching cards, tiles, and bits come into play. If they do, you win." 

If Feld keeps this up long enough, 'pasted on mechanism' may become as much a part of game design parlance as 'pasted on theme'. 

The central idea is always the same: in the name of 'variability', only half, or less, of the components come into play in any session. The end of the game is always the equivalent of 'the flop' in Texas Hold'em, but only when the players are 'all in'. If there was some amount of game (in poker, the betting) left after the cards (tiles, cubes, bits) are revealed, it could be alright. But it's always just, "If I turn over an X I win. If it's a Y you do". 

Feld is capable of designing really innovative games like Notre Dame and The Speicherstadt. He just doesn't. I don't even look at his new games anymore.

(Other Feld games I've played that are cut from this cloth: Macao, Bora Bora, Trajan, Aquasphere, Amerigo, and especially the god-awful steaming turd Bruges.)

The downside is that in a 3- or 4-player game, there can be a lot of down time while you're waiting for the rest of the players to take their turn. RATING: 4
I'm not a big fan of Die Burgen von Burgund.  

There are a lot of abstract rules to learn, which means it does not stand out from among a whole slew of thinly themed Euro games.  The game seems to be balanced, and there are a lot of interesting decisions to make, but it does not have anything innovative going on, and the theme is very very thin.  For a game with this many rules (it is overwhelming to begin with), I have grown to expect something that is more thematic. 

I'm already not a big fan of Agricola because I get overwhelmed with options, but at least Agricola has a theme that I can follow.  Burgund has a overarching theme that makes sense (building an estate), but all of the actions and point structures are very abstract.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Players are medieval nobles developing their lands in Burgundy.  Mechanically simple game with a lot of pieces and options.  The game is played over 25 turns, each turn players roll two dice and "spend" them on actions.  Actions are either to draft a hex tile off a pool board, from a slot that matches a die result.  Or... they can use a previously drafted hex tile, and deploy it into their little land on a hex that matches a die result.  Alternatively they can ship goods ... that match a die result.  Finally, they can simply dump their dice and take any action ... a last resort move when there is nothing constructive to do.  Along the way, dozens of victory points are awarded for filling in areas, shipping goods, farming animals (nice tilt to Knizia's Africa there!), and acquiring end of game bonus tiles.  A very nice design that feels a little different, as usual for Feld, with absolutely no relationship of mechanics to theme at all, again as usual for Feld.  Tons of things to think about, but the rules don't get in the way of the process, usually a sign they've got it right.  Good stuff.

RATING: 10
Wow, what an awesome game.  Feld can go way overboard with putting too many mechanisms in a game, but he has shown nice restraint here.  I really like that your goals are clear, and the way the dice limit your choices.  However, if you are vigilant, you can set yourself up so that you can use nearly any numbers you roll.  I think the use of dice here is more successful than the attempt made with Macao.  The random tile draws add nice variability as well.

Are you afraid of a drone attack on any pieces that are actually visible on the game board?  Designers, please start selling your best designs to other companies that know how to treat a lady!

RATING: 8
Essentially, this is a tile-laying game where each player is building their own estate using their own dice to claim tiles from a central area.   The game consists of 25 turns, which is about 2-3 too many if most of the important work is finished prior, although this becomes less and less of an issue with experienced play.   The thematic integration is a little more lacking than other Feld games, but it's not a huge complaint.   There are some production issues - bad color choices/matching, thin and tiny Alea components - but these aren't game breakers either.   Turn order seems really important, much in the same way as Agricola - don't neglect it.   Works well as a "couples" game.   Like comfort food.

RATING: 8.5
This is a GREAT game, but the potential for analysis-paralysis depending on who you are playing it with on top of the somewhat finicky non-streamlined rule subtleties, keep it from being a PERFECT game.  

During your turn you always have good options available that can score you points, but its about finding the BEST option – that is where the challenge is.  This feeling of always moving forward during every turn is an attribute I always admire in games.  And therefore, depending on who you are playing with, with so many good options to choose from, you could have a situation where players take too long to make their decision.  

Additionally, even with somewhat experienced players, there is something of a steep learning curve here for new players to absorb the rules and game play.  For one thing, it’s a very unique game and I can’t really think of any game to compare it with; new players come into the game without any frame for reference as to how the game plays out.  

I’ve heard some complaints that the rolling of the dice creates too much luck for this kind of a strategy game.  However, I feel the dice just narrows your choices down to a more manageable level and, if you build up your engine properly, keeping worker tokens in stock completely mitigates that luck.  

Its not the most streamlined set of rules by today’s standards (and learning the iconography on your individual game-board is CRUCIAL!).  Two rules that ALWAYS seemed to be overlooked is that you can’t have two of the same type of building in one area, and you can’t make more than one purchase from the center of the board, per turn.  Numerous times.  Players had to try to try to back track their turns after making such mistakes and causing other players scramble to think if they also made such mistakes.  I’m not really sure of the reason for these rules other than to make unnecessary hurdles in the game to more it more complex (I don’t see this as a balancing or run-away-leader-stopping mechanic).  There are also other little rules here and there that make the game a little finicky.  I’ve played this a few times, and in every game, were aren’t entirely sure if the final score was totally accurate.  

Oh!, and then there are the colors: it might look pretty artistically, but having three different shades of green and very muted yellows and browns for all the types of tiles was not a good idea.  I’m not sure how anyone with even the slightest color-blindness could play this this game.  You need VERY good lighting to play this game.  

Still, after a few plays, I can say I enjoy this game and would like to play it more, I’m just hesitant to throw it on the table for the reasons discussed.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Took me forever to get a game of this in, well after the initial buzz had faded.  I can see why people were excited about it, though.  
The dice put a lot of constraints on what you can do, but you always have workers to modify them, so you can usually get what you want if you're willing to pay for it.  There are also a lot of rolls in a round if you're willing to wait.  'Course, the good stuff may be gone by then, and getting mine production set up early is kind of important.  I love the fact that there are so many different boards, just with the base game, so you always have options on where to start and what types of tiles to focus on.  
I'm not going to disagree with some of my friends who deem the game 'point salad'.  You really are rewarded for just about everything, so it can be hard to tell what to do first.  Even the games I've won, I couldn't tell you how.
Still, it's a solid midweight euro, and one I'll probably play for a while.

RATING: N/A
EXCELLENT (I mean it) catch up mechanic. Saw 2 games where the last player suddenly got on a bullet train and gained massive points during gameplay (I was the person who's leading, hence I remember this incident) and became the leader/2nd player in three quarter of the game. So, when you see a person's on the last spot, doesn't mean that he can't be the first. 

I'm familiar with Stephen Feld's design (just by a few games) and usually his design includes a disaster, huge VPs deduction or catastrophe (1. In Speicherstadt, there's fire 2. In In the Year of Dragon, there is drought etc 3. In Macao, there's crazy deduction of VPs 4. Notre Dame, there's rat/plague), but Burgundy feels different. There is no bad things happening and IMO is rather unusual for his famous signature.

The game IS prone to AP. Although you can roll you dice (you're asked to roll dice simultaneously anyway by the rulebook) and plan ahead while other players are taking their actions. Problem is things can't go according to plan when the turn finally comes to you (because players before you might grab stuff that you want).

This has become one of my favorite game from Feld's designs. It's a good two player game and scales very well with 3 and 4 too.

RATING: 7.77
Mechanically outstanding game, but little dry for the eye. I played only 4 player games so far and only with basic player tiles, and it never finished the same way. There are always a bunch of strategies to follow while you are expanding your estate. Combos that you achieve when laying buildings are extremely important and careful planning can decide the winner in the end.

Also, this game is a perfect example how dice mechanics can be extremely elegant solution. Dice are only guiding you by limiting your options, but it doesn't have to be terminal because you can change the result on the die in many different ways. Beautiful. Lack of flavour and player interaction keeps it down from 9.

RATING: 6.5
A game that is entirely about mechanics - to be honest, I had no idea what we were actually accomplishing, thematically.  This is pretty common with Feld's games.

However, this one is a lot more enjoyable as the random draw of tiles and the common board keep it replayable, preventing an "optimum strategy" with a variable turn order and people inevitably grabbing the stuff you want.

Still, while it won't enter my own collection, if someone brings it to the table, I'm more than happy to sit down and play.

EDIT: After a few more plays, I've had to lower my score.  While the overall impression is still the same, I find that the only reason to have other people at the table is simply so they can bung up your plans.  While I won't say no to a game, on principle, I simply can't rate it as high as it previously was if only because there's little social aspect to the game, and I love this hobby for that specific reason.

RATING: 6
Upon reading the rules to Castles of Burgundy I was immediately impressed by all of the interlocking systems of scoring.  I also liked that you wouldn't see every tile in a given game as this tends to increase replayability.  In fact, I was even thinking that this game could be potentially better than Troyes, due to the fact that there is a spacial element in the game and the fact that rolling high really isn't better than rolling low, it's just a matter of what number you need.  In Troyes, you generally want to roll a high number of pips to allow a card to be activated more times.  Low rolls can still be useful (Cathedral + Building Placement) but high rolls are generally better.  Well, after my first game of Burgundy, I can confidently say that I don't find it as enjoyable as Troyes. I felt more screwed by the dice in this game than Troyes as you'll typically want a specific number and you might not be able to mitigate the luck of the die.

The game is easy, for 25 rounds (broken up into 5 phases), you'll roll two dice and use those dice to do 2 actions of the following actions: (1) Add tiles from the main board to a 3-space docking station, (2) Place tiles from your docking station to your board, (3) Sell a good for VP and money, (4) Gain workers which mitigate the luck of the dice.  You have many different tiles that do different things when added to your board from the docking area: (1) Ships: Increase in Turn Order + Gain Goods, (2) Mines: Gives you money, (3) Castles: Allows you to do an extra action with a virtual die of any result, (4) Buildings: One-Shot benefits of varying types, (5) Knowledge: End of Game VP scoring and persistent special abilities, (6) Pastures: Points which increase the more you specialize in a single animal type.  Though diversifying your animals is useful through knowledge tiles.

Overall, I enjoyed the first half of the game, but felt it kind of dragged in the latter half.  The only real problem I had with the game is that if felt too long.  Our 3-player game only ended up being about 2-ish hours which I'm told was pretty good pacing.  It felt longer than 2 hours to me.  While I can see how the game tries to increase replay value (ie not seeing all the tiles, different board layouts, acquiring different knowledge tiles each game) it seems like the game will eventually feel repetitive.  Maybe repetitive is the wrong word.  Maybe lacking in a narrative arc.  In Troyes, games can feel vastly different due to the events and activity cards... you can have low money games, low influence games, games where you have to combat a lot of dice.  The plays just feel a lot more unique.  I think in Burgundy, you'll do some different things each game, but it will mostly just feel like you're doing them in different order.  I also wasn't fond of how you just seem to get points for doing anything which ends up having scores above 200 but still relatively close among all players.  It's good in that, you can't 100% tell who is in the lead but it also makes you wonder how you could have improved your game.  I think it's pretty good but Troyes is still the definitive dice-rolling Euro. Also, I now feel this game has been replaced by Grand Austria Hotel.

Edit: I only play this as a 2-player game. Other minor issues have surfaced for me. [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/976448/it-just-me-or-does-no-one-really-bother-animal-til/page/1]Animals seem like a weak option with 2[/url] so I usually play with 1 animal type/player. [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/983959/stats-avg-points-win-etc-player-board-based-few-10]Board 8 is also widely known to be the best board, it's useful to give newbies on their first play though.[/url]

RATING: 8
I get so much satisfaction at the end of the game when I look at my kingdom that I have created on my player board! This is a great two-player game and scales well with three and four players. Because there are SO MANY icons on the board, it can seem a little overwhelming at first, but they all make sense so once you learn them the game goes quickly. I really enjoy the diversity that the game provides through rolling dice, taking actions based on the rolls, and stacking actions together with the buildings you place on your player board. Don't like dice? Think dice hate you? I've heard a number of people with those same thoughts say that they like this game and that the dice rolling aspect is an interesting action mechanic.

RATING: 8
The Castles of Burgandy takes the recent trend of dice driving your decisions to an extreme. Although you have a limit of choices, Castles of Burgandy still offers an incredible amount of choices. Personally, I found the choices even more numerous and complicated than say Agricola or Troyes. 

The amount of choices comes with a price though. The result is that the game is one of small increments. You will rarely have a choice that really changes the entire scope of the game. If you are like me, and enjoy games of nickels and dimes, games of small increments, this is a goodie. 

My favorite element of the design of dBvB is the value of the dice roll - a six is no more valuable than a one. 

Also the board and tableaus are ugly, real ugly. They are pretty functional though.

The game gets a lot more interesting when you start using the different boards.

RATING: 9
[b]Rating based on - 100+ plays, 2 player, 3 player[/b]
A highly addictive and satisfying dice assigning tile placement game where you can make combo chains eg. place a city hall to place a mine which lets you grab a castle, then place the castle to place a carpenter's and grab another building from the market...WHEW! If you can get all that to work the game is incredibly fun. You can use your dice and some special tiles to allow you to modify your dice rolls so you are not so much luck dependent on the dice. I've played 2 and 3 player and I like it best at 2 where you have more control over the turn order (and therefore the market) to a certain extent. A really great game that deserves its high ranking status.

RATING: 9.3
A classic. This is a go-to game when we don't feel like a long setup and want a relatively quick but also deep game. Dice games are where its at and this game uses them beautifully. Players get two dice which they use to place on the board in various locations. Dice can be manipulated by worker tokens which is a nice twist to the game. Because of the scarce token types and limited availability on the board, the game can get very passive aggressive and tense. There luck in the dice rolls and token availability creates some nice drama too.

RATING: N/A
Too long? One comment I found: "The box optimistically says 60-90 minutes; expect your first game of 4 to go about 120-150 minutes."

Like Macao it has dice but is simpler.  Mostly multi-player solitaire.  Recommended with 2 or 3 players, less so with 4 (otherwise too much down time and too long a game), some still consider it too long. RATING: 6
This is one of those euros that I liked for a few plays but then suddenly my interest dried up. I think that’s simply the case for some euros, especially Feld designs. They’re fun for a while but don’t hold interest beyond a handful of plays. I can’t help but compare this to Troyes which is a game I still enjoy after a dozen plays. 

Unlike the forced dice selling in Troyes, there's little to no element of anticipating other player's moves which turns it into a solo optimization puzzle and removes a lot of the tension. You might take tiles away from each other in the market but for the most part, you do your own thing without intentionally affecting other players. And you do your own thing over and over without a feeling of an arc. After a while you total up the points and find you’re all within 10 points of each other.
