RATING: 4
My favorite pure euro: a ton of variable challenge, best 2p.
Popular with my tweener nephews and casual gamers.

Rating history: 8|8|8|8|8|8|8|8|8|9....6|4

Played 7 times.
2p - 5 - excellent short 2p game
3p - 2 - not better than 2p, just longer

Nov 2016: The systems are clever, but the game is quite abstract. The shipping feels tacked on to boot. But my real objection is elsewhere. This game is one more euro-with-a-brown-and-green-palette. Middle-ages Europe. White people building things. So many games are now coming out that offer us something different setting-wise, as well as vibrant art, and clear iconography. Setting matters to me to a point, but visual design is a big part of my enjoyment of games, and this game lacks it. That drab, muddled presentation on top of a very gamey Feldian game - no matter how clever - just leaves me cold these days. Clever, but ultimately not that fun after the initial joy of playing with a clever system. 

July 2014: For years I've seen photos of this game and thought "Meh." But that ranking is so high...? So I finally borrowed a copy and sat down to play. Finally a Feld I really love. Don't get me wrong, this game is PURE euro all the way - abstract point-salad from start to finish - but it plays in THIRTY MINUTES with 2p. THIRTY. And in that thirty minutes you are acquiring and selling goods, acquiring and laying tiles, acquiring with bonuses in mind, prioritizing and re-prioritizing with every acquisition your opponent makes... Whew! All of this in THIRTY minutes. And THAT is (in my opinion) why this game is so good. NO game offers this much gameplay in such a short amount of time.

Well done, Herr Feld. Well done.

5th play: 8. SEP/14. Just as fun as I remembered from a few months ago. Glad I purchased it.

10th play: 9. SEP/14. Seems to float between 8 and 9 depending on my mood for euros. Still challenging with every play.

This game fires:
...Attika, as a 2p tile-laying/expand-territory game
...Ticket to Ride as a short light-middleweight

RATING: 4
Bad color choice: 4 shades of green, one of which is actually yellow.

RATING: 4.5
[floatright][size=5]2013-07-11[/size][/floatright]
Unfortunately, for me this game is deeply unsatisfying.

Certainly the game is rather clever: even though what you can do depends on the dice you roll, you have the ability to change your dice's values; whatever crap you roll, you can still do something that feels like an achievement (the fact that doing anything scores you points helps too). This is probably one of the reasons this game is often praised.

But to me it feels too scripted. Being able to easily influence your dice means both making luck less important and being able to push most games into the same path. This can be good with games where you have an overwhelming number of choices (like Go, Race for the Galaxy, Napoleon's Triumph), but here I feel like my choices aren't interesting and varied enough.

[floatright][size=5]2015-10-01[/size][/floatright]
sgosaric explained it much better: https://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/188288/item/3781054#item3781054
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
with BGG extra boards - x
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Rules Complexity: :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar:
Strategic Depth: :star::star::star::halfstar::nostar:
Luck Factor :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Negotiation Factor: :nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Amount of Downtime: :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar:
Fiddliness: :star::star::star::nostar::nostar:
Replayability: :star::star::star::star::star:
Component Quality: :star::star::star::nostar::nostar:
Player Interaction: :star::halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar:
"Take That" Conflict: :halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Theme Integration: :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar:

The ultimate "use your dice to select actions" game IMHO. An amazing puzzle-like experience that plays best with 2 or 3 and may be my favorite game to play alone with the spouse. It's like a game of basketball in that it's high scoring and scores will typically be pretty close, which may be a turn-off for some. Cons: Setup and take-down time is steep and the insert could have used more small compartments. Player interaction is on the low side, but there's so much to think about that I mind even less than usual.  Pros: Plays in about 30-minutes per player, and gives the perfect blend of dice constraining one's choices while still offering many tactical and even strategic decisions.  The basic rules are very simple with the rules complexity coming from the abilities and uses of the many various tile types.  It feels like a race and you'll never get everything done that you want to in the time that you have. If you like strategic, puzzle-like games with a small dose of dice luck and you don't mind games with only indirect player interaction, I highly recommend it!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
I'm in love with Stefan Feld's designs, because they are elegant instead of fiddly. This one is my present favourite Feld board-game (I also have Roma and In the year of the dragon). The inteligent use of dice makes this game one to be put on a "category" we could name: "Dice that aren't dice", where I would also includ Troyes and Roma.
There's a lot of paths to victory in this game, and the desitions to be made are too many and so variable! Nevertheless, the game mechanics are so pure, simple, brilliant and elegant that you'll never feel numb or lost... or confused.
The playing time is another succes of Castles of Burgundy, 'cause it can be played in the half (or less than the half) of the time required to play other "Great Euro-Titles" such as Puerto Rico and Agricola.
The one and only issue I have with this game is the quality of its components: the player boards are very thin, as all the cardboard pieces. They should have made this piece of art with the quality it deserves, but they haven't. Well, at least its price is not expensive at all, and corresponds perfectly to what comes inside the box.
I give this one, at least for now, a complete 10.
---

Edited: I still like this a lot but my current favorite Feld is Trajan, so, Burgundy goes down from 10 to 8.5 to me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Die Burgen von Burgund is another game that jumps on the 'dice are nice' bandwagon. Here, they are only used to restrict the action choices available to the players. There is nothing particularly new or innovative about that, and the impact of the dice is reduced even further because there are ways to modify the results. In short, you might say that the description of BvB as a dice game is somewhat misleading.

What remains is a fairly generic point conversion game with a light engine-building aspect. You grab tiles from a common pool, then place them on your own board to gain improvements for future actions, trigger special actions, or score points. While there are a few strategic considerations most of the game is very tactical in nature because even more than on the dice results you depend on the right tiles coming up (and nobody else snagging them up before you do).

I can understand those who say it's repetitive to some extent; the variance in possible actions is fairly small, and their nature or impact doesn't change too much from the first to the last round. Nevertheless the tactical considerations are usually interesting enough, and a little advance planning can keep things open enough that you rarely get stuck with results that aren't useful at all.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
CoB is supposed to be a strategic game. You make strategic choices. However, if each player would be allowed to make any choice that he wants, the game would not be interesting at all since it is relatively painless to identify the best choices. Therefore, designer Feld introduced dice: you can only make the choices that you want if you manage to roll the numbers of those choices. Translated: CoB is a game where the strategies are so straightforward that it needs randomness in choices to gain interest. When I say that, people tell me that you can compensate for the randomness by buying workers, but that makes it even worse: the designer KNOWS that his design is too random to be of interest, so he introduces a mechanism that allows a player to compensate for the stupid design and make it less random! Sorry, I rather play a game in which the strategies of players are pitted against each other rather than against rolling dice.

RATING: 8
This is an excellent game. Excellent! It's dice driven all the way, but what makes it unique is the way the dice are used to do things in the game. Using worker chits (earned by spending dice) can change the outcome of the dice. So can certain knowledge tiles. You get to build your own little kingdoms on your own play mat with tiles you can buy with your dice. Victory points are earned by filling up regions, selling goods, or earning silverlings. silverlings can be used to purchase special tiles from a central bank. The game plays in 5 phases with 5 rounds each. It takes a while to play, but every round in a phase is a lot of decisions and routes to victory. You might think you're going to lose, and then suddenly you're in the lead.

I like that there are variant maps. I'll have to try the solitaire version, because I think it will be better with fewer players.

RATING: 7.5
Very fiddly.  Avoid if you require theme--there's just a whiff of it here.  This is a bit like worker placement with dice--instead of just looking at everything available at the beginning of the phase and deciding what you would choose first, second, third--take what you like from what was left when you actually got to pick--this game adds two dice which limit which things you really have access to on your turn.  To compensate for this, the game gives liberal die mods so you can typically achieve your second or at worst third choice when the heartless bastard ahead of you takes the tile you wanted most.

RATING: 6.5
I don't get why this is such a big deal, for me it's JASE, but exceptionally ugly. I like the speed of play and I like the simple rules, but I don't like the dice and I don't feel particularly accomplished once I've filled in an area. When I don't roll what I need I feel frustrated and when I roll what I need I feel lucky instead of accomplished. I never feel like I fought hard to fill in an area, I just feel like the dice just happened to allow it. My big issue is that even though there's plenty of dice manipulation and strategic planning that goes into every placed tile, I can't bring myself to see that when a plan finally comes together, which makes the game extremely unrewarding. I think it's because you only have 2 dice each turn, the game would play roughly the same if you had 4 dice every turn and there were half as many turns, but I think it would feel better in my head. An "optimal" turn in this game would be to pick up a tile and place it with your 2 dice, but just placing 1 tile on your turn doesn't feel good to me.

RATING: 5
Played this for the first time today.  It's like a nice mix of Glen More, Carcassonne, and Troyes.  We made a few mistakes, but nothing major.  All in all a very pleasant first experience, considering that most first experiences in learning a new game are miserable.  This game's already fun, and my wife says: "See, it's not that Troyes lacks theme.  This game doesn't have a really great theme, but I still had fun...so the problem with Troyes is something else.  I'd play this any day over Troyes."  She beat me twice the first day we played.  :)

UPDATE:  we rushed through a game and it sorta revealed the dryness to me.  I wouldn't recommend rushing. It feels very solitaire and robotic and mathematical that way.  We've played it a couple times since then but I'm starting to think Feld is too dry for my tastes. (this is my first Feld game).

UPDATE: we played a few more games and overall it felt like I was just going through the motions.  "Everything is made up and the points don't matter" kept coming to mind.  The point salad and that the game is designed to be so tight in scoring kinda make it feel like my actions are worthless, as if I'm playing a very elaborate version of a roll and move game.  We fell out of love with this one rather quickly and I've put it up for sale/trade.

UPDATE:  It's been awhile.  It didn't sell, so I decided to keep it.  It sits in a nice sweet spot for duration/weight that we've been looking for.  It's still ugly as sin and dryer than other Euros we have, but it works for what it is.

UPDATE: we gave this game a few more chances, but for the amount of time it takes to play, it's just not exciting, and the point salad isn't our cup of tea.  I never get the feeling that I can think of anything I could have done better to score more points.  It just ends up feeling lucky, dry, uneventful, and mediocre compared to the quality of entertainment I get out of other games I have.  It's up for trade or sale or to whoever wants it.

RATING: 10
Pure masterpiece. Unique mechanics and many choices makes The Castles of Burgundy perfect strategy board game. Despite strategical depth, this game is light enough and plays in 1-2 hours, sometimes even less than hour and offers much fun in that short period of time. Components and theme is not the strongest side of this game, however the game play is so fun, that this proves again, that idea, mechanics and game design makes the game, not the theme, story or art. Those are just minor things and this game could even have zero theme, it would be fun anyway.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Components: ok, could be better, but they could also be worse
Complex: easy to teach and start playing inmediately
Weight: medium to light
Players: works well with 2 to 4, will say 4 as all tiles are in play
Length: no more than 90 mins with 4 players
Mechanics: dice rolling, tile placing, set collection...
Decisions: quite a lot, you roll dice for your actions but have to adapt yourself to everything
Opinion: one of my favorite medium to light games, and one that works well with 2 to 4 players, would say that 4 is the best number, but only because all tiles are in play.
Here you have to build your kingdom with 6 different types of tiles, and in order to do so you roll 2 dice each turn and do actions according to them. One important thing, the dice can be modified with workers, and some tiles offer you bonuses to the dice as well, therefore we could say there is luck, but you cannot loose due to lack of luck.
And depending on the tiles you will get different bonuses (buildings with special actions, yellows with special abilities, green with animals, ....) and you get points for sooo many things (hello Point salad), but the game plays so smoothly and fast that it's a joy.
In a nutshell, this is a game that come to the table quite often due to the simplicity and the length of the games, but you will enjoy each play, each decision and each final score

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The game flow of The Castles of Burgundy is simpler, smoother, and more cohesive than Stefan Feld's other games published by alea. The dice-as-actions system here is excellent. There are sufficient options that you're not at the mercy of the dice, but not so many that you won't be frustrated by what you roll. Players need to make their own luck by preparing for as many scenarios as possible. Smart players will not have as many "bad" rolls because they will have positioned themselves so that fewer rolls would be considered "bad."

I strongly prefer to play TCoB as a two-player game. You get exactly the same experience as the four-player game in a much faster and more exciting format.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Good strategy game for 2 to 4 player.  The game is pretty simple and even if it uses dice, it's not only luck driven.  On your turn, you roll 2 dice and must do 1 action with each of them.
The 4 available action are :
- Take a tile from the main board to your player board
- Add a tile from your board to your estate
- Sale goods
- Draw 2 worker tile
The result on the dice limit your choices but there his rarely only bad actions available.
If you really need a specific number on a dice, you can always spend worker to modify a dice result.
The game end after 25 turn, the player with the most victory point wins.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Usually I don't like comments like "too long for what it is". This is just kind way avoiding to say "I got bored after an hour". After one 4 player game I tend to say "too long for what it is" but not for the reasons of being bored. The point is: you play 5 phases with 5 rounds each with 2 actions (2 dice). This means you play at least 50 turns/actions. With bonusactions (Buildings/Castle) you have even more actions that enables you to fill up your board to 95% !  No matter how good or bad you play you fill up more than 90% of your board and getting therefore more 90% of the possible victory points (around 200 points). Only some timing issues will decide which players wins (if all players are of equal skill). 
I would prefer a shorter game not only resulting in less play time but also the fact you have to prioritise what to build because you end up only with 70% of your board filled up with tiles. This would need more strategy or tactic skills and results in a tighter fight on tiles.
Typical for Alea: small tiles and not 100% color matching.

RATING: 5
Stephan Feld's rules are breathtakingly cool. But sometimes the games themselves become fiddly to the point of breaking. At those times, the sheer sensual--and especially tactile--fun of handling a game can overcome the tedium of setting it up. Not in this case. The Castles of Burgundy gives no pleasure visually, and the thin, cheap components are not fun to handle...and they must be handled continually. The set up is oppressively long.

I will play this, as long as someone else handles the coal shoveling.

----
Returning to the game, I find it's a blast to play two player. Little colored bags help with set-up woes--in fact, this is the game that taught me that proper set-up of the game in-box is a small, but key, factor of enjoyment out-of-box.

---

Sold. As with many Feld designs, it is "interesting," at the border of being fun, and monomaniacally contemptuous of the underrated sensual aspect of playing games. Such ugliness comes down to a contempt of playing with other people, in a shared space. It's an aspect I can no longer overlook when considering game purchases.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The Castles of Burgundy is a dice-as-action driven tile placement game. This game is tremendously fluid. Roll dice and use those rolls to take actions. Either draft a tile or place a tile. Stephan Feld demonstrates some great design here. The game feels light and breezy, but also has a pleasing depth to complexity ratio. When collecting tiles, the buildings tend to be a favorite of mine as they all tie in nicely to whichever strategy you choose for a particular game. It scales very well and gives plenty of positive of feedback to each action through seeing satisfying growth in your kingdom and point rewards at every turn. The art is an easy criticism, but it evokes a certain style of euro from the last generation that I very much enjoy.

RATING: 9
Excellent game by Stefan Feld; (for my opinion actually his best game ).  :thumbsup:

Burgen von Burgund is a fine mixture of dice rolling, worker placement, and tile laying.  I especially like the way how placing tiles trigger free actions which can trigger chain reaction of additional free actions.  This creates really positive and rewarding gaming experience.  Another thing I like is the way, dice are manipulated.  Players roll dice and can use worker tiles to modify dice values by +1 or -1.  One fine details here is, that a '6' can be turned into a '1' by "adding" +1 (and vice versa).  This greatly increases the players' felxibility and makes unfavorable dice rolls much less probable.

Burgen von Burgund works with any number of players but is best with two players because of the reduced playing time (~45 minutes), almost nonexistent downtime and more tactical gameplay.

My rating of '9' applies to the two player ganme.  With 4 players I'd rate it 7.5.

RATING: 8.5
„Ez egyszer mind a tiéd lesz fiam…”
A játék már nem mai „gyerek”, de én csak a többszöri pozitív beszámolókat, kritikákat követően vettem rá magam, hogy kipróbáljam (erre jó a játék online verziója).
Földbirtokosként célom a rendelkezésre álló uradalmam felvirágoztatása. A játékban a választható akciók fontosabb részéhez szükséges alapot kockadobások jelentik (és igen itt lakozik némi szerencse is a játékban). Általánosságban elmondható, hogy mindig tudsz valami jó akciót végrehajtani (nem részletezném őket), de a trükk az, hogy a legjobbat válaszd a lehetőségeidhez képest előre tervezve a területed beépítését. A játék javára írom, hogy nem kell a többiekkel „törődnöd”, hanem a saját magad vágyait követve építgetheted birodalmadat (ezt nagyon szeretem a 7 Csoda társasban is). Természetesen a győzelemhez nem árt játékostársaid lépéseit is figyelned és az akcióidat azzal összekötni, hogy esetlegesen csökkented az ő akcióik hatékonyságát (legjobb példa, amikor egy-egy olyan lapkát veszel el, amire éppen szüksége lenne, főleg, ha ezt tudod kombinálni azzal, hogy te kezdesz az adott körben). Mivel a játékban az akcióidból élsz, azon lehetőségek, amelyekkel plusz akciókhoz jutsz, vagy más akciók által biztosított hatásokat bónuszként szerzel meg, értékesek. Van még egy-két taktikai lépés, amelyet érdemes követni, de alapvetően mindenki pasziánszszerűen építkezik és a végén vagy összejön minden, vagy nem. Így szívesen ajánlom a játékot a kezdő társasjátékosok számára is.
Összességében megtetszett, szívesen játszom vele.

RATING: 8
I'm a big fan of Feld's designs, and this one is a lot of fun. I love Luna, but I always opt for this one to hit the table. It is basically a deckbuilder with tiles, and you gain VP if you build a series of mini-engines and chain-reactions.

Lots of information to take in when learning the rules and it seems overwhelming when you are covering them, but once the game starts you see how elegant and simple the gameplay is, and also how easy it is to decipher the board, the multitude of tiles and powers, and the strategies. RATING: 6
There are three main things I have against this game:
- lots of dice rolls which can make or break your game (the randomness is only partially mitigated by the workers that you can collect)
- the winning score is in the 200-point range (I prefer games with a top score of under 100, so that the game doesn't turn into a runaway)
- so many decisions make my turns very long!

My first play of this was a 4-player game, and it took over 3 hours!  There are so many decisions to make, and you have to wait for the previous player's turn to finish before you even roll the dice, so absolutely no analysis can be done in parallel.


Also, unlike other Stefan Feld games, the iconography is not easy to understand.  In particular, the beige tiles have a picture of a building which you have to decode each time, using the table on the player mat.  Why not have the symbols for the action on the tile rather than a meaningless picture?  Bad design, if you ask me!

I'd prefer Macao... the dice there affect everybody equally, and people can take their turns almost simultaneously.  And of course, I like Notre Dame and In the Year of the Dragon better too.

RATING: 8
I was afraid to get a game which sounded too much like others in my collection, but this is not the case.
There is dice rolling, there is a spatial element and there is a quite terrible fight - indeed the only interaction is mediated by grabbing things first, but if you play in your little corner without paying attention, you'll get horribly trashed.
Maybe it's groupthink, I've read many comments about playing without interaction; well those playing the "kind" way are missing a superbly balanced piece of nasty.
You can feel how much design genius has gone into the numerous options the game offers; while the game engine is deceptively simple, there is a staggering amount of choices, all have been wonderfully crafted by Mr Feld; moreover, the different player boards and varying starting position offer and impressive array of strategies to consider; the dice impose shifting tactics: I can't imagine getting tired of this game anytime soon.
The only let-down is the poor color set; the yellow is greenish on the tiles (and looks like the light green), while the beige and grey are barely distinguishable.  Too bad as the iconography is nice and the whole is pleasing.
Do not mix passive and agressive players, and avoid AP prone people at all costs. Or limit the number of player to 2 or 3.

RATING: 8
Another one of those games with lots of weird iconography that is a big hindrance to learning. I feel like I'm bringing this up with every new game I play lately, but it's true. Lots of ways to score and lots of options to consider. Looking forward to playing this one again. I'll give this a solid 7 for now, but this may go higher with more familiarity. I think this one has some good meat on it that's worth savoring.

RATING: 7.5
The Castles of Burgundy is a Stefan Feld dice-driven tile-laying game, and in many ways a multi-player solo game. So what is there (besides the designer's name) in this one that makes it a top 100 game?

Well, first off, it plays well for 2-4, and offers a variable challenge based on both random tile distribution, play order and funds available at any given time.  Strategies can vary greatly in value based on tile availibility and what player's can acquire, when.

All of this makes for a consistently entertaining tile-laying game, and when the additional boards are added in it seems quite certain no 2 games will be quite alike.

That, with the ability to control income and the dice somewhat means that while there is plenty of random variation, there are also a large number of real decisions to make at any given play, but not so many that AP has to set in.

Definitely a keeper, this one took a couple of plays to grow on me, but after 6 plays I rate it a strong 7.5.

This is a nice, scalable game, not too interactive, but very playable in lots of circumstances, and one of Stefan Feld's more public friendly games in general.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
(06/2012) For some inexplicable reason, I was beginning to dislike Stefan Feld's game designs--maybe it was my "meh" experience with Luna--but this was surprisingly fun, accessible, and engaging, along the lines of Lords of Waterdeep.

While I usually dislike dice-allocation games (Kingsburg comes to mind), this was a pleasant exercise in puzzle-solving to each of my dice rolls. While the game board was initially daunting, with all the spaces and numbers and stacks and whatnot, I quickly "got it". Everything on the main board and player tableaus have die faces of varying number of pips. The 2D6 die rolls represent what opportunities open up. While this may seem completely random and chaotic, picking up and laying down specific kingdom tiles to gain specific capabilities is key in maximizing the benefits of those randomly generated pips.

There is very little downtime, and game play is relatively quick. It is difficult to anticipate future plays, as most attention is focused on "what can I do with the die rolls I just made?" Since the board is seeded with both fixed and random elements, it is about leveraging what little resources one has on maximizing the limited set of actions. The fun and satisfaction comes from "discovering" building/action combos, much like in Dominion, out of the seemingly chaotic distribution of tokens.

There are a number of intriguing game mechanisms that mesh together well, seamlessly, that makes this game unlike any other game out there today. I look forward to more plays. It is a solid '8'.

Update (02/16/2014) 6 plays: After pondering about this in my subconscious for several months, won my first game. The game is all about focusing and identifying the most resourceful combinations, for any given dice roll. There is also the element of planning ahead, for potential combinations down the road. This, and other Feld designs have been derided as "point salads", but I am beginning to see them for what they are. They're not bad, as far as games go. But great? No.

RATING: 9.2
I think that Castles of Burgundy is a gem of a game. It is very easy, conceptually, but has a depth of strategy which some other titles lack. The game is a nice mix of luck and strategy. You roll dice to determine your draw each round, but are allowed to use workers to increase or decrease the value of the die, assuming you have a worker available. In this way the game also mixes in an element of worker management and strategy to compensate for the random luck of the die rolls. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.9
You roll dice which let you pick up tiles, place tiles, or ship goods for points. There are tokens that let you fudge the dice. There is a puzzle element on where you can place your tiles: everything must be touching, and the color of what you're placing must match the background and number on your board. There is a ton of downtime with 4 players, as you can't do anything until everyone has selected, and sometimes you won't know what's left until it is your turn. This game is fine, but doesn't justify 90+ minutes.

HOWEVER I can image how playtime would be much quicker playing two-player. I would love to try a game that way and could imagine my rating of the game improving after.

RATING: 7

For an optimisation exercise, though, it is fun and interesting, but without much significant variation between games. Also plays nice and quickly: we can crank out a 2-player game in 45 minutes or so.

RATING: 9.6
Stefan Feld es un diseñador que suele cortapegar mecánicas de otros juegos y logra diseños secos y sin alma... pero es un tío listo y lo hace bien. En este caso se suma a la tendencia (¿actual?) de usar dados. Mecánicamente es un juego que consiste en colocar losetas en lugares, ambos determinados por dados... pero no está restringido a usar exclusivamente la puntuación obtenida en la tirada para poder hacer algo productivo. Hay que buscar combos y eficiencia en las acciones y además, sacar un 6 no es mejor que sacar un 1..  PROS: Muchas opciones dónde elegir (más que Agricola o Troyes). Muy rejugable (9 tableros distintos) CONS: Curva de aprendizaje inclinada porque cuanto mejor conozcas las losetas y sus efectos, mejor jugarás (y hay muchas). Componentes por debajo de la calidad de Alea. Que Dios te ayude si eres daltónico. El juego termina "tarde" (casi todo el mundo ha completado sus opciones)

[ENG]

Stefan Feld is a boardgame designer who copies mechanics from another games and does dry and souless new designs... but is a clever buddy and he does it pretty well. In this case he follows the mainstream tendency based on using dice. The main mechanism is tile placement on the board and this process is determinated by dice... but isn´t restricted just only by dice results. You should look for "combos" and eficiency in your actions, and to obtain a 6 with dice is not better than obtain a 1. PROs: lots of options (much more than in Agricola o Troyes). Replayable becouse of nine different boards. CONS: difficult learning curve becouse of the different tiles (there are a lot). Game components below the average. God bless you if you´re colourblind. The game ends late (usually when everybody have finished all his options).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The only thing I don't like about Castles of Burgandy is the production value of the components and art, which seem to fall well below average relative to all the other games I play in both the main playing board and the tiles.  Otherwise, I love this game!  Players roll dice that will dictate their choices of actions in a given turn.  There is a great mechanic that causes you to not get screwed by undesirable dice rolls, worker tiles that you can spend to modify the dice.  So if you need a 2 and you roll a 3, you can spend one worker tile to do the action corresponding to 2.  I like that there is no player elimination and there are multiple legitimate paths to victory.  This is a deep game and it has very strong replay value.   
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.6
Castles of Burgundy is a  well-designed strategic tile-laying game in which players acquire properties, sell goods, hire workers and earn silver to arrange their fiefdom in a manner that will result in the greatest number of victory points.  The mechanics of the game are very satisfying, with occasional "wow moments" when a single, well-timed action leads to subsequent high scoring actions.  

While there is luck in the game, the mechanics grant the player wide latitude to mitigate the luck by trading workers for changes in the dice result.  The game mechanic invites strategy by confronting the player with numerous options as he or she considers the composition of their fiefdom and tile placement timing within their fiefdom.  For instance, a player may choose to score  points early in the game by completing cities before their opponents, or set themselves up for long-term point generation by strategically placing tiles (i.e., university tiles) for potentially decisive points at the end of the game.  

While player interaction is essentially limited to denying an opponent access to a particular tile, the game incites enough competition among the players to be an enjoyable socially engaging experience.  

Each time I have played Castles of Burgundy, some aspect of the game has amazed me.  Castles of Burgundy has just the right balance of strategy, engagement, satisfaction and length to be a great choice for 2 players looking for an enjoyable light-medium weight game.

While this is a very good game, I prefer the more complex mechanisms of other games designed by Mr. Feld, i.e. Trajan and Bruges.

Rating: 5.6 (Fun 6; Gameplay 7; Components 3; Theme 5)
Formula:
[Weighted rating = (((Fun*4) + (Gameplay*3) + (Components *2) + (Theme *1))/10)]

RATING: 8
The process of rolling dice and working within the constraints of the results and the rules of the game has never been more fun than in The Castles of Burgundy.

Every turn is a new puzzle to find the combination of moves that will result in more points (or at least an opportunity for them).

While the game can have some periods of downtime (especially with new players), it doesn't ruin the game at all. And while it is playable with three or four players, it's actually at its best with two players - there is much less luck and randomness with fewer players.

I don't foresee removing this classic from my collection at any point in the future.

RATING: 6
You roll two dice each round and you get an action for each die depending on what you rolled for that die.  There are a number of options for each die roll and ways to expand those options and add different options.  The main focus is claiming pieces from a common game board and later playing them to your personal board.  I enjoyed playing it, but the options could overwhelm even the least of the AP-prone.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
While a completely different game from Feld's other design Macao it has a bit of feel from that design.  You've got dice used in a semi-unique way, ships, goods pick up and delivery, tiles (vs. building/person cards) that override the default rules if you've activated (built) them, a similar turn order mechanism, etc.

Also like Macao your first play or several plays can take a long time.  Each player has 25 turns total in the game with each turn consisting of 2 (or more when building certain tiles) actions.  I wonder if a variant to play only 20 turns would work?   Also even for those of us who were 1st time players, we all scored over 200 points (looping the score track twice).

Even though it was long, I do have to say it was fun.  Can't wait to try the "advanced" player boards/maps.

RATING: 8
What a sad, boring box this game has. A shame, really, because I like this one a lot. Basically you're trying to build up a city around a central castle, whether that be with buildings, pastures for animals, silver mining areas, rivers or other special yellow sections, perhaps you could term them industry? Mostly they just give you bonuses for your other sections. You have silver, workers, and goods to help you, as some of the game is based on the chance of dice rolling. You have to use your brain a lot in this one, as it requires a lot of forethought and planning based on what comes available in each round and your strategy to get the most points, which are earned in a variety of ways. I will say, this game could get slightly dry after a while, but there are different boards to choose from to mix things up.

RATING: 8
2012-04-26

Initial Rating: 7.0 (April 2012)

At first it seemed like a great game, but later some concerns began to appear.  The quality of the components is regular, but what really bugs me is the awful similar looking colors. I wish they could be really different from each other. I´m ok with long games, but this game is very long with the full complement of players and this leads to an annoyingly high down time so now I believe this is best enjoyed as a 3 player game. 

But my main concern is the massive swings in VPs, I feel there is little strategy as the best VP generators are clearly defined so it is mostly luck if you can get them or not. For example, if you don`t go for the huge VPs awarded for animal tiles you will lose and I don`t like that in the game as there is one path to victory. Perhaps if I played with a different state board I could appreciate some improvement in this area. For now I want to play again to review my feelings about the game to see if the rating goes up or down.

I still think Troyes is the best game out there with the dice allocation mechanic.

Current Rating: 7.0

2013-04-04

After some more plays, I’m still worried about the animal tiles. They are a must take as they offer a lot of points, if you get them early you have a high probability of winning. Also each player get only one kind of animal because if I attack other players taking the animals they already have on their estates, I also hurt myself, so (in most games) all players have only taken one kind of animal.

Still this is a good game and one I enjoy playing, perhaps my 3th favorite Feld (after Trajan, and In the Year of the Dragon). I will play with the expert boards next time to see if that lessen the “animal effect”.

RATING: 7
I didn't find it "soulless" as multiple of my geekbuddies have commented; I actually had a lot of fun building my little city. Processional maybe, and definitely longer than its weight warrants. I do think the use of dice isn't as much to my tastes as in Macao, to which this game will be compared. In Burgund the dice restrict how one can act on one's turn, a much looser restriction admittedly than in Settlers of Catan where one can find oneself waiting for a specific 2d6 result for many turns, but a similar feel. The only real planning one can do is to keep options open on all dice numbers - compare to Macao where one finds that one will have 5 red cubes 5 turns from now, and the object is to sync up other resources with those in future turns. I'm not done with Burgund yet but I'm not sure it's a standout for me.

RATING: 7
Stefan Feld makes games that have been affectionately called 'Victory Point Salads'. This game is like a salad itself. It may be a little bit difficult for people to differentiate the various shades and varieties of green+yellow (grellow?) that can be found on the boards.

Design decisions aside, The Castles of Burgundy is an excellent game with a somewhat poor theme. True to the spirit of Euro Games, The Castles of Burgundy is somewhat dry but has very solid, and very well-designed mechanics. 

If you do not mind playing a game for its gameplay alone, then the Castles of Burgundy is for you. Otherwise, The Crushers of Brogundy might be more a more suitable alternative.

RATING: N/A
[b][url=http://www.spieldesjahres.de/cms/front_content.php?idcat=8]2011 Spiel des Jahres Recommended[/url][/b]

The Castles of Burgundy is a detailed strategy game set in the Loire Valley of France during medieval times. Players assume the role of princes trying to build the greatest estates in the land by becoming more prosperous than their competitors. Over the course of five rounds, players collect points by trading, livestock farming, city building and scientific research. They must buy and sell goods or labor and use action tiles for building, shipping, mining, livestock and knowledge across two game boards.

Players: 2, 3, 4
Time: 30-90 min
Mechanics: [property=2072][/property], [property=2004][/property], [property=2002][/property]

RATING: 9
Territory building that determines the options based on dice rolls over a set number of turns. For each die, you can choose to buy from the options under that number… and place it in a number-specific place on your map (though there are modifiers you can get with a die too). No two games are the same, which is nice, and the boards vary once you decide to go past the base versions.

PLUS: easy to learn/teach, many variations, heavy involvement with what other players are doing
MINUS: when someone takes the lead they really take the lead

ESSENTIAL game for those who want something with a bit of strategy and a bit of luck -- a definite deserver of its top 100 placement on BGG and other lists

RATING: 8
Another innovative "dice" game from Feld. Castles is lighter than most of his games, but still creates lots of decision points. I can see why this is one of his most highly ranked titles as it is pretty darn accessible. The rules for his games are never complicated, but often the best decisions are rather opaque in initial play-throughs. With Castles, you can more easily see the path to points and generate an initial strategy. It's not my favorite Feld, but with some players I'll have more success getting this to the table than other titles I might personally prefer.

UDPATE 10/15 (upgraded from 7 to 8): The more I play this game, the more I like it...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
One of these new-fangled "euro-dice games". Overall I enjoyed it, it's right up there with Kingsburg among my favorite dice games. I give it a 7/10, with plenty of room for increase pending further explorations. 

And, there's a lot to explore in this game. Influenced in large part to having different player starting mats for every player, which creates a nice asymmetry and replayability. Stefan Feld's games, more than any other designer (at least based on this and Luna), remind me of clock-work devices, with lots of little gears and mechanisms all interacting with each other. There's so much going on, so much to play with and discover.

The visual aspect of the game is very subtle. At first glance it seems underwhelming, with all the pale colors. But if you look closer you can appreciate the care that was put into the production. The illustrations are all intricately detailed and nicely done. Even the player mat hexes, if you look really closely, have tiny textures that match their theme (such as forests for the dark green). The intricate visual aspect of the game actually nicely matches that "clock-work gears" feel of the mechanisms.

Looking forward to more plays of this one!

Won in "Designer's Cup," Rapier 2012.  Traded for Liberte.

RATING: 9
Played many times now. I really like this game the decisions are very interesting. Planning is critical, efficient use of actions, and dealing with what you roll. The latter is the biggest potential problem with the game. You have to either work hard to collect die-modifying abilities or accept the outcome of not doing so. Falling  victim to random luck is crappy and it can happen in this game. 

Understanding that the dice might not cooperate, and planning for that is an interesting part of the strategy. Another potential problem is downtime if people think too much. With speedy experienced players this game is great, with those who agonize it can be unbearable, especially with 4 players.

--------------------------------
Played once with 4.

This is a bit more complicated than Feld's other designs. The game plays longer as a result and is more prone to analysis paralysis. However the return on the time investment is well worth it. It's a fantastic game full of interesting scoring options and decisions. 

I'm looking forward to playing this many times. The arrival of an English version will help considerably.

RATING: 9
Trivia: What do Seeland and Burgen von Burgund have in common? Players collect lots of VPs. The winner in both games will have more than 200 of them. A feeling of accomplishment is guaranteed.
In each of the 25 turns players have two actions which can be chosen from a broad array of options to build up their duchy. Mechanically this is a tile-laying game governed by dice that (dis-)allow selecting some of the options. Expect AP to be at work here. Typically, at game end individual players' mats will likely be filled up almost completely no matter which way the players went. It's efficiency in VP generation that's key. There's no destructive element in BvB. Interaction is usually not targetted but definitely provided nonetheless as the game consists of many small races to reach something first.
Upgraded to 8/10 after four plays as it's a good game for two as well.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Many different terms can be and have been used to characterize The Castles of Burgundy. I might describe it as a not-quite-solo optimization puzzle with dice-based constraints and a focus on action economy. Player interaction is limited to picking resources from a common pool and racing to be the first to reach a variety of goals. Everyone typically gets some of everything, so efficiency is required to get just a little more or sooner than anyone else. I can see why this kind of "continually build stuff, continually get rewards" gameplay is popular, even addictive, but in the long run I want something with a little more bite. Said to be better with two, said to be better with nonstandard player boards.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I'm mostly done with this game. For a year or more I played this a great deal, mostly on boite-a-jeux, which is why it has so many plays. It's a superb fit for asynchronous online play because you can be away from a game for hours or days and quickly assess the situation to make your play.

It's an elegant design with many tiny parts that fit together cleanly. I cannot help but admire the clockwork nature of the design. Yet after many plays I find myself admiring the structure of the game far more than the experience of playing it.

My frustration is that how I play doesn't depend much on what other players do. It's more of a puzzle than a game. Players wind up playing more against the game than against each other. During each phase your options are slowly reduced because players are taking hexes from the main board. So other players shape your decisions, which I like. But most of the time they are not taking hexes to develop a strategy in relationship to yours. They are merely taking hexes that enhance their own strategy, with little or no care to what you are doing. So when your choices become limited you rarely feel that it's because a player is forcing you to change and adopt your strategy. They are merely doing their own thing and the fact that your options are reduced is unintentional on their part.

But the problem isn't that as each phase winds down you have fewer options. The problem is your inability to develop an effective counter-response. While this game is often described as a point salad, it can often feel the opposite: a punishment game in which your options become weaker and weaker as each phase progresses yet for reasons that often feel somewhat random, even when it's the result of what other players do. 

With better players this is less pronounced. People are more likely to make choices based on what other players need. But even with experienced players this happens only rarely, and usually towards the end of the game.

You can get better at this game. Experienced players will typically crush new players. But experience isn't the whole story. The boards are not balanced. Board 8, for instance, is much more powerful than other boards. And some of the extra player boards in the first expansion will hobble even skilled players. Add in the random tile draws, which become more random with two players, since some tiles may never appear in a 2p game, and the result is a game that manipulates the players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
It's fun. Lots of choices every turn, but they are limited to some extent by the D6s rolled, which I think minimizes AP. There are a lot of interdependent points-grabbing opportunities. When I looked at the player boards before my first play, I saw the D6 symbols and thought everyone's land would end up the same, an on-rails game. That's not so. Probably the funniest part of this game is the animals tiles—that is, [i]taking[/i] the animals tiles you know would give a huge bonus to your opponent.

RATING: 9.8
Can't get enough of this game! The gameplay is just so seamlessly elegant. Not too much thinking because the dice limits what you can do, but enough strategic depth that you can force different approaches. 

Only, admittedly very minor, downside are the uncharitable components. Obviously the size of the box limited the different playerboards to thick paper instead of cardboard. For the colour scheme, however, there is no excuse. Such a blatant ugliness is seldom to be found these days and it is quite easy to confuse the bonus point tokens due to very similar green/gray tones. Heck, where the hell is BURGUNDY or other red tones, which the cover art and the name implies? Fix this in a reprint and you get what the 10 is reserved for.

RATING: 7
Whoa! This game is way more complicated and much longer than I thought it would be. At first, I thought it would be a simple "just play two dice each turn" game.

Instead, each turn is a struggle to:
- Find out what moves you can do
- Think about what moves are the best (for your plan or to hinder the plans of another player)
- Re-think each in response to the plays of the other players

By the 3rd phase, my brain was pooped-out.

I want to play again for sure, but not right away.

RATING: 6
A very similar experience compared to Macao. Yes, there are (quite big) differences between these Feld's games, but overall experience is almost the same. Burgund is more straight forward and easier to play & handle, because there isn't Macaos' challenging dice system AND every play feels more the same, because there are all the same elements available (compared to Macao, where half of the cards won't be available and you don't know which ones are missing). So Burgund is a bit smoother to handle, but in a same time you'll miss some challenge. I think to biggest issue is the length of the game: it should be a bit shorter - maybe 4 phase would be optimal (now there are 5 of them). At least: play with 3 players, not with 4 because the fourth player bring nothing else than more length.
 
So, overall: game is nicely made, but Macao or even Luna are better ones.
Updated 09/2011: the first experience was right. This is nice, but now need to own it.
Updated 05/2016: the card game version of this game is a better than this: it feels the same, but plays faster. If you're ever thinking about to get this, buy the cardgame version instead of this. You'll save some time AND money!

RATING: 7.5
Very euro with a fair deal of strategic avenues and more player interactions than is immediately obvious.  Quite easy to learn & play, and easy on the eyes (although yellow and green are way to close).  It's fairly original and not strongly reminiscent of anything I know.  The dice are evocative Kingsburg or Troyes but it's very remote.

Its a nice game but there are downsides.  The thing is too long for it's own good and generally overstays its welcome (4 phases would have been enough, our typical games is 2-3h).  Its deep enough that serious players will sometimes AP, making things worse.  Lastly it gets old quite fast.  The varying boards do little to renew the fun and the whole thing is very repetitive.  Space out your plays.

RATING: 5
The game is interesting but it's not something I would be eager to play. I am not excited to play the game, but it's not an horrible game either. There is a slight amount of randomness which is well used in the game since each roll can be used in various ways.

The first complaint is the color issue, not very color blind friendly especially with 3 shades of green. The board colors made it also harder to analyse what tiles are available to buy because there are too many colors. They should have used neutral colors as the board background to make the colored tiles stand out.

Second, at the beginning, all the buildings seem very confusing especially the fact that the yellow ones are unique. At least in puerto rico, there is text on the tile which makes the learning curve easier.

In our game people said they bought more ships than the usual, but I don't find the goods mechanic very interesting. The random placement is almost pointless because there were almost always 1 good in play at a time. I would have personally done it in a different way.

My biggest complaint is the play time. Most people said the game plays within 60 to 100 minutes. It took us at least 2h30 (150+ min) which is way too long for what it is.

So I am not very hooked by the game, but the game does not seem broken, over complex or convoluted. This is why people seem to like the game so much.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
LIKE:

* I appreciate the potential of variance in play with the different estate boards.
* The pain of being forced to use the dice results, particularly if you've made the mistake of not having many modifiers can be frustrating but I like this tension between gambling and setting yourself for a good chance.
* I appreciate that the dice modifiers allow you to turn a 6 into a 1 and a 1 into a 6!
* Lots of different methods towards scoring is available.  I'm wondering though if the game basically comes down to who plans for the final few rounds the best and doesn't run out of good options.  
* While the game is largely solitaire, there is still a fair bit of hosage occurring in what you choose to take from the depots, thereby forcing your opponents to keep changing their plans.  
* Be careful allowing yourself to get far behind in turn order as this will give you less chances to select the most desirable tiles.

DISLIKE:

* Downtime is potentially painful in this game.  When it isn't your turn, you should be thinking about your options so you can quickly take your turn when it arrives, but this rarely happens.  
* Some people have expressed concerns that the game ends too late in that they have completed most of their point options.  We didn't see that in our first game, but one person didn't plan well for the last two turns of the fifth phase and had little opportunity to score points while I ran right by him.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I had very high expectations when first playing this game. After all, it's supposedly the 10th best boardgame in existence right now. At first "Castles" didn't meet those expectations. But then I played it again... and again... and again..

This game is highly addictive and there are loads of ways to score points and many paths to victory. It's just a great puzzle of a game and one of the finest euros. My wife and I play this multiple times a week and we're not so much competing as trying to best our own highscores (mine stands at 234 at the moment).

Really like this game and time will tell if I'll grow to love it and come back to it in the years to come.

RATING: 6
[u]Comments:[/u]
The Castles of Burgandy is another in a line of Alea box games that came into maturity back when Puerto Rico was released under the line. Ravensburger knows what they are doing with the line of games, and knows there market. CoB doesn't have any flaws, it plays smoothly from beginning to end, and overall its a decent package. That being said, CoB doesn't really tread into any new territory. Its problem is that it always seems like a game you probably played a few years ago, but just couldn't remember the name of. Gameplay is really tight, and flows pretty well, although some of the rules can be somewhat obtuse to new players for the first ocuple of plays. The components and artwork definitely leave something to be desired and it seems as though Ravensburger has slid backwards in terms of their investment in the quality of the components for their Alea games, which ultimately is really a shame. The setting also leaves a lot to be desired as just another bland medieval building game. Yawn!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
In my mind, similar in "ranking" and kind with Notre Dame: efficient, simple but efficient euro, that keeps you engaged. Alhambra is simpler but keeps you engaged as well, in a similar way with simple things. 

In Castles of Burgundy, I like the relatively fast turns, and the little goals that pop up together when the players are close to completing a district (we try to grab a tile useful for either us or an opponent).

I like that the game is cleanly done. Clean score counting (upside tokens and special powers). 

I do not mind the "point salad" aspect of it: the game felt more like a race than anything, with multiple temporary goals that act as that many strides—more difficult goals that reward the player with a bigger point stride. I do know where I should have prevented my opponent from going that fast on the point ladder, or where I should have thought of a way of going faster myself.

Now, I don't find any special spark in the game, like I find in games like Warhammer: Diskwars, Heroscape, Race for the Galaxy, Magic, Battlelore (second edition) or even Agricola and all its cards.

It's a good euro, with simple and clean rules, and with some obvious goals to fulfill in parallel, which creates some nice but basic tension. Solid but without a spark. I slightly prefer Notre Dame, which is a bit more thematic and has more flavorful powers. In the end, though, the games that enthuse me are those with strong in-game effects, with flavorful and varied powers, etc. So: really solid but ultimately too bland for being, in my eyes, an exceptional game.

RATING: 9
There has been a lot of attention given to [thing=84876][/thing] after it came out, particularly as a two player game.  That being said, despite the rave reviews, [thing=84876][/thing] was somewhat intimidating to get started with.  The graphic design left a lot to be desired---in some cases, the muted color palette can look classy (for example, with Old World maps), but here it gave the game a subdued, drab look.  Beyond that, the dice icons and the rest of the iconography on the board made the game look extremely dry and mathematical.  In addition, for some reason, the rules felt very opaque to me.  Although in reality there are only a few actions you can take, just trying to read the way they interlocked made by head hurt.  My wife took one look at the game and gave me an "Are you serious?" look.

And yet, everything clicked and crystallized after we got started.  We immediately played another round.  And another.  In fact, we played several rounds every weekend for a couple of months.  The game is subversively addicting---despite the apparent complexity, the dice rolls provide an elegant way of limiting/guiding your actions (and reducing analysis paralysis).  However, there are still ways to mitigate your dice rolls through the worker tiles.  There is a good mix of tactics and strategy---in the beginning, we were mostly focused on what we could immediately do with a given set of dice.  However, after playing it more, we've started thinking more long term strategy.  Which areas should we focus on?  What type of tiles should we get?  What areas of the board should we push into?  The game also tapped into our like of special actions games---after a while, if we couldn't use a turn to do trigger multiple special actions, it felt wasted.  My wife in particular loves those types of optimization games.  In general, similar to [thing=31260][/thing], it's just pleasant to watch your board fill up with tiles.  

In the end, for us [thing=84876][/thing] lived up to its billing.  This is our second Feld game---we've enjoyed [thing=55670][/thing] as well.  I would probably say that I enjoy the tension/panic of [thing=55670][/thing] slightly more while my wife prefers the more freeform [thing=84876][/thing].  Both games give me a similar feeling to [thing=31260][/thing] and [thing=35677][/thing] (both favorite games of ours)---tension in one game, freedom in another.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
I don't know, this feels like Just Another Soulless Euro, but I still like it. The colors are bland, the mechanics are mundane, and the theme is basically non existent, but it still works. As always I like games with a spatial aspect, and although it can be frustrating not being able to place your tiles at times it adds some strategic planning to the game. The tile drafting I'm not sure I'm a fan of having a ton of options at the start of the phase and almost none near the end, and am so-so that you are restricted (unless you pay) based on your dice rolls. 

There's some indirect interaction in the drafting of your tiles/goods and racing to be the first to completely fill a color. However while I'm sure there's plenty of strategy of when it's worth to snipe your opponent or not the game still gives the feel that it's more you versus the game, both from the race against the clock aspect of trying to fill completely the regions before it moves onto the next phase, and the luck mitigation of trying to place your tiles down in general.

The point salad aspect seems to make several diverging strategies viable. You will fill up most of your board by the end of the game, but how you do so (especially with the science buildings), exactly which few hexes you leave out, and when you do so matters. The inflation of points I think makes this game seem a lot closer than it actually is. E.g. I lost by about 7% of the leader's score but felt like I had played much more poorly.

Each turn goes very quickly so despite having 25 turns per player the game isn't extravagantly long. However I feel like this game might not be ideal for AP players, as the huge amount of turns combined with a lot of slight optimizations could drag this game out.

RATING: 5
Nice game system. More abstract than expected, missing an opportunity to even give 'phase' a meaningful name ('era' for us).

Still taking too long, in part due to the tiny components on the too-small board with all the cluttered in-yer-face drawings all over it. Those tiles are so thin! Sometimes think we have a Worker on the board, but it's just the one printed there. Wish these images were grayed out instead of being so vibrant that they look like an actual tile sitting there on the board (or mat).

Really like the player mat material! This stuff is great and does not need laminating. The main board should be larger, and less busy. Heck, would like larger tiles, thicker tiles, larger player mats.

Which Building is that? The one with the blue roof, you say? Which one with the blue roof!! The little squished blue roof, or the great big rectangular blue roof?? Difficult to tell apart these unnamed building pictures.

RATING: 8.5
This is a very well designed game with poorly designed components. I really enjoy the feeling of building my village and earning points in a variety of ways.  I appreciate that there is a built in system to mitigate the randomness of the dice roll.  I also like that there are dice. And there's a small farming component. I heart farming. 

I wish that I didn't need to have studio lighting in order to see the differences in the colors in the game. (I'm constantly drawing the wrong colored tiles.) 

I wish the iconography was more intuitive. (I still need to look up what all of the buildings do and what the bonuses mean.) 

I wish the player boards were made of higher quality cardboard. (This game looks and feels like a print-and-play that someone printed out on their inkjet printer that completely ran out of blue and was low on red.) 

I wish the scoring track didn't have a jog at the end. It looks like a blatant design mistake that publisher ignored. "Bah, we're going to market. We don't have time to fool around with formatting." (This is how I imagine these errors came to be.) 

But I really like playing the game despite it's production flaws.

RATING: 7
Castles is the best dice-based game I have played since Troyes. Castles is also VERY long. I really enjoy the game, the variety, tension, and wealth of options throughout each play however.

I'm concerned that Castles is likely best with 4 given that every tile appears in a 4P game and that there are more available tiles vs player actions leading to each round being 5 turns of great choices not 3 or MAYBE 4 with good choices. I still had a fun time with the 3P experience but there's something to be said for the full player count.

I'm also highly motivated to use the alternative player boards as I think there will be less player collisions based simply on equal desire from a static setup. I think the tension would be even higher, the games more varied, and the competition more fierce at times when the variable boards create uneven levels of demand.

I think it's Feld's best game with In the Year of the Dragon being a very close second.

RATING: 7
The best 'modified' dice game in 2010-2011. (compared with Troyes and Macao)
The major differences between these games being that Burgen is:
1. Best use of small rolls;
2. most thematic (for buildings only, for others, it's still an abstract game with paste-on theme);
3. Least luck dependent;
4. Most interactive.
I hate almost every other game designed by Mr Feld, this game is an exception that I'd play eagerly, maybe even bought a copy later.
The worst of game the being the graphic design: the drawings of the buildings are just not functioning and we can't recognise every single one of them even till the end of the game.

RATING: N/A
Jeder Spieler hat eine eigene Landschaft, bestehend aus 36 Feldern, zu bestücken. Motor meines Zuges sind zwei Würfel. Deren Werte erlauben es, einen Marker vom zentralen Spielplan auf meinem Plan zu parken oder vom Parkplatz aus in die eigene Landschaft zu integrieren, sofern die Würfelergebnisse passen.
Zwei Würfel, zwei Aktionen, schon ist der nächste Spieler dran. So einfach ist es grundsätzlich, aber die Marker lösen weitere Aktionen aus. Um Siegpunkte zu sammeln, gibt es eine Fülle an Möglichkeiten. 
Die Burgen von Burgund sind komplex und herausfordernd ohne schwere Kost zu sein.

RATING: 8.6
solid game!
easy to understand game play mechanics
strategies are easy to plan but pleasantly challenging
game pace stays level
works great with every amount of players
just enough random draws to keep each round and each game played fair but fresh
high level of competition without adding much "screw you" type of moves 

-does drag on with 4 players, due to the fact you can't really plan while waiting

two key mechanics that this game executes very successfully is who goes first each turn and you turn depending on what you roll.
whoever is further with a specific type of tile goes first, but if you catch up to them the player who was trailing behind now gets to go first.  This shocked me how fair it made the game.  
You actions are dictated by what you roll but you have the ability to change the outcome fairly easily.

RATING: 8
Although its probably to early to say after just two games, I think that the outstanding idea in Burgund, the one that might elevate it above the crowd of action -> VP converter games, is the use of topography. Tying die numbers to the spaces in your realm that can be developed makes it possible and necessary to plan ahead, balancing between the immediate gain of your two-action-punch and the benefit of opening up new spaces, preferably with numbers that a) you don’t access yet and b) fit with your stored building projects.

If this should prove to be true, the main strategic element of Burgund beyond the usual (combo hunting, action efficiency) is ensuring that you can’t have unlucky die rolls, because there’s always something you can do. Complementing that, tactics mainly seem to reside in ensuring that your opponents do have unlucky die rolls, and as can be expected from a Feld game, turn order is very relevant to this.

Since all information on available tiles, free spaces and, most importantly, dice results is available to the first player, the opportunities for messing up the plans of your opponents are manifold and obvious. Not obvious enough for everybody, apparently, because moans about the lack of interaction can be heard for those inclined to listen. I guess that these are the same folks that were incapable of perceiving the interaction in Race for the Galaxy, and will try very hard to say no more than that (just insert a mostly resignative rant about ‘gamers’ who regard anything more subtle than I KIL ALL UR GUIZ! action cards as non-interactive). I will concede that getting hold of that information is actively resisted by the graphic layout of the game, but I guess that this was not an easy game to illustrate and design. The other nit to pick is that it tends to be a bit longish, but this can be partly remedied by restricting your learning/teaching sessions to two players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
A Feld game I actually like, but can't quite put my finger on why.  

It is highly re-playable with a simple game flow.  Between the tiles that come out,the different player boards, and your dice results, no 2 games will be the same.  You can create small little combos with the tiles you play, plus you get to build up your kingdom.  However, the decisions in the game never seem to be that important.  Pretty much anything scores you points so if your first option isn't available, you have a 2nd almost equally attractive option to pick from.  That can make the game feel somewhat light.  In a game where your options decrease as the round goes on, you would think the tension would increase, but it does not.  You will not be punished in this game, at all.  So, it is definitely perfect for people that like low confrontation or just want a relaxing, but still somewhat thought provoking game.

This is a hard one to rate.  Started around an 8 and now after 15 plays (plus many more on yucata), I'd say it's closer to 6.5 to 7.  It's a good game and lots of people clearly love it.  Unfortunately for me, this is one of those Euros I don't find that interesting after I get in 10-15 plays.  Not enough to compel me to pull it off the shelf.  The card game version has taken its place for now.

Would likely enjoy playing someone else's copy sporadically, but not a keeper.  Will get rid of it eventually, once I need the shelf space.

Will not play this 4 player - too long for the type of decisions being made.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Absolutely brilliant design, this has a place on every gamer's shelf.  Perfectly balanced at every player count, the tile actions are simple to play yet offer remarkable  strategic depth.  While it's a bit tough to teach and the options can make new players feel overwhelmed, the dice mechanic narrows the focus while not completely limiting the options.  The only thing holding it back from being a 10 are the components, which are sub-par even for a euro game.

While I enjoyed the dice mechanic and the mechanics in general, I felt like there wasn't enough strategy to the game as there are just too many options to get exactly what you need.  By the end, everyone had most of everything and it didn't seem to matter what I did.  There are way too many ways to score points so the calculating of points is cumbersome.  There is very little interactivity or ways to mess with your opponents because tiles are so plentiful and the workers can always change the die rolls anyways.  What you have left is a fairly dry VP engine game.  

Also the graphic design and quality of the tiles is below par for what should be a top class design.  I guess they were trying to make this as cheap as possible because they wanted to appeal to a large demographic like Catan, but the game is too heavy and there are two many icons and rules to learn for that.

I can't help but be disappointed.

RATING: 9
Man, this is a satisfying game. Some strategies are apparent right off the bat, even on the first play, and every turn is interesting in some way. I never felt like I was forced to play a bad turn, and even when I likely didn't make the best choice available I was pleased with how things went.

I like that you can start with one strategy and stick with it, but will need to vary it a bit to snag surprise opportunities, block, etc. It's a good mix, and one I enjoy in most games; it's particularly well-implemented here. Turns are short, downtime is limited (and if someone slows down you can plan your turn in advance), and really everything about playing this is just plain fun. It works.

The boards are great; lots of information in a small space, but not crowded. The components are typical Alea: a bit thinner and cheaper than other major publishers, but not bad. The exception is the color choices, which are terrible; I'm not colorblind and I'm still bothered that "pale green" (in my country, we call this "yellow"), light green, and dark green are all used for tiles. Still, it doesn't really detract from the overall experience; it could just be better.

RATING: 6
Hmmm...

The good: 

1. It's simple
2. There are interesting decisions to be made
3. There are many paths to victory 
4. It's a clean design

1. The theme is non-existent
2. The components are awful...really really bad!
3. The rulebook, while not terrible, could be more clear. 
4. The art/colors are dull and uninspiring 
5. It seems like the die rolls *almost* don't even matter. While that's good from a randomness standpoint, it's at the cost of excitement and suspense. 
6. Turn order can make or break you in this game (even 2-player). With that in mind, I'm not a big fan of how turn order is determined. 
7. Because of the lack of theme and the "dryness" of the game, it made it feel like the ultimate euro. That is, how can I get the most points? The end. In that regard, it made Caylus seem flavorful and thematic. 

Overall: It probably sounds like I'm really hating on this game. I'm not trying to hate. COB isn't a bad game by any means. I can see why people like it (combos and engine building are fun). But it's just so dry and the dice just aren't that interesting. I'm willing to give it another try.

Traded away...simply not interesting or unique enough.

RATING: 8
My go-to Euro strategy game. COB is a Catan killer for me. There's asymmetrical gameplay and variable player boards, giving this game tons of replayability. Tons of small goals and achievements throughout the game that scores you points, leaving you with a good sense of accomplishment. Setup between rounds is a bit fiddly, but its well worth it. RATING: 9.75
From a design standpoint, I haven't played better. A dice game done right due to the sheer number of options a player is given within a focused group of actions so they never really feel screwed regardless of what they rolled. Compare this to Kingsburg, which offers numerous options but does so in a far more random feeling fashion. I'm actually surprised this hasn't been done more often in dice games.

I placed it #3 all-time after one play even though I got numerous rules wrong. I highly recommend printing off one of the player aids unless you want to spend a chunk of your first couple of games with you looking up types of buildings and knowledge tiles. I feel like I can play the basic boards 1-2 more times before moving on. The fact that the game comes with multiple player boards is a huge boost. Again, see Kingsburg.

Pet peeve, the manual points out you might need proxies for silverlings and worker tokens. For such a well designed game, it seems odd to knowingly give players fewer tokens than possibly needed.

Rating Potential: I would have to play a lot of other games for this to go below a 9, and it is a serious contender for a 10. I need more plays to further hammer out a score.

A relatív játékossorrend még a Caylusnál is ötletesebben lett kialakítva, kár, hogy itt jóval kevesebb jelentősége van, szinte alig változik a játék során. Nagyon kevés benne az interakció, szinte egyáltalán nem kell nézni, hogy mit csinálnak a többiek, ami nálam negatívum.

Update: a jó eredményhez muszáj figyelni a többieket is, néha jobban megéri elhappolni valaki elől egy neki nagyon sok pontot hozó lapkát, mint a saját pontjainkat növelni + ha az ember már jobban ismeri a lapkák tulajdonságait, akkor a játékossorrend is nagyon fontos lehet, tehát az utolsó két gondolat sztornó.

Néhány újabb játék után: azt hiszem, megtaláltam a kedvenc euro-mat. Nagyon tetszik benne, hogy csupa jó lehetőség közül választhatsz, bármit csinálsz, tudsz pontot szerezni, mégsem "overbalanced", mert egy jobb játékos mindig sok ponttal meg tud lógni a többiektől.

Újabb update: Az egyik legjobban megtervezett játéknak tartom, nagyon jól ki van egyensúlyozva, tényleg több működő stratégia van, nincs olyan, hogy elhanyagolom pl. a hajózást és akkor tuti nem nyerhetek. A lényege, hogy az adott leosztásból és a rendelkezésre álló erőforrásokból kihozzuk a legtöbb pontot. Mégis, mindezek ellenére úgy érzem, hogy lélektelen a játék. Jól meg van tervezve, jó "iparosmunka" de érzésem szerint hiányzik belőle a tervezői ihlet. A 10. játék után számomra kicsit egyhangúvá vált, nem érzem, hogy a következő x játék bármilyen szempontból különbözne az eddigiektől, azt hiszem erre mondják, hogy kijátszottam. Ennyi játék után már inkább érzem matekleckének mint szórakozásnak.
