=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I do like this game, and I like the dice mechanic. However, there is just a little too much luck involved, but it doesn’t completely ruin it. 

First, I like the theme and variety of options. I like the pieces, colors, boards. First time through is a bit slow, but pace picks up on replay. 

Early on the dice don’t mater too much because as others have pointed out, you have options. The exception is the first turn and getting the 2 Castles immediately as first player. 3rd and 4th player suffer a bit here. But at least ships help change this from round to round. 

Later on however, dice rolls are more important as you have less spots left on your map and so luck factors in more. You can change your luck with the workers (and some yellow tiles) but better for the person who rolls lucky and never has to use a worker. 

The other random factor – picking tiles to put on the board for each phase – also can be good or bad luck. The biggest issues there are the animals that come up and the yellow tiles. Animal farming seems to have the biggest spread of possibilities and this random tile generation can make or break that. Also there are only so many yellow tiles that have end game bonus, so when/how they turn up can be key (and lucky). 

For all the bad of this luck, it is also the thing that adds excitement to the game. 

The only bad part seems to be the time length. As someone pointed out, perhaps 30 min per player. That’s a long game to play to the end and lose in last phase because a tile did or did not come up. 

Still, overall a great game and glad I have it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[i]Castles of Burgundy[/i] appears to be well-balanced, offering multiple paths to victory.  I have won on the strength of my yellow tiles (without playing a single animal tile) whereas another player won on the strength of his animal tiles (without playing any ship tiles).

Although I am far from good at this game, there do appear to be some basic rules-of-thumb that should be followed to increase your chances of winning:

- Placing mines early is a huge advantage
- Placing castles and animals early offers no major advantage (with animals, be patient and ensure that they match)
- Placing ships is most advantageous during the last round of a phase so that you can become first player during the first round of the next phase (and have access to a full board and black market)
- Placing yellow tiles with in-game benefits should be done early whereas those with end-game benefits should be taken selectively throughout the game

The game scales reasonably well from 2-4 players, as the number of available six-sided tiles is proportional to the number of players.  My preference is the two-player game, for two reasons.  It is a much shorter game (an hour versus two hours with four players) and there are many more opportunities for screwing your neighbor, compared to a four player game (which feels a little more like solitaire).

While it is fun playing with different boards, I think having everyone play with the #1 board makes the game the most balanced.

RATING: 5
01/24/12 Played a four-player game. 
- The box says 90 minutes. Ha! 
- Noticeable downtime.  
- The theme (building a principality) and mechanics (dice allocation) are nothing new. That's not to say they are combined in an uninteresting fashion.
- Some see the multiple number of choices one can make on a turn as a sign of flexibility, keeping one from being stuck due to bad dice rolls. But the down side of that is it can lead to analysis paralysis.
- Its not exactly multi-player solitaire. But player interaction is so indirect it sometimes feels that way. Many will find this dull, especially when stretched over 2.5 hours. 
- The iconography at times is hard to decipher. Coupled with the tiny size of the tiles this can lead to frustration.    
- There is no "engine building" so each turn is almost the same as every other. This has lead several on BGG to ask why the game needs to go five turns. As it is, game length can lead to boredom.  
- There are *many* comments on BGG (and in the two video reviews I watched) saying playing with four people is a very bad idea. For it exacerbates the AP/downtime problem a great deal. 

I will play it again (hopefully not with four). But you'll never hear me asking for it, for I've played much better dice allocation games.  

12/23/14 Played part of a four-player game. I bailed out after 78 minutes; I'd had enough. I'd rather never play this game again. I changed my rating from a "6" to a "5".

RATING: 9
I've really enjoyed my few plays of this.  Players are constantly making decisions, but interestingly most of the decisions don't really feel like they're working toward any larger goal -- you're generally trying to tie a few moves together to eek out a few extra points.  Since all players are doing this in various different ways, the game feels sufficiently competitive without being highly confrontational.  Essentially you're just looking for cool combos based on the available tiles, but putting those combos together and watching them pay off is a fun puzzle for me.

The decisions are not that interesting, since everything you do gets you points.  The game is in trying to do it as efficiently as possible, which leads to calculating and recalculating and blah blah blah it goes on FOREVER.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Game in a Nutshell: Acquire and add tiles to your own little "island" while scoring points in a multitude of different ways.

Played as: 2,3,4 player

Pros: I quite enjoy the main mechanic of the game where you roll two dice and have several different options of how to use a given die result. This really adds a fair bit of space to play your turn with some tactical creativity. It really balances the level of tactics required with any strategy which one might choose to persue. It's a game I've actually done quite well with trying different things such that I don't feel like there's one go-to way to play the game (though there are perhaps some minor nuances to avoid). Great price point for a mid-weight euro in these times of over-produced games.

Cons: It's taken me about a dozen plays to know what certain building or tech tiles are without having to look at a cheat sheet every time. Visually, the game is very boring... so much so that I probably never would have purchased it had it not been such a great price. I'm not sure the various player mats add enough variety; but perhaps that's just to say the game can feel same-y to a degree even with different player mats. I don't know, I just find myself beginning to wish there was something to shake the game up more after my first 10 or so plays.

Other: One of the biggest knocks for me is that it's the type of game that employs a passive aggressive form of interaction (I get that that's a personal preference). Due to that low interaction though, there's no real benefit to increasing the player count as it only adds downtime and does very little (make a few more tiles available each round) to change the game up.

Best Use: A tactical but relatively freindly mid-weight euro for two.

RATING: 9
This game had been lying dormant in my gaming group's collection for a long time when I finally decided to give it a go in getting it to the table. I ended up absolutely loving it, it's a really nice, strategic game of building up your own area of Burgundy.

There are issues, but not with the game. The production makes some of the tile types a bit too similar in colour scheme, which can be problematic in set-up, changing out tiles between phases and putting away the game. If there ever was a new edition of this game, I'd absolutely go for it despite having my own copy of this now.

Gameplay itself is solid, there are many different paths to victory, and it's all about seeing which one will work the best for you. Have enjoyed all player counts I've played so far and it seems to scale well. 

Highly recommend this game, look beyond the washed out appearance of the board and tiles, this is a solid game, well worth your time.

RATING: 9
This game is entertaining. I don't know if there's anything new in how the dice are used, but I like the way you can set up combinations using tile abilities to make double and triple moves. I would probably rate it an 8, but the tile icons are a severely lacking, making the game almost unplayable without the player aids. I've played a couple of times now with aids in hand, and I doubt I could play the next game without using the aids either. And since different tiles are on different aids, you end up flipping back and forth between them. It's kind of annoying. Fortunately, the game is fun enough to make up for the nuisances. A great non-confrontational, game for all types of gamers.

RATING: 8
[microbadge=1714]

[u]08-Jan-2013[/u]: This game is right up my alley, and once I play it with others (I hope!!), this rating will definitely go up.  There are tons of tiles.  Lots of variety in set up, gameplay, and paths to victory.  The dice mechanisms are very well done.  This is the only Feld game I've played and I wish I could try out others.  Unfortunately, with my mostly solitaire game life, that just isn't going to happen.

Anyway, CoB is really fun.  The way the main board integrates with your personal board and the use of dice and all of the various tile powers...it all comes together really nice.  It can seem a bit fiddly, but I don't mind that so much.  It also feels a tad long, again which I don't mind much, but once I try this with my family, I'm going to need some time put aside to teach it and play a full game.  We seem to be a slow playing group in general.  We'll have to see how it goes.

So far, I've only played solo mulitplayer games and I've used this [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/679446/solo-variant]solitaire variant[/url] with some minor tweaks similar to [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/article/9968634#9968634]these suggestions[/url].  It's been quite a while since I've gotten to play this, and that's a real shame.  I can't wait for it to hit the table some time soon.

[u]31-Oct-2015[/u]:  I've played using the [listitem=2672240]SoloPlay[/listitem] Variant several times now, so I figured I'd add some comments.  I really like this variant a lot!  It's probably one of the easier ones to grok out of all the SoloPlay rules I've tried so far.  The only wonky part is setting up the board.  But once you get over that hump, it's pretty quick to play, feels enough like the multiplayer game, and has some additional challenges for the solo gamer to overcome.  As I've rid my collection over the past two years of several games that only provide user-made solo variants, this is one that will definitely remain for the reasons mentioned.  Easily recommended.

[size=10][u][i][b]r{Initial Thoughts}r (after 5 plays):[/u][/b][/i][/size]
* Excellent worker placement/dice Euro
* Designer has succeeded in making a game where two dice have a myriad of possibilities
* Expansion boards add freshness and a challenging new rule regarding tile placement
* Tactics and strategy are key to thwart opponents AND maximize end-of-game scoring
* Wealth of options can bog down games with AP players
* Great for any fan of medium weight Euros and those that enjoy multiple scoring paths
* Initial rating: [b]9/10[/b]

Kockavezérelt lapkalehelyezős, elegáns euro game. Igazából, ha nem lenne ráírva a dobozára, hogy Feld mester tervezte, már a játékszabályzat alapján megmondtam volna a Notre Dame és a Bruges után, hogy ez is a német tervező zseni íróasztalának fiókjából hódította meg a világot.

Amint a fenti cirkálmányos mondatom már sugallhatta: bizony ez a játék igencsak találkozott az ízlésemmel. Kocka ugyan ebben is van (mint a "feldek" többségében), de a szerencse faktor itt is minimalizált (akárcsak a "feldek" többségében). A tematika meg tökmindegy ugyebár. (Ameri-rajongóktól ezúton is elnézést!)

Már az első játékot követően nagy kedvenc lett, 24 óra alatt 5 partit sikerült lejátszani vele és alig várom már a következőt.

Asszem be kell szereznem az összes Feld-játékot...

Ez meg egy erős 9-es lesz, alig elmaradva a tökéletestől. (Fél pontot meg mondjuk a nem túl erős dizájn miatt vontam le, de amúgy meg tökmindegy...)

RATING: 8
First foray into the world of Feld--a very good game: thin on theme and interaction, but great fun trying to optimize your own little estate. Have enjoyed about an equal number of 2- and 3-players games, preferring it with three despite the longer playing time.

There are many moving parts here, room for clever play and a number of viable strategies. Turn order is an important advantage, yet you can win without having gone first much of the time. Animals can rack up a bunch of points, but aren't always crucial to winning. The mines as a source of silverlings are nice, but not always necessary for success. I would say though that players who disregard point-scoring knowledge (yellow) tiles do so at their peril.

A certain sameness set in after a while, despite the variety of playing boards. Perhaps we played too many games in too short a time. [14 plays]

RATING: 2
Excruciating. I thought Feld's most popular design would somehow transcend his previous efforts, but instead this is just the same old same old to the max: two hours of opportunistic, micromanaging point maximization. There's barely any strategy, as you're going to have to do a little bit of everything (as usual) to win. Everything you do scores points, from twitching your finger to nodding your head. The theme is meaningless, and interaction is incidental at best. There's no arc to the game; it's just the same thing over and over again. Macao and Glen More seem awesome by comparison, mostly because they are pretty much the same thing in less time. I will never play this again, and you're going to have to work hard to get me to try another one of Feld's designs.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Spelgezel

This seems like a difficult game at first sight but once you try it, you get away with it in 1-2-3! Based on your dice roll, you either buy a tile, or you place a tile, or you sell goods.  Even though you need some luck with the dice rolls, you can influence it with the worker tiles if you were smart enough to keep some.

Most of the times, there is always an action that fits your strategy. A nice optimization puzzle that also plays well with 2 players. A must have for people who like Agricola where the interaction between players is also indirect. The only negative points I can think of about this game are the poor design with the player's boards being printed on very soft cardboard, the confusing colors and the fact that it can last long with 4 players. But with 2-player it is fabulous and our favorite couple's game!

Besides Twilight Struggle it is the oldest game in BGG top 10 games and for me there is no doubt that it deserves its position in the list of best board games ever.

RATING: 8
Players looking for an intensely strategic euro will probably be disappointed, but this game provides some interesting choices as well as dice rolling that feels "good". There are many ways to use your roll (and you can use worker tiles to change the result), so it's very rare that a turn feels "wasted". 

The luck elements that sometimes bug me are the tiles that come out. If you have cows, being able to pick up more cows can be a great advantage (this might be better with 4 players as all farm tiles come out). Nonetheless, there are many ways to score points and the game has many interesting elements. Those elements, however, are largely disconnected from each other. This contrasts with a game like Puerto Rico where most of the actions depend on other actions.

The theme is not amazing but this isn't a game where I need much theme. The tiles are very abstracted but building your player board still feels meaningful. Overall this is a nice medium-ish euro if you're ok with a fair bit of luck.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.2
Overrated. If you have time and you don't know what to play, go for it. It's like candy crush for phones. Spending 1-2 hours where you don't feel the tightness. Like a point salad game.

Updated to 6: there isn't really anything more than a race with a little tactical planning for the current turn, just to see what others are going for (by observing their dice) and try to take one of their two tiles. And that's when you are the first player! Seriously, no matter how many players you play with, you can never block them as there are as many tiles as players in each action space. You can just get the one tile you "think"  is better before other players and they can still go for the rest of even mitigate the dice and go for another action space and still get points, many of them! 
Again like candy crush, the competition is based on victory points, to check it on another platform (Facebook) and see which of your friends have higher points! 
Note that my review is based on many two player games. There are many better games out there with more strategy and meat than a solitaire tile building.

Updated to 8: It looks like you can have fun with this game after all! There is definitely a tightness going on, because it is a race to go forward on the point track. And the game has a catchup mechanism, so all players race close to each other. As you can see, you have to play it few times before you see the fun in it!

L'initiative disputée par les tuiles navires, l'unicité et la diversité des 24 tuiles connaissances, la course pour compléter l'adhésion d'un type de tuiles au domaine, le trucage des dés, l'aspect "économique" des mines et de la vente des marchandises ne sont que quelques éléments qui rendent chaque partie un véritable casse-tête.

Malheureusement, je déplore principalement trois choses à ce jeu: 1) la qualité et l'aspect du matériel (plaque de domaines très minces, nuance trop subtile entre les tuiles vertes de pâturage vs les tuiles jaunes de connaissances, beaucoup de petites tuiles à observer sur le plateau central et éventuellement sur les domaines des adversaires); 2) un certain manque d'interaction (il peut arriver d'acquérir une tuile surtout pour nuire à un adversaire, mais on peut rarement se permettre des actions "inutiles" étant donné l'espace de stockage limité à 3 et la situation distincte des domaines qui fait que chaque joueur ne recherche pas nécessairement les mêmes choses que ses adversaires. Dans ce même ordre d'idées, j'ai observé qu'à la fois mes adversaires et moi-même avons tendance à peu regarder ce que les autres font pendant une bonne portion de la partie, parce qu'au final, notre propre stratégie passe rarement par nuire à l'adversaire). 3) Dans 90% des parties jouées, le score final est très élevé et l'écart entre le 1er et le dernier joueur est très serré (Il est donc pratiquement impossible de "valider" durant les rondes 1-2-3 si la stratégie choisie sera victorieuse ou pas, et des résultats du style 180 à 178 me déçoivent, je que sois le gagnant ou le perdant).

Bref, un bon jeu, mais après une vingtaine de parties en deux mois, mon attrait pour ce jeu a quelque peu diminué...

RATING: 9.5
Really strong game. Quite a bit of variety when deciding what strategy to take collecting victory points. Almost everything in the game is of value in more ways than one. 

I had to dock a half point for a couple things that are minor. First, while the game gives you tons of options for what to do with your 2 turn actions, optimal choices can be unavailable based on nothing but a die roll. For some this isn't a problem, but for me it makes me feel less in control of my own strategy. This could have been a worse issue if you didn't have ways of modifying die rolls with the workers.

Secondly, while nearly everything in game is rewarding, I'm convinced that building mines is much less valuable than other options. You can get some bonus points for early zone completion, but one silverling at the end of the round compared to the rewards from buildings, livestock, ships (since they allow you to grab commodities and increase your turn position) or even the knowledge tiles, it just doesn't seem like enough. It could be that I just haven't fully committed to this tactic and it pays off heavily in later turns with more mines, but it does seem less effective from what I've played so far. Still though, a fantastic game and will stay in my collection for a good while.

RATING: 8
There are 25 turns in this game to build up your landscape. After rolling two dice, players use the dice to acquire tiles from the main board, put tiles to your own board, sell goods or take extra workers. You earn points for completing areas, and more points are earned if you complete them early. There is a racing aspect as well since you earn bonus points for finishing certain areas ahead of your opponents, and knowledge tiles from the board can give you bonus VPs as well. 

This is a very good game. Each turn you have tough decisions, as you want to help yourself, but don't want to leave good tiles to your opponents, but  your dice rolls limit what you can do. It's very tense and engaging. It's great as a 2 player and 3 player game.

RATING: 5
I think the idea of the game is good, but the gameplay doesn't strongly grasp me. Its smooth gameplay, and I can somewhat see its depth, but I think the drab looking board and dice both put me off a bit, not to mention that the gameplay doesn't draw me like other euros. I'm also a sucker for production quality and this is pretty bottom barrel IMO.

In general, I think I am not a fan of Feld since many of his games are nonintuitive and just don't click for me. Why is it that a 1 pip or 2 pip tells you how far to move on a track, for example? Stuff like that in his games annoys me. I like euros, but usually I understand the intuitiveness of gameplay. For example, in Caverna, step on a space and get that space's action. In Cuba, the role cards tie directly to the board. It would be okay if the actions were clear or simple, if it didnt make sense. For example, in Hansa Teutonica, you play a cube, teleport cubes, or you clear a route. Simple, smooth and streamlined. Even in Alien Frontiers which has similar dice manipulation, the board clearly elucidates what you can do, even if its not tied intuitively. In Feld's games, the understanding for why certain mechanisms do certain things are a lot less intuitive (mainly because of symbology) and a lot less clear boardwise and spacewise. There's the side space on the board with the symbols, but a lot of things felt kind of arbitrary and deciphering it was hard for me, at least. Things like "castle gets you another dice result" felt kind of random. Even in Dominion, it made sense as the things in your kingdom are an investment over time.

Anyway, overall, I am not crazy about replaying this again. Another small thing I dislike is how tactical this game is, since I prefer strategy. I know there's plenty of dice mitigation for longterm planning, but I still am not crazy about it, and I think there's many other tactical games I'd prefer to play first. In this one, rolls can make a minor difference and also uncertainty to what tiles may come out can be a bit annoying. Feld gets around this being a big problem by making it point salady so everything has somewhat close relative value so no one jumps too far ahead, but that makes the individual plays and points feel not as power/not as meaningful. Also, despite being a highly acclaimed 2P game, I did not find it that amazing. I'd rather play a different semi-multiplayer-solitaire game for 2P than this one.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A bit early on the draw, but at the moment 9 seems reasonable. Might go up to 10 if I become better at the game, or slip to 8 if I don't... :P

The aim is to build the area around your castles (in Burgundy, I guess). You do so by filling you board with tiles. These tiles are gathered from a common area. 

Everything in the game is numbered from 1-6, and your actions are dictated by the roll of two dice.
Rolled a 2 and a 5? You could take tiles from the common area, as long as they are numbered 2 or 5. Or maybe add tiles to your own board, as long as the areas are numbered 2 or 5. You could also sell goods, if the numbers match. And so on. There’s always something you can do.

Figuring out the right move for the right moment is the hard bit. The balance between this and the luck of the roll is brilliant!

Even the worst of rolls allows you to get workers, and workers allow you to change your dice. Didn’t like the 2 and 5? Spend a worker and the 2 is a 1. Another worker turns it into a 6.

Getting the tiles onto your board is what scores you points.
Some tiles give different bonuses, so placing the right tiles in the right order can start nice chain reactions.

The rulebook is a bit of a mess. A quick summary of why you play the game would’ve been nice. Also, some things need to be rearranged for clarity.

Finally, there are a lot of colours in this game, both on the board and on the tiles. Some of these colours are very similar, so you need to play this game in good lighting.
I’m really glad I still have good eyes, or this game would be unplayable...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Castles Of Burgundy is an excellent game desperately in need of a Special Edition. Mechanically it is a well designed city-building, resource management game for 2 or 3 players. (Although it can be played with 4, play time increases a little too much for my taste.) Turns move quickly, slowing occasionally from slight analysis paralysis. End game scoring is a swift affair that isn't bogged down with complex calculations.

Where CoB needs revision is its instruction manual, but more importantly a redesign is needed for the game's overall appearance. CoB is just visually unappealing, which is particularly astounding given that most city-building games usual endgame result is an attractive and unique little district that players can be proud of and often find photo-worthy. CoB has that potential, but falls short due to the murky, bland art design of all of its components, from its box down to the smallest tile.

It is clear that Alea/Ravensberger were trying to keep their costs down when they chose the components for CoB. Victory point and turn counters are just cut and painted wood dowel. The dice are a good size, but generic. The majority of playing components are tiles made from the thinnest possible card-stock. Game boards are of the next thinnest. Although small changes could be made to improve the other components, its the tiles that are really the problem. Tiles represent several elements of gameplay and even varying their thickness would have been an simple way to differentiate them.

RATING: 7
Feels similar to Macao, here there are four basic actions. In one you acquire a hex tile - representing a building/castle/silver mine/animals/ship/bonus possibility - and store it on one of three slots on your player mat and in a different action you place it on your landscape (that has color hexes corresponding to the tiles) to activate the hex. With ship activation you get goods tiles - also stored on three slots on your mat - that can be sold for one gold and VPs in a third kind of action. Each player gets to do only two basic actions in a turn and there are 5 turns in 5 rounds. Your actions are driven by your own two dice you throw each turn: each dice allows you to do one action. There are six areas on your mat numbered 1-6 where the hex tiles, that entered the game are on display. The hexes on the landscape of your mat are numbered and the goods tiles too. Your dice throw must correspond to the numbers on the mat or on the goods tiles in order to be able to execute one of the already mentioned three actions. There is a fourth action where you acquire two dice modifier tiles. Each modifier can shift the value of the dice by one. Beside the four basic actions there is a special action where for two coins you may acquire one hex tile per turn. The effect of the hex tiles when activated helps in many different areas. The buildings may allow you to pick or place another hex tile or earn silver coins or dice modifiers. The castle gives a free additional action without throwing dice. The silver mine earns a silver after each round. The animals give instant VPs corresponding to the number of the same kind of animals in the enclosed area. The bonus tiles modify some of the actions or give game end VPs for collections of buildings, goods tiles or animals. Additionally as the landscape fills up with tiles there are instant bonus VPs awarded for completing parts of a landscape and for being the first or second to fill up all of the same kind of hexes first or second. So there is a lot to pay attention to. It is a good thing but it induces AP, so our first three player game was three hours. It is a little too long for a game where you acquire VPs in small increments from different sources. I prefer not to play this with 4, it is just too long.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I LOVE this game. Yea, yea it's a point salad but it's a very good point salad. I love the fact that there's no bad rolls or turns where you can't do anything. Everything just works in this game.

RATING: 10
[size=9][b][c]OVERALL REVIEW:     :star::star::star::star::star:[/c][/b][/size]
[size=8]Multiple uses of the dice, with a well balanced marketplace, and player board expansion mechanics. Everyone that I have introduced COB to has really liked it! And yes, I am a fan of Feld games.
[color=green]My favorite dice rolling game.[/color][/size]

[size=9][c]RULES SIMPLICITY:   :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar:[/c]
[size=8]After a turn the actions are intuitive, but rules consulted for buildings[/size]
[c]QUICK SETUP:        :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar:[/c]
[size=8]A lot of pieces, but storing them separately helps setup[/size]
[c]SHORT GAME LENGTH:  :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar:[/c]
[size=8]Depending on players, an hour and half.[/size]
[c]MAXIMUM STRATEGY:   :star::star::star::star::star:[/c]
[size=8]Always multiple ways to use your dice, and you can plan ahead[/size]
[c]MINIMUM LUCK:       :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar:[/c]
[size=8]Dice rolls every turn, and random tile draws replenish marketplace[/size]
[c]PLAYER INTERACTION: :star::star::star::star::nostar:[/c]
[size=8]Players build their own board, but can snatch tiles from others in the marketplace[/size]
[c]COMPONENT QUALITY:  :star::star::star::nostar::nostar:[/c]
[size=8]All cardboard, beautifully illustrated and colors work well[/size]
[c]THEME INTEGRATION:  :star::star::star::star::star:[/c]
[size=8]You feel like a Baron/Baroness growing your fiefdom.[/size]
[c]REPLAYABILITY:      :star::star::star::star::star:[/c]
[size=8]Every play is different and there are multiple kingdom boards to choose from[/size]

[b][c]BEST WITH:[/c][/b]
[size=8]4 players[/size]

[b][c]MY PLAYS:[/c][/b]
[size=8]in-person with 3, 4 players[/size]
[/size]

[ImageID=2917152 small]

Players roll their dice simultaneously at the beginning of a turn. This prevents downtime when it is another player's turn, as each player is able to strategize how to use their dice, and have an alternative option or two in case the first opportunity is lost. Additionally, there is a secondary marketplace where players can spend currency to purchase tiles, and save their dice for tile placement.

A player can also use a worker to change the value of a die, which creates additional opportunities, and can potentially mask their planned actions from other players. All information is public, and it is to every player's advantage to know other player's options and how they might intersect with their own plans.

There is interaction where players might be in a race to acquire a specific tile. But given various options for using the dice values, any player that loses a race for a specific tile, has other opportunities. All actions can help benefit a player in one way or another, so there is never a turn when a player feels they have wasted an action. Completion achievements for player board regions and first and second completion bonuses help focus player strategies.

[color=#3388cc][b]Pimp it?[/b][/color]

I have replaced the silverlings cardboard tokens with metal coins. I have seen some people upgrade the turn order and/or scoring tokens with miniatures.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game has a very tactical feel to it. You are mainly concerned with what you can do with your die roll, although there is the ability for limited future planning.

After another play, I think there's more to this that I had previously thought. You do have to consider what other players are doing, and try going for the types that aren't being pursued by others. Taking quarries early is worth it, it's always nice to be able to buy additional buildings.

I still think this is mainly a tactical game, since you can never be sure what you're going to be able to do from turn to turn. Still, you can have an overall goal, and as long as you have multiple tasks at hand, you'll likely be able to advance something.

RATING: 5
More plays required. It seems to outstay it's welcome by about five turns (one round). This may drop it's rating with more plays...

Update:

I like it fine enough, but it's my least favorite Feld I own, and if I didn't own it, I don't think I'd get it again.

Verdict:

What I Like: The game is easy to play and not overly mentally taxing for a Feld design. The procedural construction on the players personal land mat is (artificially) satisfying in a derivative way. Some pleasant Feldian action/point mutiplication combos are present here.

What I Don't Like: Regardless of the player count the game always lasts a round longer than I think it should, but it is obviously designed such that shortening it via houserule would completely undermine some strategies. The two and three player games are often decided by the random tile seeding (Better guess your early field animals correctly! Hope that one building you need appears!) The art is graphically dull.

Some Extra Thoughts: The people I know who enjoy this game are the people who enjoy building personalized stuff in boardgames regardless of whether they win or lose. Comparatively, I find less (though admittedly some) enjoyment in putting stuff together, so that aspect mostly falls flat and I'm left with a game I'm rather unimpressed with, especially when compared to Feld's outstanding heavier creations (Trajan, Bora Bora).

I'll probably never get friends with Stefan's philosophy of game design, yet I can see why people enjoy Castles of Burgundy. RATING: 10
[b]The Castles of Burgundy[/b] was reacquired* in a math trade 3/21/15.

[COLOR=#FF0000]A year later... thoughts and rating (10):[/COLOR]

[i]I was dead wrong about this game and I made a huge mistake when I traded it. I can see this game getting a ton of play when I am looking for a 2p game to play with anyone in my family (well not Lilly yet). This will probably be the next medium weight game I introduce to my wife and I'm hopeful she will like it.

I just played a game with my son and I think he did a great job summing it up... it's like Suburbia with dice. This means we'll be playing CoB a lot since Suburbia is one of his favorites. I am really looking forward to more plays of Castles and highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a 2p, medium weight Euro.

- Excellent, medium weight 2p game (definitely my favorite player count for this game).
- Dice manipulation done right, everything you can do with the dice in this game is extremely intuitive.
- Streamlined game play, while the game make look complicated once it is set up it turns play very quickly. This game is easy to teach (just don't try to explain all the science tiles at once).
- My favorite family/mid weight Feld title. (I've played Bruges, Castles of Burgundy, La Isla, Luna, The Name of the Rose, Notre Dame, The Speicherstadt, Strasburg and Trajan.)[/i]

[COLOR=#FF0000]Initial thoughts and rating (7):[/COLOR]

[i]This is the third Feld game I have played, the others are Bruges and Notre Dame. As of now Notre Dame may be my favorite, but it is currently out of print. I am not sure how I feel about his games yet, which means that I don't know if I like point salad games. I need to play all of these more before I make up my mind, so on some level I definitely enjoy them.

I like Castles but I need more plays before I decide whether it is a keeper or not. I do enjoy how the dice are used to determine what you can do on a turn. And I always enjoy finding ways to maximize points, but as of yet I feel like the game is a bit random. Also the components are mediocre at best. This is definitely one I want to return to and I look forward to teaching my wife.[/i]

*Was initially received in a math trade 4/14/14 then traded away for Agricola 7/17/14.

RATING: N/A
An engaging and fun Alea game! I really enjoy playing this one. It may be one of the best in the series. The rules as usual are very clear and easy to relearn and refer back to. There are several double sided boards, all different, for each player to choose from. Plus several more boards are available for purchase. The game is simple enough to play during a work week, yet engaging enough to feel like you really played a game.

I love the mechanic of rolling the 2 dice and using them to perform 2 actions each turn. You can purchase, sell and build all according to the single die result every turn. The puzzle building aspect to your personal game board really is fun and since there are so many boards, every game is totally unique.

RATING: 9
心得:
動作簡單
目標清楚
有可以常有combo的感覺 
不過玩那麼多場 
感覺好像還是沒有完全上手
規則:
1.起使用骰子數字決定 ， 三塊貨物 一塊錢 工人照順位 1-2-3-4
2.結束記分，沒賣貨物，銀幣一個一分，兩個工人一分
3.賣貨分跟人數一樣
4.建築物同一區不能重複
5.每回合兩骰作兩個動作加上頂多買一次黑市版塊
6.拿貨不能拿的就留在版圖上，不能棄貨物
7.動物版塊 只有在同樣圈地內的同樣動物才會累加記分
8.銀礦是大回合結束產的，最後一回合也會產
9.要拿版塊一定要有空位，拿的版塊不能棄

Solid and original gameplay with enough re-playability to earn a spot on my shelf.

RATING: 7
A VP accumulation game. Two actions per turn which are constrained by the 2 dice you roll. They determine which pool of tiles you can buy from (and you're racing the other players to pull out the ones you want/need first). They also determine where you can place on your board and which resources you can sell. While you're grokking that aspect, the next trick is to buy tiles that give you powers to get more tiles out faster, or allow dice manipulation, or sell resources quicker. Plus aiming for tiles that get you good bonus points for what you've invested in, or aim to invest in. With 50 actions, plus bonus tile payments and placements, that's a lot of micro turns which add up to 30 or more minutes a player. Generally you're euro-engrossed but there's some occasional downtime. There's no theme, so you're in it for the tactical analysis vs the strategic overlay - this is what I've rolled and what can I do best with it (including should I be spending my dice manipulator one-offs) given this is what I've invested in so far, and this is how I'm aiming to score big and does it fit within that strategy. And if not, do I do something else and hope to return to the bigger picture later. Which provides a decent puzzle-y type game, but lacks drama.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is Euro - and not non-gamers or new gamers.  It is not a difficult game.  It's just that there is a lot of symbols and a lot to think about and remember each turn.  Easy to get into for a gamer, but can put non-gamers off.  Having said that, this game is amazing. The whole time there is a tug-of-war feeling to it as you are building and getting points.  There are many ways to get ahead.  In each of the 5 phases of the game, the available options change just a little - not too much to throw off a strategy, but just enough to encourage you to adapt your strategy.  There is no obvious dominant path to victory.  It is often very close and is never over till the very end.

This is %100 Euro.  So for a Euro, I give it a 10.  Every Euro gamer needs this game and if you played a couple and like Euros, then you must have it.  But I believe that you have to score it in it's category.  Some gamers who only like American games may not rate this high.  But for Euro games, the game design is top notch.

RATING: 5
What I liked:
- Multiple paths to victory
- The only interaction is tile drafting
- Nice use of dice
- The theme is thin, but helps with learning the rules

What I didn't like:
- Longer than it should be (2.25-2.5 hrs)
- Very prone to AP for optimizers
- Overwhelming options at first
- Very little sense of progression throughout the game (phase 5 tiles are the same as phase 1)
- The theme is thin, so it plays more like an abstract
- I HATE the rule about not duplicating buildings within an area--each of my plays, it has messed me up big time
- I don't like the majority-ish race for turn order

NOTE: Both times I played (with different groups and teachers), we incorrectly took only one action per player turn, instead of taking both actions within one turn. Playing correctly would speed the game up (YAY), but would make the shipping race for turn order even more important (BOO).

Ultimately for me the long-ish play time combined with the thinness of theme leaves me hoping not to play it again, although I might if asked. It would be far better with only 4 rounds instead of 5. Probably 4 rounds of 4 turns would be even better.

I agree with a 3.1 weight, mostly due to the vast number of options available each turn.

RATING: 9
A Feld classic!  I love the tile placement and the way the tiles carry out actions for you once you place them on your map.  You're in a  constant race to finish sections of colors as quickly as possible, to get the biggest scores for them, and to get the bonus-point tiles before your opponent(s). Acquiring those yellow tiles will often help shape your strategy.  I also like the two-step process for being able to place your tiles on your map.  Nothing but solid mechanics wrapped up in a great game!

RATING: 8
You roll two dice and then use those rolls to take actions. That is the basis of the game. However, your board presents a collection of locations for tiles that you can claim (with your dice) and each has an effect when played or at the end of the game. Plus you get bonuses for completing sets of certain types of tiles, which based on your board only allows one tile type to be played in each hex. A great game, that fits well in the Alea series.

RATING: 7
I’ve played this a lot two player and only a few times with more than 2. I’m not sure I like it as much with more than two because of the extra down time and less chance of getting what you want each turn. Plus the tile drawing between each round gets a lot more arduous with more players.

The dice as workers is very cool and the special puzzle aspect of laying the tiles in your estate keeps the game interesting throughout. The sheer number of different kinds of tiles and the random way in which they are drawn really help to make each play different and fresh.
After playing it on an almost daily basis at one point it sat on the shelf for a number of months unplayed. We recently pick it back up and I’m still enjoying it, the mark of an excellent game I would say. The reason I haven’t scored it more highly is because it is lacking in theme and the art isn’t the greatest (very functional would be putting it politely), if my wife didn’t like this so much I think it would sit on the shelf for much longer periods.

RATING: 6.5
I don't think I'm the target audience for Feld games.

This isn't a bad game really, it's just the combination of near-zero player interaction and reliance on dozens of tile actions that require constant consultation of a reference that generally make it a pain to explain and teach that makes me dislike it.

The core loop is simple, sure, but the rest is a confusing mess of rules and actions that never really makes sense outside of the context of "well but it gets you points".

I don't demand strong theme, but Feld games take euro mechanics a little too far into abstract-land for me.

RATING: 7
Die Burgen von Burgund richiede un atto di fede: icomponenti (la plancia personale, quella comune e gli esagoni) sono di una bruttezza rara. 

Ma è un gioco di Feld, l'uomo che mette in ogni sua creatura una meccanica originale e azzeccata. In questo caso c'è l'uso creativo dei dadi, che ti fanno prendere tessere e costruire nel tuo territorio.

Il gioco non è per niente semplice: ci sono tante cose da tener d'occhio e molti modi per far punti: ogni zona del tuo possedimento farà fare punti vittoria in maniera differente. A questo si aggiunge la gara a chiudere per primo i vari tipi di territori.

Alla fine mi è piaciuto ma, e lo dico da eurogamer, questo è l'incubo di ogni giocatore di american game: l'ambientazione è davvero attaccata con lo sputo e componenti molto sotto la media.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I would imagine this game is hurt pretty bad by components, though it isn't too much of a factor in my opinion. The cheap components made this game inexpensive and easy to justify buying.

Plays pretty well with any number, but the gameplay seems to be the best with 3. Another game where the dice work perfectly.

With 4 player, I would definitely probably choose a different game, as there are better at that count, and it tends to drag on.

This has been downgraded to a 7. Still a really good game, but it makes me realize how important more variability is in my games. It just feels like each game is very much the same.

Downgraded again to a 6 after about 8 plays. The feeling that the game is just the same every time only continues to get worse. This is compounded by the fact that the game feels too long for how repetitive and relatively simple it is. I feel like my wife and I just whip through a game at top speed, and I can't imagine how the minimum 30 minutes on the box is realistic. My guess for most people, even somewhat experienced players, is that a 2 player game will be 45 to 60 minutes at least, and a 4 player game will be minimum 90 to 120 minutes, perhaps more.

I get how people love this game, I really do. There is surprisingly a lot of tension in hoping the right tiles come out, planning your dice and silverlings, hoping you can grab the right tiles before someone else, and feeling like you never have enough time to do everything. But because of the reasons outlined above, it just isn't my favorite.

I hope to get it to 10 plays and then retire it.

RATING: 8.75
I think this has become mine and my wife's favorite game to play together. The board is drab, the bits are not terribly enticing, and there's not really much theme to speak of, but the game play is so tight that it doesn't matter. It's a quick game to set up and play, the decisions are fun, and the wrinkle the dice rolls present is a great mechanic. But, even though there can be a lot to keep up with, it is a really simple game to explain. It might take several plays to understand all of the tiles and the strategies they allow but the game play is simple, unlike something like Terra Mystica. Roll your two dice and take the two actions they allow. That's it. Again, it may take a while to understand which two actions will benefit you the most, the "what" and "why" of the game, but the "how" is really simple and easy to understand. Great game. 

Update: This game just gets better and better. Really easy to understand and play, but a lot of depth and interesting decisions to make throughout.

RATING: 9
This game is on the longer end of the Euro spectrum, and is definitely very thinky (may not be for the AP-prone). It's really best described as a drafting/set collection game, and at times it feels like you're trying to complete a puzzle. Not as brutal as other Feld titles, but still very tense. The dice constrain what you can do, but there are always options.  You're never able to do everything, but how much you do a particular strategy and when leads to some good varied paths to victory.

RATING: 7
So I guess I don't dislike this game as much as I thought I did. It's a solid game with 2, fine with 3 but adding any more players (especially ones with AP) makes this game drag on far too long. The choices can be difficult, but most of the time it's pretty obvious what to choose, especially once you get yourself going.

I'm not a huge fan of the "everything gives you points" feel of this game and really I think you could take your score and subtract 100 and get what you should actually be at.

The components are standard Alea and are serviceable, but the color scheme for this game is so drab.

Extras: Meeple Realty insert.

Perfect for 2p, great for 3p, haven't played with 4p as it could get a bit slow, but I don't think i would mind it.

RATING: 8
This was the first modern board game that my wife and I played. It was an epiphany that games could even be like this; multi-round strategy, balance, smooth mechanics, and just plain fun. 

We played it tonight, years after having discovered it and the better part of a hundred other games later, and I realized why we don't play it as often as we used to: Dice can be annoying.

OK dice lovers - spare the flames - hear me out. The way dice are used in this game, they are an impediment. In a complex game where you're trying to do five things at once and every move counts, it's a bummer to roll two dice and not be able to do anything substantial to move any of your strategies forward. It becomes infuriating when this happens two or three rounds in a row. Sure, you can use dice to buy worker flexibility or fill your deployment area with tiles that may give you other opportunities (including special powers to offset the luck of the dice), but when you're counting on dice to enact your strategy, a bad run of dice can make the game swingy and just plain irritating because your engine sputters just when you need it to roar. It interrupts the momentum of the game. The mancala structure used by Trajan solves this, as does the dock structure of LeHavre. I like the actual game of Burgundy more than either Trajan or LeHavre, but we play it least of the three because of the dice.

I don't mind dice so much in short shotgun-strategy filler games, particularly where the dice are communally rolled and affect all players racing toward a common goal. In fact, the uncertainty of dice can be a benefit in a short game that is all about building flexibility into an engine. And actually, I really like dice if they're used as a dice-draft mechanism, because at that point, the dice are scarce resources and players can compete for the most valuable ones. In those instances, dice add to the strategy rather than inhibit it. But sitting there waiting for a number to come up... is... well, it's limiting because it means that you are penalized for building long complex intricate strategies because flexibility is a dominant concern if you don't want to get trapped by a bad run of dice. Quite frankly, dice used as a move-trigger mechanism feels a bit like the old "move & roll" games to me.

The flow and win conditions and multiple ways of scoring and winning bonuses are amazing. It is a singularly brilliant game with one annoying hitch.

That being said - I still love Castles of Burgundy.

RATING: 7
So first the cons: Yes the theme is a bit dry and "pasted on" and all that, but even still, it works. Color palette is also somewhat weak, which is a little difficult if lighting isn't great and/or you have weak eyes. Component quality is mediocre. Some players might also feel a bit restricted in options even though there's almost always at least one if not a few good actions to take per turn.
Now the pros: Turns and rounds are quick once you know the rules. Despite the small set of options available the permutations grow rapidly and there's nearly always something good you can do. The game is heavily tactical and the dice mitigation is a solid part of the strategy. It is point-salady, as a typical Feld, but there are still some great options to really bump up one's score with planning.
Overall I think I prefer the CoB the Card Game over this one but it's still a solid, good game.

RATING: 9
Considered by many to be Feld's masterpiece (although I would personally put Macao and Amerigo above it), Castles of Burgundy certainly deserves to be considered an all time classic of the Euro genre. Fabulous mechanisms, above all excellently implemented dice selection, combine with a greater degree of theme than Feld is typically given credit for to produce a game that provides a fun, engaging, intellectually testing experience time after time. The one down side is that CoB has been given a less stellar production than it really deserves (all the cardboard in the game is just a little thinner than one would like and the game's graphic design and artwork is functional at best) but at least the price point at which it is sold reflects this.

RATING: 7
Typical Feld point-salad game, where you have a thousand things to do that all score points, but there is a mechanism in place that arbitrarily limits your options.

In Trajan this mechanism is a mancala, in Macao a rotating compass thingamajig, but in Castles it's simply dice. Not as innovative, but the game moves a lot more smoothly as a result.

Each player rolls two dice, then uses both dice mainly to take tiles from a matching numbered spot on the central board, or place them on a matching numbered spot on a player board. Most tiles are simple, some have extra rules that allow you to build combos. However, keeping things simple and flexible is probably better than following some grand plan, as in the first case you have far more options if the dice don't come up the way you wanted.

In the end the players do fairly similar things in building up their princedom on their player board, but timing and efficiency makes the difference between winning and losing.

A pleasant way to spend the time; who doesn't like to build things and get points for that? Probably my favorite Feld, but I'm generally not a Feld-fan. I like straight paths, clear goals and tense competition, and like most Felds this delivers a multidirectional points-for-everyone personal puzzle game instead.

RATING: 7.9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Enjoying this on Yucata, so can elaborate since my 1 face to face play.

A gamers version of bingo? Feels like it, as a random number (1-6) indicates tile placement, however being a game there are elements that modify the number value. Also tile placement is generally a 2 step affair: firstly drafting a hex tile (according to die roll or modified) onto one of your 3 vacant (off the board) spaces, then secondly from one of those spaces onto the board filled with hexes of different colours and die face values. Your placement is restrained by matching colour of hex, die roll or modified and next to an already placed hex. The game even comes with various board with different configurations of the hex colours and numbers....Bingo anyone?

I think what really makes this game addictive is the gratification of filling in areas of the same colour, a visual set collecting motive as the last placement in the area scores vps (variable depending on number of hexes) but filling all the (sometimes scattered) areas of the same colour gives an endgame bonus. So like bingo there is the drive to fill your board in, but as it is a gamers version there are synergies and kickers to fill in the board quicker (generally as you roll two dice you only have 2 actions per turn). Thankfully there are no kickbacks in the game only unlucky rolls which can't be modified, and there is little interaction except denying an opponent a valued tile from the draft. So a safe choice to play, but I feel the face to face had bloated turns and the scores are too for my taste.

RATING: 8.5
OK, let's get the obligatory dice comment out the way: rolling 1-1, 1-1 as your first four dice scuppers any degree of flexibility; rolling it again (or 6-2, 6-2, 6-2 for that matter) means you do the best you can: but that's 6 rolls of 25 that blew chunks. There is mitigation in the game, but if you've not had a chance to improve it, well tough. All that aside, CoB is a simple (ugly) point salad that plays very well, with definite tactics and strategy. Hone your dice rolling skills, though!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A tableau style game as you are building out your player mat. Mostly an optimization puzzle with several scoring paths to follow. Player interaction is the indirect competition for scarce resources similar to many other Euros, if you want more "in your face" style game this is not for you.

I liked the way the dice are used to constrain your selection options. You roll and have to select actions based on the roll. You can mitigate the problems by making sure you have modifiers, but that has its cost. 
Also liked the player ordering mechanism - using one of the tile types to change the order. Players can end up earlier in the order by timing the placements.
Prefer the asymmetric boards so players have differing values to what they are trying to accomplish.  

With all the optimization planning that really can't be completed until your turn, downtime is an issue, making what is a long game even longer.

RATING: 5
Castles of Burgundy is a fine game, but it really doesn't get me excited. I doubt I suggest this one, and mostly will play it because others love it. In general I'll be happier to play other games. 

To start with, Castles has got to be one of the drabbest, dreariest games in existence. The components and artwork are very boring. Additionally the colors are not all that distinctive, nor are the various symbols used. It's just passable which is pretty much my summary of the whole game. 

The actual gameplay is really quite well done if you're into highly tactical games. I personally prefer more strategy in my games, the ability to long term plan. Castles offers almost none of that. The majority of the decisions you'll be making in this game are all about the turn to turn maximization of your various priorities, of which there are a million. You really can't plan ahead and think you'll do x this turn, and y next turn, and z after that due to the die rolls which dictate the sorts of things you'll be able to do. Now there are always useful things to do, and whatever luck of the die roll there is should mostly even out over the course of the game so I have no complaints there. I'm just remarking that this trait means Castles is a game of constantly reacting to the position the game puts you in, and very little of the game is spent actually making long term plans or even what your opponents are doing. (I'm sure high level players will point out the subtle ways you influence each other, but in general most of the decisions you're making in this game are all about reacting to the situation that the game grants you from the rolling of the dice, to the revealing of the tiles). 

Many many gamers will likely love this. I think it also really helps players that don't love to have to consider a million possibilities and plan ahead--each turn they just need to make the best move they can and they'll fare well in the end. But those aren't the type of games I love, and Castles is certainly something that I find to be fairly mundane. Whatever magic is here that makes so many dearly love it, I don't see it. In the end it's an aggressively mediocre game to me. Nothing about it makes me hate it or even think it is a bad game, but literally nothing about it makes me excited to play it.

RATING: 4
I didn’t think I’d like Castles of Burgundy, but I really wanted to be wrong. Sadly, I wasn’t. The game very much wants to be likeable and inoffensive, but it ended up feeling bland. The points dished out on every turn made it seem like the game was patting me on the head. “Look how good you did! What a great move! Have some points, and then some more points for getting those points!” I feel like CoB might be great to grab if you’re just starting your collection, but at this point I have games that do all the things it does, only far better and with more fun and more style. While I tried my absolute best to focus on the mechanics and nothing more, the soulless art hurt me. I’m sure the low quality art and components were economical decisions, but it made it seem like care wasn’t put into the game. It also dragged on too long for the enjoyment I got from it. Nevertheless, while CoB isn’t for me, it’s not a bad starting point to figure out which mechanics you enjoy.

RATING: N/A
I was never really in love with Feld's games, but this was definitely the game that made any kind of affection impossible. 

A lot of recent Euro games really crank on the Action Selection Restriction. You're not allowed to do whatever you want to do on your turn, rather, you must manage a little minigame that will give you permission to take actions, and then the game is tactical point accumulation when run through an Action Filter. Feld is an absolute master at that kind of thing, but I really don't enjoy it. For one, the kind of gamer who owns one of those type of game tend to also own 50 of them, with more on the way all the time. Consequently, that side of the hobby really seems to focus on "testing the waters" of each new Action Selection gimmick. That's not my hobby. 

But additionally, and perhaps more importantly, I find that we interact with one another very infrequently when we play these kinds of things. I'm sure there are groups out there that have turned Castles of Burgundy into a hilarious social experience, but I find it a deathly quiet game of mostly private tactical optimization. There's no reason this couldn't have "1-4 players" on the box.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is a game I would normally despise. I'm not a fan of:
* point salads
* individual player boards where most of the action takes place
* the strategy of compete in objectives no one else is competing in
* almost non-existent player interaction: you opponents just get in your way

I really enjoyed this game because [b]there are no resource cubes[/b]! Instead, there are lots of hexagonal tiles, and the rules to where you are allowed to play them is exquisitely clear -- unlike [thing=66362][/thing]. There's something compelling and visceral in this kind of clarity as opposed to what typical Euros ask you to do: exchange a cube for another cube for another cube for some victory points, a transaction that doesn't have the geometrical and visual impact of placing tiles on a grid.

But there are two resources, silver and workers, but they don't overwhelm the game. It's really about drafting tiles to play onto your own individual grid, but with huge restrictions (from dice rolls) of which tiles you can draft and where you can place them ... the resources are there to help you nudge those restrictions a bit.

However, I really don't like the goods mechanic in this game; to me, it really breaks the elegance of the mechanic of drafting and placing tiles based on dice rolls.

I've only played this at 2 players. I don't think I'd enjoy it with more.

RATING: 8
Description:
This is a tile laying, action selection game. You will have 4 basic actions to choose from. How you can use those actions are restricted by what number you roll. You will compete with other players to pull tiles from the center of the board and get them to your player mat. Once on your mat, you will slowly build out your little dominion. You'll build some harbors, markets, castles, pastures etc. With each building providing you with an additional benefit. You will be attempting to chain these bonuses to create the perfect turn.

Pros:
1. Brain Burner - This is a Stefan Feld game, so you will be staring at the board, burning your brain, trying to figure out how to eek out that 1 additional action you need to get that extra tile.
2. Flexible - Your strategy can turn on a dime and it won't impact you're overall score. In fact, you will likely have to pivot several times during the game as you adapt to what tiles are available.
3. Multiple Routes - There are multiple routes to victory. There doesn't seem to be one way to win. Instead, you will likely need to dabble in a bit of each strategy as you adapt to the board.

Cons:
1. Length - This games seems to take just a touch longer than I want it too. As we play through the last round, I usually find myself wishing the prior round was where the game ended. 
2. Quality - This game has fairly poor components. The good news is that it keeps the cost down, but I'd rather pay a few extra bucks for thicker tiles and better player mats.

Summary:
Great game at an affordable price. This is a classic Feld game that will burn your brain. However, I think this game is much more straight forward than most of his other games. Additionally, this game works very well at all player counts.

RATING: 9
Very enjoyable "multiplayer solitaire". There is some room for interaction, but it doesn't happen a whole lot, especially if you gather peaceful players around the table. Everyone will follow their own goals and interaction will be almost non-existant. EDIT: Played a bit more with 3 and 4 players and there is more interaction, on an almost perfect level for an "optimization euro".

That being said, it is still a very good game. Every strategy seems to be viable, there's no single aspect of the game that can be diminished. There's some brainburning involved, not too much, just enough to have fun even with sunday gamers. Easy to teach and easy to grasp, seems like a perfect step from gateway games to something more ambitious.

The only complaint I have is that sometimes the moves become too obvious. If you already follow a certain strategy, many turns are automatic. I need THIS tile, I need to put it HERE, I need to sell THOSE goods... Doesn't happen a whole lot, but sometimes it does. Minor flaw for me.

UPDATE: After about 20 plays I realized this game is great in any setup and hardly gets old. I think it deserves 9 at the least.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
We have acquired this game recently after playing Castles of Burgundy: The Card Game and boy oh boy, this game did not disappoint. It is one of the best games designed by Stephan Feld and it deserves all the praise that it gets. IMO, this game is better than any other Stefan Feld games I have played (Amerigo and In The Year of the Dragon). 
I knew hype behind this game and its standing in BGG community but still I was skeptical about it. Even when Govind was explaining rules to me, I did not expect much. However it is during gameplay that I fell in love with it.

Reasons I love the game:

1) Deep euro. The game has incredible depth. I love the fact that I can plan 2-3 rounds ahead. I also love that I can plan entire game and the best strategy to get maximum scores even before starting the game.
2) Dice worker placement. I hate dice and I hate it when dice rolls screw me (which has happened multiple times) but in Castles of Burgundy, it does not matter. Due to worker tiles, you can balance your dice roll easily. It does not hinder the game in anyway whatsoever. 
3) Variety of maps. Player mat provides complex version of map on the other side of it. This makes the game lot more interesting. And each map is different from the other. Love that complexity.
4) Replyability. There is enough randomness to ensure that this game will come to our table multiple times. Govind absolutely loves this game which is a bonus.
5) Limited VP salad. I did not like it much in Amerigo and I am glad Castles has it in a limited scale. That makes the game all the more appealing to me. 

Things I did not like:
1) RULEBOOK and COMPONENTS:  Rulebook was difficult for me to understand. It is difficult for me to understand rulebooks as it is and Alea has made it as dry as they could. I just could not read it. Thank god Govind loves reading rules.
Govind and I, we both did not like quality of the components. Player boards are flimsy, token are poor quality and it is just not value for money. Now I understand it is an old game but this is one area where I really wish someone would revamp the whole game.


That is all. Apart from that, there is nothing I dont like about the game. I LOVE IT.

RATING: 8
An excellent game. Lots to think about, plenty of options, multiple strategies. Dice are used in the best way: you roll first, then you may spend to modify the roll, then you select an action that the modified roll allows.

There is little interaction with other players; if you dislike "multi-player" solitaire, you won't like this game. But there is interaction in the usual Euro competition-for-scarce-resources way, and you'll find yourself planning your turn by eyeing your opponents' dice rolls and trying to predict how they'll use them, and how you can screw that up.

Scales well from two to four players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

It plays very well as a two player game (although I haven't played a three or four player game yet) and gives you great options without causing too much analysis paralysis. This game looks like it would be very complicated to learn/play/teach, but is the complete opposite of that.

RATING: 9
Dice allocation, tile placement, set collection, medieval building Euro game.
Weight: Medium.  Number of players: 2 to 4. Scales well.
Designer: Stefan Feld.  Publisher: Ravensburger, alea Big Box series.
Impression: Even we played it wrong in the beginning it was very interesting and exciting Euro game. After a while it became one of my favorites, especially when we introduced different board variations. It is the best representation how luck and planning can be combined to the best results. It also rewords optimal moves and action combos. Very good game.
Likes: Variability and multiple ways to mitigate unlucky dice results.

RATING: 6
Well balanced Euro game, in which your dice roll sets the possible actions to take. There are many different ways to score victory points (trading, cities, pastures etc.) and there is no superior strategy. There are some more aspects  as turn order management and which areas in your kingdom to fill. Luck of dice rolls can be very easily mitigated by  workers.

However, to me this really feels  like a victory point salad and for me this is a rather soulless Euro. In general I like Euros, but here there is almost no theme and most of the game are abstract mechanisms. Even though you are building a kingdom, there  is pretty much no economy built (maybe  apart from the silver mines), which is probably the main reason, why all mechansims seem abstract to me. You definetely do not feel like you are building a small province (as you do in Catan). The art is also rather bland and uninviting.

RATING: 7
First off, this game is not a good game to play with those who are prone to AP.  It is enviable at some point in this game thus the less players in this one the better for me. As a three player game, it has moments that drag.  if you have no die adjusters than it's a long wait as others are trying to figure out what you do. Each turn is a little puzzle-y and has a bit of a Kingdom Builder feel when you try to get a combination of tiles however, it is much more frustrating as it's hard to plan on others turns because the main board changes so much with the players in front of you.  I don't want to be totally negative as it seems mechanically it's a good game with unique use of dice and it seems that building and watching your estate expand is somewhat entertaining but it just didn't have a fun factor with three. The building of the estate doesn't even feel like you building anything as you are so fixated on getting tiles down and completing area that the theme just slips away.   For me, I'd like to try it again with just two as it seems it would be a little quicker and maybe more engaging.  Just fell a little short for a Feld game and I rather play Macao or even It Happens over this with respect to his designed games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Clever game. Choices, variability, luck, planning - all neatly calibrated. Roll dice > choose tiles > place tiles > score points. Presents tough choices between filling small areas early for higher points, or holding out longer in the hopes of even bigger scores for the large areas. Offers way to mitigate luck, and a wide scope of variability in bonus tiles and board layouts. The gears fit together perfectly. 

Also lacks drama, conflict, narrative, and interaction. This is the poster-child for a well-designed, accessible, and completely inoffensive euro. For those times when you want to engage with a moderately challenging and stress-free puzzle in parallel with another person. Wouldn't want to play with more than two.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
This is a Stefan Feld game and while it uses dice, I wouldn't term it a "dice game."
You do use dice to acquire and place tiles on a personal board. There are limited ways to place tiles and where to place them. The tiles themselves may give you immediate rewards or ones that work each turn.
This is now a must have for me.

RATING: 9
Nikki: 8

This is one of the first games that I was introduced to where I said, "Wow! Who designed this?... Want to play again?" The balance of decisions between the acquiring and placement of tiles, from beginning to end, makes this an interesting game.

I'm still amazed at how well the game implements 2 dice without feeling like you were cheated by the luck of the die, and I can't help but enjoy the satisfaction of creating a 4 or 5 action combo with those measly 2 dice. Feld caught my eye with this one, and, as you can see by my other ratings, I've enjoyed exploring his other designs since.

RATING: 6
26-01-2015. Rated after 1 play. Castles of Burgundy is one of the first Feld games I played. I think the game is ok, I liked it. 

Each round, you roll 2 dice and buy tiles from a rotating/random display. These tiles give you special abilities or points. You score for many things, animal tiles score you points, some buildings give you points, finishing an area gives you points (more at the start) and special yellow tiles give you points at the end.

I liked it, but it didn't wow me. It's good, I can see that but lacks all passion.

RATING: 8.5
I can see why this is the top Feld game.  Macao is still my favorite Feld game thanks to the windrose, the greater long-term planning, and the constant threat to get your cards in play, but unlike most Feld games, the different ways you get points in CoB are much better integrated. I can see how the different boards and different subset of the tiles drawn each game should lead to greater replay value (it does seem that the boards with 6-8 tile regions are stronger than those that don't have any regions bigger than 5). I will say it is probably one of the best choices for a relatively deep 2p euro that won't take too much more than an hour.

RATING: 8
Very cleverly designed. It's a dice management game where every action during your Turn relies on your dice rolls. However, it's not the traditional old trash where one always wins by rolling 6s. The dice result only governs the target of your action, but doesn't represent a certain power or strength. You still need to brainstorm yourself in order to find a possible winning strategy.

RATING: 8.5
Castles of Burgundy was my first Feld game, and it still is the game he designed (among those in my collection, clearly) I enjoy the most. It's incredibly heterogeneous even if the strategy for winning is more or less always the same: complete the smallest areas first to capitalize the bonus points / round; try to choose carefully the knowledge tiles to maximize the points in the end; focus on mines and castles as soon as possible since these tiles give you extra actions or extra money to get the most powerful black tiles. Still, there are so many varying factors that we still have to play twice the same game; not to mention that during the years Stefan designed many and different boards so that replayability is really granted.

Finally, even if the game implements dice, the incidence of luck factor is not particularly high: there's always something you can do with dice, also thanks to the clever workers mechanic where, by spending worker tokens, you can "manipulate" the results. Really, a brilliant game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Playing this game I feel like I've been assaulted by an army of icons. Before you can begin to play the game part of the game and enjoy the game part of the game you'll have to conquer the mountain of different cardboard chits with their special little meanings. Okay... once you get past all that (it's not so difficult), you've got a decent little dice game that plays well 2-3 and with 4 if you don't mind the downtime.

With 101 different ways of scoring points it could almost pass as a Ystari game, but Alea can be happy to have this in their catalogue too. Mainly you'll be racing your opponents to certain tiles and to close off certain areas. With 25 turns you can't do it all, so you'll have to determine what will work best in what combination.

It's very low on the interaction (just a little bit of tile acquiring before your opponents), and it ticks along in a flurry of point grabbing here and there. So much here and there that it's super easy to rush your scoring and overlook grabbing points you're entitled to.

Mechanics match the theme in no way shape or form. You're rolling two dice representing workers? Geographical influence? They let you buy or build or sell stuff. If you've got nothing decent then you can add a couple of worker influence tiles.

Replayability comes from knowledge tiles coming out differently game to game, different player boards and opponents playing in different ways. You can choose to do your own thing, or try and block your opponents from getting choice useful tiles. Ideally you'll be doing both.

If you like to roll a few dice and not have them mean too much, then you might like this little race puzzle. It'll get a play under your belt where it might seem like just another soulless Euro, (it certainly felt that way to me first time around), and it is, but there's some good decisions to be made and it's nice to see dice making a Euro gaming comeback. Feld's Macao did a nice job of using them and this one is a similar weight to that. Quite decent.

RATING: 8
Yet again the typical Euro of getting something to take another that improves your position, or to obtain victory points. Nevertheless, the dice and the spacial elements make it a little different. Players actions depends on the roll of two dice, and mostly they consist in take tiles from the center of the table, put the tiles into the private boards or sell commodities. The objective is to develop a region and its different kinds of territory: country, urban, coastal, special places and quarries. Every board has its own strategy, and the players interaction is guaranteed because of the fight for the different tiles and the race for the bonuses.
