RATING: 8
A truly enjoyable (and usually quick) tableau builder. I'm a sucker for tableau games - Race for the Galaxy and Glen More are high in my list - and this is among the best.

This game is extremely well-balanced, in that scores will usually be tight (I lost a recent game 233 to 231) despite players using different strategies. (For example, my opponent in that game had no mines, but was able to score small districts very early.) Plays very well with four players and equally well (if not better) with only two. In my opinion, these are remarkable traits for any game to have.

The down side, of course, is not the randomness to me (hearing Tom Lehmann complain about rolling seven doubles in a row and giving up on the game seems a very shallow criticism) but that usually your decisions are very obvious. This is not a difficult game to parse, so players will often pick up the strategy right away on their first game - even somewhat inexperienced gamers. As a result, I think many dedicated gamers will bore of this.

This isn't much of a criticism, though. To me, this is a fantastic Settlers replacement and gateway game. I have seen many Ticket to Ride level players really become addicted to this game and I'm super-happy to see them latch on to this - a gateway into Stefan Feld's world, what more could we ask for?

That said, I think the goal for a heavy gamer should be to figure out a way to fill their entire tableau. Can it be done??
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Finally a game from Stefan Feld that has a payoff at the end for laboring through the "language of the game". Die Burgen von Burgund (German name sounds cooler -- like Burger on Burger) ropes together a lot of fundamental ideas from other Eurogames, and glues it all together with the action dice. You need a die to swipe a tile, and another die to place it in your tableau.

Any time you use dice as actions, there's always the 2 extreme risks: it is too luck-dependent versus does it not even matter what I roll since everything is good -> I just follow what the die tells me to do and take it like a bitch. This game falls more into the latter category, but the decisions involved are interesting enough to make it a non-issue.

My only complaint is that the game is a little too long for what it is. Game length has to be justified by a linear/exponential increase in interesting situations and options. Die Burgen von Burgund doesn't really get any more interesting the further along in the game you are (it's less an upside-down pyramid, more a building that tapers off at the bottom), and it can get repetitious. Trimming the # of rounds and the size of the player boards would have worked better.

==================

Aw what a dumbass I was. There is no payoff, just a gimmick that's cute for the first 30 minutes, like every single Feld game ever designed. As I suspected, the game didn't get any more interesting, but it was a lifetime thing, not a once-in-a-game thing (i.e. the first 30 minutes were interesting, but on the basis of your experience with the game, not the first 30 minutes of each play). Bone-dry game. And though you ostensibly should follow what your dice tell you, the strategy is to always have flexibility with the dice to prepare for a rainy day, which means it's almost pointless to screw others, since they can always climb out of that hole.

Hot tip: be aware of any game where it's possible to score 200+ VPs. It means the designer just let himself go, and gives you a carrot for doing anything from sitting down to play a game to doing an action. The OVER-JUSTIFICATION EFFECT in full force. VPs should only be awarded for POWER-MOVES, not for scratching your ass.

RATING: 1
Hi! This is my original comment:[hr]Complex, painless, themeless. 

The games I don't get intrigue me, they are elusive, they involve people in such a way that produces unpredictable outcomes (emergant). This is not such a game. There is no theme worth naming such, there is no interaction - you're just staring at your own board (okay, yes, there's [i]rich interaction[/i] which involves grabbing a tile from the market before someone else does). 

What this is: a spatial puzzle you must solve by managing random elements and special powers of some tiles. That's all of it. And it manifests as a victory point salad, which seems to me like laziness on designer's part. Or it's just another step from conflict into the friendly euro zone when you get instant gratification for nothing. 

It's a sissy game. 
Which means it tries very hard to hide the fact that it is indeed a game. 

And I realised I was giving some colder Uwe Rosenberg's design hard time unjustifiably. Uwe's game have focus and even in their prussian coldness, they're charming in that old german way. This has no focus (victory point salad) and no charm either. It's that aunt that let you eat everything you wanted and you didn't end up any better for it. [hr]Later comment:

Back in the day people were talking about euros again and some guy called Feld and something called "a victory point salad". Of course, me being clever, I was sure what they're talking about. Then I played Burgund von Burgund and ... [i]Oh![/i] A realization dawned. So that's a victory point salad! It's not about points at all, I mean, yes it's about points from everywhere, but it's not the points that matter (they're everywhere!), but the dilution of tension. I couldn't have imagined that even the tiny amount of tension and interaction in workerplacements could be diluted further. But hey, if anybody could do it, Feld's your man. (He's also the man to make an auction be about optimisation, but that's another game). [hr][b]But what you really want to read is this: [listitem=3781054][/listitem][/b]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Played once with 2P and another time with 3P, with a 2 year gap between games. In Castles of Burgundy, players compete to fill their estates with various landscapes, and earn points when they cover regions, ship goods etc. All actions are determined by the 2 dice each player rolls at the beginning of every round, which makes Castles of Burgundy a combination of both strategy and tactics.

The first thing I noticed about the gameplay is that it's surprisingly concise and straightforward for a Feld game. As the landscape grows and players begin collecting more knowledge tiles, the scope of choices also gradually expands and strategies begin to solidify. Unfortunately this also leads to some considerable downtime as players agonise over their optimal move for the turn.

On the whole I quite like Castles of Burgundy. The core mechanism isn't quite as attractive as that of Macao's or Trajan's, and the range of choices can be daunting as the game progresses, but I appreciate the tightness and relative simplicity of the gameplay here.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
My perfect 10 game. If you're into light to mid-weight Euro games, this is the game for you. Sure the components are sub-par but that allows this game to be affordable to the public (under $30). I highly recommend that you play this with 2 players only. Avoid playing at 4 if possible. Its very simple, you roll two dice on your turn and depending on the number you could either grab tiles and/or place tiles corresponding to the pips. Every turn is a rewarding turn and because of the game's design you can pull off a long chain of combinations that'll reward you tons of points!

Dice Rolling, Set Collection, Tile Placement
Wt: 3.0

My most played and favorite eurogame. I love the wealth of choices you have in each turn, but also how clear those choices are and how simply and elegantly everything sort of meshes together into a coherent flow. It's marvelously well-balanced, and it's relaxing to play. The only tension comes at the end of the game, when you're tallying up you final points to see who squeaked out a victory. The pay-off from combos is great, and I love trying to beat my high scores.

RATING: 8
[2011-04-23]
Notre Dame, Macao, In the Year of the Dragon és most itt a Burgund Stefan Feldtől. Lehet, hogy Stefan Feld rajongó leszek? Fantasztikus játékok, a Burgund pedig hozza az előzőek színvonalát. Kockadobálás, szerencse? Közel sem! Nem is éreztem a játék során, hogy óriási gondban lennék a kidobott értékek miatt. Eleve a kompenzáló munkáslapkák könnyen szerezhetőek, bőven van lehetőség különböző akciókra, így tényleg nem szerencsejáték, de mégis meghatároz egy lehetséges kört, amiből a játékosnak a két akcióját fel kell építenie és a legtöbbet kihoznia belőlük. Mindenki a saját birtokát építi, városokat, legelőket, várakat, bányákat húz fel, hajókat indít árukért. Sok lehetőség, egyáltalán nem nehéz szabály és játékmenet. Nem éreztem lassúnak, szerintem négy játékossal sem nő meg jelentősen az üresjáratok ideje. 2 játékossal pedig tökéletes élvezetet nyújtott. Stefan Feld csak így tovább!

[2011-05-28]
Hihetetlen, de 3 játékossal is két-két pont különbség lett a végeredmény. Nagyon kiegyenlített játéknak tűnik és úgy érzem nagyon magas az újrajátszhatósági faktora, főként a különböző kezdőtérképek miatt is. Talán egyedüli negatívuma lehet, hogy négyen kicsit sokat kell várni esetleg mire újra sorra kerül a játékos, de majd erről később nyilatkozom.

[2013-04-15]
Négyen nem biztos, hogy ajánlott játszani. Hárman is rendesen hosszúra nyúlhat. Az újrajátszhatóság a többféle térkép miatt valóban magas, de azért vannak benne logikus és újrajátszható stratégiák.

RATING: 8
I've wondered... what is it that makes The Castles of Burgundy special? As much as I like this game, in my mind there's no doubt that there are many Feld games that are superior. Despite that, CoB continues to be his highest ranked game on BGG by far.

I think the reason might be accessibility. There are few games that are as easy to learn while providing this level of strategic depth (can't find any in the top 20). Once you start rolling those dice and working out how to grow your estate... there's no stopping anymore.

Play it!

RATING: 10
Oh wow. This is truly one of my favorites of all time. It feels so good when you're playing, building your little... what is it supposed to be? A town, or city or something? Whatever, who cares? it's not the most thematic game out there, but it is sooooo good. Really, i can go on and on, but suffice to say that Mr Feld is certainly one of my favorite designers, if not my favorite - and his stuff just gets better and better. If you like low interaction, deep euros, and you dont mind some cool dice stuff thrown in, you will love this game. The bits are nothing to rave about, and the color choices are pretty but,...well...stupid. Nevertheless, the game is a masterwork.

RATING: 5.5
Most overrated game in the top 100, for me, without a doubt.  I had such high hopes, since I love Macao and Bruges.  Really makes me wonder about the ratings on BGG.  The gameplay is rinse and repeat, for 5 rounds, with no arc, or build up.  Feels about one round too long as well.  Way too hard to not mess up the scoring at least once per game, by not remembering to take these two points or those two points, or wait, I have this tile that says I can get this, or do that.  Did I take that last round?  I don't remember.  Then the game ends 173 to 172, and you wonder.  But that's not even the biggest problem.  The biggest problem is the variety of different boards.  
Someone on BGG, did a statistical study of all the different boards, and found the average scores for a 2 player game, to be as high as an 18 point variance.  So with some boards being 6 points better and some boards being 10 points better, do two equally skilled players, play with a handicap then?  When I play with the board that is 4 points better on average, and I win by 3 points, should I feel smart?

RATING: 5
Decent euro with mildly interesting decisions--and tons of tactical depth thanks to the dice-allocation mechanism. Indirectly interactive and plays as well or better with fewer players. The artwork is bland and the theme is nonsensical, yet they're both functional. Mechanically, it's rather unique. On the one hand, it's not a bad action optimization game. On the other, it's dry, repetitive, mechanical, anticlimactic, and the individual player boards are symptomatic of how little interaction there is. In other words, it's a typical Feld. Like so many Felds, I suspect that this one would play as well solo as it does with others. 

To be fair, the dice ensure a measure of dynamism, but overall the game just isn't very compelling. This isn't sour grapes, either. I'm good at the game. But what does that mean exactly? I'm good at tactically optimizing points for the sake of scoring points? Optimization is a skill, but it's not why I play games. There's no narrative arc here, and there are few opportunities for meaningful interaction.

RATING: 7.5
This is a pretty fun game! I just wish the production quality were better: the player boards are flimsy, the tiles are on the thin side, and the colors are just terrible and washed-out looking (and the yellow on the board doesn't even match the yellow on the tiles)! Also, gameplay seems ideally suited for the full complement of 4: with fewer, you won't see all the tiles and it seems you could just luck into a very good (or bad) situation when that last turn comes around. Still, I wouldn't mind having a copy of this cool game.

--- Summary ---
Players start with a random set of two (or 3?) goods on their play mats. Also, a number of worker tiles (= position in turn order), which allow you to modify die rolls +/- 1.

The board shows 6 numbered areas each with space for several tiles (a new set is placed each round, some specified but most random; will see all tiles in 4er game by the last round); an area in the center (for the black-backed tiles); and spaces for goods tiles. The non-goods tiles are one of several types (beige buildings of different types, each of which gives you a different reward when built; green cities, which immediately give you another virtual wild die; yellow tiles, mostly for end-game VP bonuses or in-game rule modifiers; blue boats, which advance you on the turn track -- Macao style -- and also allow you to take one group of goods tiles from the board; gray mines, which each give you 1 income; green pastures, with 1 of 4 animal types, which gives VP when played). There are 5 rounds, each with 5 turns. Each round, place 5 goods spaces randomly on the board in designated areas.

At the start of each turn, one of those goods is placed in an area corresponding to one of the 6 numbered areas. Players collect their income (based on number of mines), then simultaneously roll their 2d6; 1st player rolls an extra die, to determine which space to place the goods tile for this turn. Then, in turn order, take your actions by spending your d6 (will be using the numbers rolled):
- take a tile from the same-numbered area on the board; place in your staging area (space for 3 tiles)
- place a tile you've previously taken (now in your staging area) onto a matching numbered space of your player board; must be adjacent to another tile, and same building may not be built twice in the same area. Some tiles may award immediate VP. If you completely filled an area, earn VP (more for larger area and earlier in game); if you were the 1st or 2nd player to do so for that area type, take the corresponding bonus VP tile (to be scored at end of game).
- sell all goods of matching number: earn 1 gold + n VP per tile sold
- take 2 worker tiles
- in addition to dice actions, may spend 2 gold to buy one of the black-backed tiles in the center of the board

After 5 turns, the round ends: remove all tiles on the board from the game; refill with new tiles from supply (will see all tiles by the end of the game if playing 4-player). After 5 rounds, award end-game VP:
- based on yellow bonus tiles (e.g., for each building of a specific type; for each color of goods sold during game; etc.)
- bonus tiles for having completed areas on player boards
- 1VP per unsold good
- 1VP per 2 workers
- 1VP per gold
Most VP wins!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very cool Euro.  I never played a Feld design until a couple months ago and since then I've played 3 (In the Year of the Dragon, Macao, and this one) and they've all been winners, including this one.

This one is a small departure in concept from my other Feld experiences in that this game is a lot more forgiving and leisurely.  The other two Feld games I've played were very harsh, punching you in the face and making you pay heavily for your mistakes.  When I realized this I was a little afraid I wouldn't enjoy this game.  I actually tend to like punishing games, the tension gets my adrenaline pumping and has me excited and on the edge of my seat.  This design, while still providing opportunities to directly compete, mostly had people doing their own things and I also tend not to like mostly solitaire experiences.

What this game has in spades though is charm.  I love rolling dice when the mechanics are expertly designed like this game.  The dice results determine the actions you are able to take but these really just present a rough guideline on what you are able to do.  The resource to increase or decrease your die results is abundant and easy to acquire so the dice end up just directing you into the easiest and most efficient moves out of a couple options.

These actions are some combination of putting different items onto your estate and/or shipping goods for gold and victory points.  In the end that makes this a very standard Euro.  Your goal is to have the most VPs at the end of the game and so the goal of your actions should be to create the most efficient VP engine.  To go along with the friendly tone of the game are beautiful soft colors and tiles depicting happy animals grazing and oil-painted Victorian buildings.  The only real opportunity for player interaction is acquiring tiles your opponents are after, especially the rarer ones.

There are certainly people out there that prefer more forgiving and leisurely-paced games with an inviting coat of paint and this is the perfect Euro for those people (most Eurogames don't tend to fit that bill).  It is so charming even I greatly enjoyed it and would probably never turn down a gentlemanly game.

RATING: 3
From a rules read through this looks like it has some similarities with Macao - dice, and instead of lots of  card powers this has lots of tile powers. Its also a very flimsy theme - to the extent that it seems a shame that Alea did not try and find something that suited rather than more fragging castle building in the fragging middle ages - a space theme could have worked v well here.

Gripe over. The game looks fascinating, though how interaction works worries me, as players have their own boards and there appears a lot of Macao like opportunities for mini combos and specialisation

English rules in the box - what a good idea to cut out the middle man!

Graphic design terrible, This game is really too 'big' for the alea format. It needed a bigger box. bigger, tiles and better colouring and design. a triumph of 'beige over function'

Think i preferred 3 player to four.

After 4th game i have really gone off 'Die Burgen' - in latest game 3 of us were sperated by 4 points having totalled well over 200. winning or losing seemed meaningless in the context of the score as none of us could identify why player had performed better than another, Moreover, there is no real strategic arc to the game - it just feels like rinse and repeat in most of the 25 turns. Player interaction is really limited to turn order and grabbing a tile before someone else (possibly nabbing a needed animal in 2 player)- otherwise its a real shared solitaire exercise, in fact the game would probably work well as a solitaire. The game feels far too long for what it is. There are lots of clever little combos which are nice to pull off, however they are done in isolation.Add in the terrible graphic design and its now sold








=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I will admit I was expecting some sort of punishment that is all too commonly found in Feld's games.  I really enjoy this game as it does dice placement in a much better way than others like Kingsburg.  Your dice rolls are overall fairly easy to manipulate so there is always something productive you can do on your turn.  Only two actions per turn makes the game move along at a nice pace too.  Highly recommend.

UPDATE:
Down from a 9 to an 8.5.
Played again this weekend and I think the game is just too tactical for it to be rated any higher. There really isn't any longterm planning that can be done. Original Review:
I should probably rate this game an '8' if I'm being completely accurate, but just because of the pure enjoyment I get from this game, I'm bumping it up to a 9.

The rulebook and initial learning period is a bit unintuitive, but once you "get it," it's super easy to understand.

I like that there are a lot of strategic options, but your actions on a turn-by-turn basis are limited so you don't get too tired out from overthinking. Yes, there is some randomness, but you never feel like the game is what beats you. 

If it weren't for the terrible components and blank artwork (seriously, everything looks beige), it would be bumped up to a 9.5. Deluxe edition please.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Mechanically sound if you like this type of game. This is not my type of game. Need to give it another try though.

There are too many ways to get points. Nearly everything you do gives you points. This makes me feel like I had little to do with the outcome. Everyone optimized the best they could so it was happenstance that things ended the way they did. I did not feel I played any better or worse than the other more experienced players. A close score around nearly 200 points validates that to me.

There are lots of choices to make but there isn't much meaning to them in the long run as you will get points from any direction you go. The choices are a kind of red herring as you are really just sifting through them trying to find the most efficient each turn. Many choices you might make for planning ahead are leaps of faith as the future resources are random. I've heard that this goes away at max players because all the tiles will be used.

Dice are used to limit your choices and actions but these are easily modified. You can still have turns where you simply didn't get as optimum a roll as others. While I'm fine with that in many other games, The amount of points from so many actions means the loss of 2 points from things outside your control is more detrimental than 2 points gained from a choice you made.

The first turn dice results and player order will determine your starting direction but this again becomes meaningless as you may not get what you need to work that direction and points can come from many other directions as well.

The tiles that provide bonus points will give you direction early on but you may not see many of the tiles that go with it for those bonus points. Like wise, later bonus tiles may only be good for one player because they already have many of the related tiles to benefit from the tile. 

There is little to no player interaction. Taking tiles you don't need to hurt a leader also hurts you.

Player order can have a large effect on the outcome of turns but you can affect player order.

The game is boring as hell to look at. The colors and art work are dull and muted. Theme is barley there.

RATING: 7.5
A good game of engine building and special powers.  It does however run quite long to play well.  It is no where near 90 minutes unless you play it a ridiculous non-planning-pace. To be honest we've only see our play times increase since you are able to increase your downstream planning when you have more knowledge of the interactions possible.  Its primary problem is that to play well, you MUST take time on your turn to analyze the board situation--most of that CANNOT be done during the other players' turns since the board situation changes substantially with each player.

It is very good, but is it worth the time to play?  That is a question that can only be determined by how much we end up bringing it to the table.

It has similarities,not just in mechanics, but it over all feel to several other games.  It's closest to Glenn More which plays in about an hour, compared to 2.5 to 3 hours for 4 players.  It also has a bit of a feel of an expanded Agricola, which is pretty cool since one of the things I don't particularly like is how confined the options are in Agricola.  Diamonds Club hits all the same points in a much more streamlined fashion, but it is lighter fare--so if you're looking for something with a nice developmental arc with lots of interaction, CoB is a go-to.

Is has a heck of a set up and take down time, but the game length offsets that--at least the game is long enough that you don't feel like the set up is unreasonable in relation.  But is it worth the 3 hours to play it well...maybe--but consider that some of the 18xx games like 1889, are leagues better and take about the same amount of time.  Now stylistically they are very different, but these long time slots are pretty precious.

In 1889, because it is a zero luck game, and allows significant downstream planning, you are in control of your game.  In CoB, your decisions are primarily tactical, and it is possible to lose simply to luck.  Is 3 hours of gameplay where you can win or lose based on luck a good deal?  Well, it's a pretty fun ride, but the game is definitely hovering on the edge of being traded away

RATING: 7
Very good dice allocation game. It has the usual issues that the wrong dice and the wrong time [i]can[/i] screw you, but it's one of those designs where your choices usually run the gamut from the good to the great, so "cutthroat" play is the equivalent of taking the last macaroon from the dessert tray. "That villain Mr. Bingley has taken the last macaroon -- should I take an éclair or a profiterole?"

This kind of convivial garden-party atmosphere makes it a pleasant and enjoyable way to spend time. Depending on your proclivity for games that set your heart racing or make you cackle with glee at particularly vicious play, that could be damning with faint praise.

Not recommended with four players; that extra 50% downtime over the three player game is a killer.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Brilliant. Typical alea. I want to do this, this & this. Unfortunately, I can only do that. A quick look up. I'd best do that now because it probably won’t be there next turn. Not a cube shuffler (no cubes!).

It’s a tile laying game. You gather tiles, you store them, you place them.

Restrictions & constraints everywhere. Timing matters. Sometimes you want turn-order position, sometimes you want to grab goods. Sometimes you want to complete an area to earn a bonus tile. Cash matters - with cashflow, you could obtain another tile every round. Storage matters: you have a 3-tile store - all tiles have to go through that store before being placed. Workers matter - your two actions per turn are partially dictated by dice. Workers allow you to tweak die values (including 6/1 rollover).

In the first session, we played twice. First with the "beginners #1" boards, then we decided we were pros and went for random boards. [i]Ooof that was harder[/i]. Tightly constrained choices. Much greater need to plan ahead to create flexibility.

No colour issues whatsoever. No "small icons" problems (we printed 3 pages from the rules PDF as a crib sheet, but the buildings page was almost unused in our second game). A great small-footprint game where the combined central board plus four A4 player boards fit conveniently on a table.

RATING: 9
Rice-rolling and allocation game with a territory building theme. Each turn players roll two dice, the numbers of which allow certain actions to be taken. There are various tiles depicting different types of land usage and these correspond with one of the numbers on the dice. These tiles can be selected and then placed on the players' 'princedom' boards. To place the tiles within the princedom regions another corresponding dice number has to be obtained. Points are awarded for the first player to complete certain types of regions and having matching types of certain tiles. This is a simple yet clever game and despite the core mechanism being that of dice rolling, luck doesn't seem to play too great a part in the eventual outcomes, which leads to 'TCoB' being another excellent lighter strategy game from designer Stefan Feld.

RATING: 4
CoB went over well with my wife because of the theme (it has farm animals) and the MPS build your own little empire aspects without interference. It did seem to run a little long but that's not too surprising for a first game though it does concern me when we play with more than two. For me the game doesn't strike me as particularly interesting BUT it was a pleasant experience and I expect to see more interesting choices in future plays. The art style is pleasant but could have been more evocative and identifiable. The iconography is okay but could have been better. The box insert is useless and the components are a little thin as seems to be Alea's custom.
I can't see this being much fun with 3/4 players. It's pretty dry and slow.

--

I've really soured on this 10 games in. It's only playable as a 2p game and the more I play the more random it feels. Strategic choices are almost impossible due to the random tile draw and tactical combo play gets old fast. The constant counting of points for every little action adds to the dearth of fun to be had.

RATING: 8.3
A fantastically well designed middle weight game with great mechanics that integrate really neatly. This is probably one of my most played games. It's light enough to be interesting and non-intimidating for newer players, but has enough depth and strategy for more experienced gamers. My only caveat is that it is a lot like multiplayer solitaire and once you have once strategy, you tend to stick to it so the replayability might not be optimal.

Rating raised to 8.5

I wish the pieces were 25% bigger and had more memorable graphics.

RATING: 6.9
I feel a little like this whole game is set up so that you never really have to worry about what numbers you roll. I can see some benefit from that; losing because you didn't roll as 'well' as someone else is frustrating, but why bother having the dice if every combination is good?

This game suffers from the usual Feldian 'everything you can do is worth something' and so each choice feels a little underwhelming; there are 29 things I can do, each is worth approximately 6 points... but as usual, smoothly put together and runs quickly. My favourite of the non-fillers from Mr. Feld.

RATING: 8
You can score so many points playing this game!  You play the role of a land baron building out his domain, and buy different land tiles to place onto your own land.  While there are many little pieces to this game, playing your turn is not very complex.  It feels very fluid and feels satisfying to land large boatloads of points!  I would not recommend learning to play this game on your own, but conversely I think that everyone should play this game to get a taste of the excellent design that comes from Euro style games.

RATING: 7.5
The theme is totally tacked-on and the game can get pretty fiddly with the replacing of tiles each round, but the game itself is still a lot of fun! I absolutely love the mechanic of being able to modify your dice rolls. It has saved me from a LOT of terrible rolling, and I probably would never have even looked at this game without it (not after my one and only game of Stone Age where I rolled a die above 3 maybe twice - never again!). There are many strategies to maximize your actions and point scores and the randomness of the tile setups ensure different paths to victory with each game. A great game overall!

I love the combos in this game. I love games that score lots of points for things you do and this is the epitome of that type of game - nearly everything you do will get you some points or will lead to points later. Once you learn the play is very smooth. Toughest part is remembering what all the different buildings do - the player mat helps with this tremendously. Despite being 'easy' to play there is a lot going on so this is probably not a 'gateway' type of game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
3/26/2017: This is the only Feld's game that I have played so far, and this is the highest ranked from his design. I generally does not like a game that depends too much on luck, especially ones that rely heavily on the use of dices. This one is one of a few that convinces me that a dice game can still be strategic. I love how a player can try to push his/her luck and there is still a way to mitigate bad rolls. There are so many different ways that one can focus their attention on and try to score as much point as he/she can. I agree with what most people have voted that this game is best played with 2 players. The downtime between turns will become longer when you play with either 3 or 4 players. 

One criticism that I have for this game is the component quality. I hope it will get an upgrade with better quality component, because this game truly deserve it!

RATING: 4
Overly long and AP-prone. When learning, I highly recommend that you play with just two. Even so, I simply didn't find the game fun. Point salad with multiple paths to victory. Is it done well? I suppose, but there are so many other games that do it better and with less reliance on dice. Without the dice, you can plan ahead and not feel the frustration of watching your opponents get exactly what they need while you get stymied. It's just another level of complexity that isn't needed, but nonetheless feels novel because it's dice in a strategic Euro. Like Bora Bora, Castles finds an interesting idea for a mechanic through dice, but bolts it onto a boring exercise in point scoring. No thanks.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The workers are a decent consolation prize for rolling very poorly, and they make it easier to get the results that you need.

RATING: 10
Somehow Stefan Feld manages to use dice as an incredibly good action selection system. You always feel as though there is something you can do and rarely ever get terrible rolls, just some that are better than others. You can mod to do one good action or do two or if you plan well can do multiple actions. 

It's intuitive yet clever. No AP, you could play it super strategic or play on a whim and still have a good time (the latter will make you lose but you will still get a sense of accomplishment). The scoring system is really good, the different paths you can take to victory, and the way you have to plan your construction while adapting to the rolls. 

There is just the right amount of actions, not too many, but enough to make it interesting. I looove how you can chain the actions and as such I like castles and buildings that give you free tiles, and collecting silverlings. But all of the strategies are fun to play, and it's easy to mix it up and try different things. 

And I have to mention the scoring system again, which pushes you to try and build quickly, so you have to choose between quick building vs efficient building.

RATING: 7
Castles of Burgundy certainly fits the Alea mold - there's no doubt this is a gamer's game and not family fare. However, I'm a little surprised the ratings so far are this high (7.82 average for 292 ratings as I write this in late April 2011). I won't argue that Burgundy is a solid offering with some clever parts to it. However, there are flaws that I suspect will keep this from matching the lofty ratings I've given some of the best games in the Alea line. First and foremost, this is almost a complete abstract - the theme is somewhere between paper-thin and nonexistent. It's far from elegant - the set-up and round upkeep is definitely a bit fiddly with all the small counters. I also fear it may have some balance issues - ships and mines in some combination seem pretty essential to victory, and they'll get snapped up by the start player every time. I also wonder if the luck factor - hey, it does use dice, even if bad rolls can be mitigated a bit with workers - is too high for a game of this length and complexity. All that said, I realize there's some real depth here and more to explore, but I am doubtful this will ever rise beyond a 7 rating for me - a good game but not a great one. I guess it's a tribute to the Alea line that I expect great rather than good from them ...

RATING: 6
City/countryside development powered by unpredictability. Each turn you use two dice to randomly determine what buildings you can plan, what board locations you can build upon, what goods you can sell, and what resources you can gather. Careful planning and management of the randomness is rewarded with points from a variety of categories.

The first several times I played I had to constantly ask "How do you score points again?" because there are so many multi-step processes involved.

RATING: 9
When you first look at The Castles of Burgundy on the store shelves you may look right over it because flashy it is not. The Castles of Burgundy was released by Ravensburger and to me feels like it comes from the old guard of Euro greatness even though it was released in 2011. It stands with games like Puerto Rico and Agricola as top tier, world class Euro games when people give suggestions for what to play. After playing The Castles of Burgundy a decent number of times I can wholeheartedly agree with all the good press the game has received. Firstly the designer is one you may know: Stefan Feld. If you don’t know Stefan Feld that’s ok but I’m hoping that this article along with the how to play video I plan to produce will bring him to your attention.

As I’ve stated in many of my other reviews I’m fairly new to tabletop gaming and have only seriously been playing since early 2015. Since I am newer to the hobby I have the joy of going through the back catalog of games from prestigious designers. The first designer I started with was Uwe Rosenberg, and that has been a fun journey. I’m now exploring the catalog of Stefan Feld and this is just as much fun but completely different in every way. There are a few significant differences in the way that these two designers work. Where as Uwe is about optimization within very tight framework, Stefan is about optimization in a system filled with abundance. There are so many points, so many choices and a bit of randomness thrown in for good measure. This isn’t to say that Stefan Feld’s games aren’t superbly designed or unbalanced, it’s simply to say that you get a much different feel playing a Stefan Feld game than most other tight Euros. In Castles of Burgundy, as with many other Feld titles that I have played, the points flow freely and most of your choices feel like good choices. Even if your choices aren’t necessarily as good as they could be they feel good.

There is one thing about The Castles of Burgundy that hit me from the very beginning of my exposure to it. The basic framework of the game system is fairly straightforward. The mechanics are satisfying and make sense. Within that solid mechanical system there are tons of choices that will impact you in different ways and make each play feel unique. So even though the game is very simple in it’s initial offering take one of four actions based on what you roll, actually picking those actions to maximize your effectiveness is very interesting indeed. I’ll go into a bit more depth about the types of actions you can take and the types of choices those actions present. 

The board is set up in a circular fashion where tile depots around the board will determine which dice are required to take tiles from that depot. So for instance there is a number one depot that has access to two - four tiles depending on the number of players. The depots go from one to six to match what you can roll on your dice. At the start of the round each player rolls their dice and plans their actions. Then each player in turn order gets to take two actions with their two dice. The first type of action you can take is placing a tile from one of the depots in your tile storage. This action is simple, you can spend a die showing a three, to take any of the tiles from the three depot. Your tile storage space can store up to three tiles so that limits you a bit, but in general that’s the first action you can take. 

The second action you can take is building tiles from your tile storage onto your player board that shows your own personal kingdom. This is where a lot of the game’s choice and complexity comes in. There are a number of different tiles that will give you special bonuses when you build them, at the end of the round or at the end of the game. You could build one of the eight different buildings to start building up city zones on your player board. Each of the eight buildings give you a special bonus whether it be taking a tile from the middle with no required action or gaining silver etc. You could build a castle that will then allow you to take a free action as if you had a die of any result. You can place livestock tiles that will give you bonuses if you combo animals of the same type. You can place ships that let you gather goods to sell and move you on the turn order track. These are just a few examples of all of the available options to players. All of this goes to show that the options in this game are many and the rewards are good. 

In addition to all of the bonuses that these tiles give you rewards are given for completing all of a certain type of tile first. So for instance if you are the first player to complete a zone or all of the castles on the board you will gain bonus victory points. So there is a high reward for efficiency both with your time and your tile placement, which is quite satisfying when you get a really interesting combo to work. Usually I will try to go for the bonuses or actions that other players are not pursuing, which usually means that I’m doing something completely different than the game before. This variability is a huge strength to The Castles of Burgundy. I haven’t even begun to scratch the surface of the other parts of the game that can be mixed like the unique player boards or expansions that can be purchased, just the base box provides quite a bit of content.

The Castles of Burgundy stands a cut above most games. There are certain games that when you play them you instantly feel the genius behind the design even if the game is not your speed. When you feel the genius and you also love the mechanics then you truly have a wonderful experience ahead of you with many plays to come. With the expansions mentioned above that are available to provide more variability and more player boards to provide a different target I think I’ll be interested for years to come. 

I’ve currently collected five of Stefan Feld’s games and The Castles of Burgundy is my favorite. There’s plenty of tension at two players but three and four play very well too. Strategies will change based on the player count but balance will not and I feel that this is another reason that the genius of this design is evident. For instance in a four player game good tiles are much more important at four points each, but in a two player game you can win without focusing solely on them. In a four player game the goods are worth more but they are harder to get, so it tends to even out. 

Another incredible aspect to The Castles of Burgundy is the price tag. At $42 USD I feel that the content you receive for the investment is outstanding. The tile laying and puzzle solving aspects will keep your mind engaged and the free flowing points will keep you satisfied as you explore this strategic sandbox of a game. I would highly recommend picking The Castles of Burgundy up if you get the chance and if you don’t like it let me know and I may buy it off you!

RATING: 9
Had a great time with this game. Lots of strategy and, like all of Feld's best games, many ways to score points. RATING: 7.5
First Impression:

An oldschool euro, with excellent gameplay and neglected if passable theme. 

I'm quite full of bland themes and I dislike the use of dice in euros. However this game is acceptable, as the theme does manage to carry through somewhat (despite minimum effort from the production) and the use of dice as randomizers is actually very well implemented (even if still not cool). Other than that, the game works and rocks from a mechanichs point of view, offering simple yet tough choices, a rewarding gameplay and a lot of interaction.

This game appears to be Feld at its best and seems of exceptional design. However it just doesn't captivate me as some modern games that manage to best combine the best of both worlds (strategy and theme) which this game doesn't try to do.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Castles of Burgundy is an incredible game.  It has the distinction of being the game my wife loves most.  This is sublime with two and good with three and a little long with four.  

You take and place tiles based on die rolls.  There are ways to mitigate the luck of dice, namely workers that let you adjust die rolls and being somewhat deliberate in where you place tiles so as to open up new potential places to place items.  Many tiles give you special abilities, some of which help to take or place tiles, some of which help you get money or workers.  There is quite often a battle for start player and there are various strategies that you can take, some of which will depend on which individual player board you play.  

Even taking advantage of every opportunity it is impossible to fill your board completely so you should have a plan how you're going to get points.  Filling areas scores points, more for scoring early and more for filling large areas.  There are also tiles that give bonus points.

It's a well balanced game.  It sometimes feels like multiplayer solitaire, although it isn't.  One of my favorite games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The game is set in the Middle Age in France (Burgund[y]). Players slip into the role of an aristocrat and at the beginning they reign over a small princedom. While playing they aim to build settlements and powerful castles, practice trade along the river, exploit silver mines, and use the knowledge of the travelling people.
The game is about placing settlement tiles into the princedom. Every tile has its own function which starts to work when the tile is placed. The princedom itself consist of several countrysides and every countryside demands its own settlement tile.
The core mechanism of the game involves 2 dice. The pips show the kind of action the players are allowed to do (example: roll a "2" and a "5: using the "2" the player buys a watch tower and places it on a "5" city tile which triggers the function of the tower with additional advantages).
It's also possible to influence the dice, so using the dice is not completely subject to luck. 
There will be a beginner and a master version of the game rules.

RATING: 7
06/2012:7.5
A very Feldian design with die rolls limiting set actions but having enough choices as well as die modifiers to offset the role of luck in the game. Make no mistake, the die will still bite you occasionally when you want to take a desperate last minute action but you can't due to a bad roll. Overall, a very solitaire feel to the game with very limited interaction. The only interaction from the game comes from tile choices and availability which means if you go down a path where no one else is taking, then you are safe. However, if everyone is pursuing their own agenda,vthe game becomes more like a solo puzzle. The only teo things that i consider are negatives are the constant scoring ehich i find somewhat tedious and potentially error prone and also the length of the game. That said, I have enjoyed most of Feld's designs and this is no exception. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Very high level of "You totally went where I wanted to go" game play. Like Macao with less foresight, there are plenty of things to do, limited by dice rolls, mitigated by additional mechanics. Somewhat Kingsburg-ish in that respect, but with many, many more options. 

Player interaction is also on par with KB, but entirely more maddening as resources are extremely limited. I found myself forcing my gaze away from the board when it wasn't my turn, as nearly every round my carefully laid plans would be shot to hell by the player in front of me. 

While I enjoy the planning ahead aspect of Macao, I like DBvB's similar dice-selection mechanic just as interesting. It's a slightly different beast, but just as enjoyable.

RATING: 8

RATING: 8
I enjoy playing The Castles of Burgundy, and find it to be one of the most relaxing games in my collection. However, I would not consider it to be one of the deepest Euros in my collection as it seems to suffer from "Feld syndrome"-  almost any action you take will score you points, so final scores are usually remarkably close. Usually the player who makes a few marginally better decisions will win, and it is very difficult to determine why one player performed better than another. That being said, I like the game, but if I want to play a heavy Euro for 2 players with lots of strategic depth, I will play something else instead.

RATING: 5
Would it kill Feld to design something thematic?  His games are always tightly-balanced interesting beefy affairs that feel like nothing so much as blandly counting points over and over and over again.  He's got a great mix of short-term gain with long-term strategy here, but the theme is offensively thin.  Towns, castles, boats, livestock and technologies are all nearly the same, and used only as extremely sparse justification for different currencies and scoring systems.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.4
Another phenomenal Feld dice game, instant smash hit here in the household. Each player rolls 2 dice, then uses the dice to perform various actions, such as using your 6 to take a tile from the "6" area on the board, or use your 2 to place a previously taken tile on one of the predefined "2 spots" on your personal board.

There are only 4 actions to learn, but the game has an amazing amount of variety in it, and different ways to score points. 4 different kinds of animals which score bonus points when grouped with their own kinds, 8 different kinds of buildings, each building with it's own unique benefit, such as money, points, dice modifiers, extra tiles, etc. Mines earn extra money, ships bring in goods which get sold for points and money, and then 26 special tiles provide bonus abilities and point multipliers of your other tiles. Further to all this, you get points for filling in areas on your board, so specializing is also good.

Essentially, you want everything, but can't have it all. But that's good, as you always feel like there's something good to grab or do with every dice roll. People who hate dice should still like this game, as rolling high or low has nothing to do with doing well, and there are ample opportunities to get dice modifiers, to help those times when you want a 3 instead of a 4 or 2. A nice touch is that dice wrap, a modified 6 becomes a 1, again, really helping you out.

Just a fantastic game. Highly recommended.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.7
This worked well with the kids after I convinced them to finish a full game.  By the fifth phase we were going through the rounds VERY quickly, and we could each see how the scoring fit together.  There are many ways to score points, but they interact with each other, and the "points building on points" mechanisms are fun to figure out without giving anyone a runaway victory.

As a fan of games that have non-intrusive randomness in them, I really like the way this game becomes less dependent on randomness as it continues; by the second half of the game you have access to knowledge tiles and workers that make your desired rolls much more likely, and the endgame is a matter of cleaning up the strategies you stumbled into in the opening of the game.

My absolute FAVORITE thing about this game is how the kids are figuring out the value of mitigating randomness on their own.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Like Troyes, DBvB uses dice as a random method to determine a tactical move, and like Troyes, you're not specifically restricted to exactly what you rolled on the dice to do something on your turn.  Of course, rolling the number you  need is better, but you're never without something to do just because you didn't roll a 5 when you needed it.  Aside from modifier abilities, the game provides enough options with any given die to allow players to branch out and build up their tableau for better turns in the future.

There are a lot of tiles to keep up with in the game, along with the abilities they grant the players, so this isn't for a bits-averse gamer.  The better you understand the abilities and how they relate to the actions you can take, the better you'll do in the game, so the learning curve is a little inclined, if not necessarily steep.  The turns are straightforward (roll two dice, and take two actions based on your numbers); it's understanding how to use those actions to your best benefit that's the challenge of the game.

I'm not sure if this is a game I would play often, much less own, but it fills its own niche, and is satisfying enough as a game.  The randomness of the dice can lead to frustrations, but the special abilities of certain tiles can put you in a position where a bad roll can still do a lot for you.

1 play: 4 players

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is the game that made Stefan Feld a superstar game designer and it's not hard to see why. It's basically a tile laying game, but the selection of tiles is not blind, but instead limited by the role of the dice. Randomness is randomness, but there is something supremely satisfying about rolling some dice and making the random results work for your strategy.

Many of the tiles trigger abilities when placed as well, which provides even more to think about when you make your selections. I think this is why the game has found so much success, as it appeals to both the planners and the folks who just wing it...and because of the dice, neither is really at a disadvantage.

The only complaints to lodge are the rather flimsy components. The cardboard is paper thin and the player mats even thinner. They tiles are also quite small, meaning there isn't much on them but a tiny picture of a usually indescript building. This leads to lots of rule book referencing to puzzle out what everything does for the first couple of plays or if you come back to it after a hiatus.

Still, compared to the sheer amount of enjoyment the game provides the complaints are fairly minor. Just about anyone can get into this game and judging by the BGG ranks, almost everyone has.

Excellent game.

RATING: 7
It's pleasant enough, and an enjoyable tactical game. I have a hard time seeing any real depth here, or much to learn past the initial and fairly obvious lessons. For tougher choices, it should either be one phase shorter or each phase should have four rounds.

After more plays, with more boards, I just can't get too enthused about it. It's too long and too on rails. I've never seen score separation greater than 5%. Barring extreme variances of luck, that is, and there's more luck here than initially meets the eye, esp. in tile draws, but also in die rolls and safe bets that may not pan out.

It's a fine, pleasant game but I do not get its popularity.

RATING: 3
This game has entirely turned me off to ever wanting to try a Stefan Feld game again. This was probably the heaviest game I had tried at the time I picked it up. For a while I assumed that I simply liked lighter games and that was my major problem with this game. I did not enjoy trying to teach the game because I was new to the hobby and so was my wife who is my main gaming partner. Trying to learn this was rather difficult even with online videos and I have come to the conclusion that the reason for this is that the theme is so loose that I could not attach mechanics in my head to what we were supposed to be doing. I am not that heavily into theme but it does make teaching a heavy game easier. Most importantly though is my personal preference. Games that I like generally present decisions that I feel carry weight for the future of the game. I also prefer games where scoring points is done in multiple ways but that are goals set as part of a strategy. You could make the argument if you have a strategy for this you will score much more points than otherwise and I'm sure you are right but I really dislike making a choice like do I take this thing that is worth 3 points or this thing worth three points. They may be done in different ways but if the outcome is the same I am not excited about my decisions. I'm obviously in the minority about this game but I could not bring myself to play this game again after only a couple of plays.

Plenty of different strategies available to win, none of which seems more victorious than another. The theme is non-existent.  The game feels like you're just rolling dice, picking up and placing tiles, and moving components around.  Good mechanics, but very dry theme.  I dropped my rating because the game lacks an engaging reason to be doing whatever you are doing.

RATING: 8.5
The look and feel of a great Euro, which plays very well for two people when often I find many 2-4 player Euros leave 2 players feeling like there's a lot of room to stretch their arms.  

Castles of Burgundy has no room for arm stretching.  It's every decision makes you feel like you are going to win or lose the game.  When your opponent races ahead of you, a real panic sets in and grips your throat.

This game is fabulous!  I highly recommend it for couples looking for a highly competitive, non-area management board game.

RATING: 9
This is one of my favorite games and one that I would never turn down playing. While my BGG stats are low, I've probably played this game more than 100 times when you include its implementation on Boiteajeux.net.

For all intents and purposes, Castles really is a step up from a gateway game but it's that simplicity that I really enjoy. The randomness of the dice and how you mitigate them, the variability of your personal board and how the tiles come out on the main board, working toward combos that net you more turns and more points than your opponents, all while trying to ensure that you can timely thwart what your opponents are doing, makes this a great game.

Yes, the game is lacking in "theme", although I can definitely find it in there, and even though the "points salad" moniker has a negative connotation and people generally like to dump on this game due to its lack of theme and its mechanics first game play, I love this game and think that it's great.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.3
After noticing the way up in the BGG top 250 of this game, we became interested in it. We watched a review, and we became even more interested. We decided to go mad, and order it, without even trying it at the gaming club. Unfortunately, it was sold out, and we would have to wait about a month before it would arrive. That would be somewhere in the middle of January 2012. Well, “it’s a pitty, but we’ll live”, we said to each-other. What a big surprise it was, when I unwrapped a present last night, and a copy of this game was inside. I couldn’t wait to start playing. Too bad for me, the alarm clock rang at 5:45 this morning, and I had to leave for work. After coming home this afternoon, I wanted to play it. But first we had some dinner. And then we finally could start the game.

Well, start reading the rules. It seemed to be an pretty easy game. Just like Puerto Rico. Easy to explain, easy to teach, easy to play. And a lot of interesting choices which could be made. And none of them are wrong. A real mind breaker.

A game takes 5 round, each round takes 5 stages. Each stage a player has to roll 2 dice. Then he can do 1 action for each die. Nothing more, nothing less. The actions are.

 - Take a hexagon tile onto the player board
 - Place a hexagon tile on the player board in the kingdom
 - Sell goods
 - Take 2 worker tiles
 - A possible 3rd action, is to buy a black hexagon tile from the center of the game board.

The hexagon tiles consist of 7 different types. Each type has it’s own special advantages. And that’s when an easy game, becomes difficult. Because of the advantages of a tile, there are a lot of possible strategies which can be followed. What is wise to do? If I do this, then I could (maybe) do that, in my next turn. Of course there’s luck involved in the game. The tiles which has to be placed onto the game board, are placed randomly. You have to throw dice. But…. the dice can be controlled by using worker tiles. If you use a worker tile, you can add or distract 1 from a die. And when you build a special kind of hexagon tile, you can even add or subtract 2 from a die. You can change a 6 into a 5 or 1 and then into a 4 or 2. That way, only the 3 is missing and that just by using 1 worker tile. So these guys can become very important. And the luck involved in the game isn’t that big deal anymore.

After 2.5 hours of reading and playing I can only say one thing.

Finally! We’ve found it! This year’s game with the magic spark. This one is just fantastic….

RATING: 7
After playing A LOT of other games with similar game-play and mechanics, Suburbia, Catan, Tera Mystica (Gross), and other build a place/ town/ empire games, I have come to truly appreciate this game for it's fairly solid design and replay-ability. Burgundy stood up to more play throughs than any of it's counter parts , even out shining Catan as the better replacement. 
Sure I have personally gotten almost all the play a can out of it, after dozens of plays, but I still find myself longing to play this game when I run into one of the many problems that the games of this rather comfy genre are plagued with, that this game seems to somehow lack.

RATING: 9
This game is awesome. It's a very good 1v1 game, though expanding to 3 or 4 players is great too. There's always quite a bit of options, and the dice rolls make it so you can't tunnel and have to diversify while keeping in mind a couple of end goals. I really enjoy the mechanics of this game, especially the dice rolls aspect selecting which tiles you can get for a turn. It's not a perfect 10 because some of the board can get repetitive, but that's a minor complaint.
